The attack was an unprovoked act of war, and resulted in the deaths of 37 sailors and a civilian, as well as damaging the ship's radar and electrical systems. Traffic data is collected by MDOT every 5 minutes during daylight hours (6:00 to 9:00 AM and 3:00 to 6:00 PM), and at other times when there is sufficient traffic to warrant a more in-depth analysis. This data is then compared to a pre-determined set of traffic volumes and the level of congestion that would be expected based on that traffic volume. If the data is in line with the pre-determined levels, no action is taken to alter the traffic signal timing or striping. In the event that the data falls outside of the pre-determined levels, an engineer is sent to the site to investigate the cause of the discrepancy.

Now, after decades of rehabilitation, work is under way on an $8.5 billion project to replace the bridge and its traffic-signal system with a high-tech "smart bridge" that will be the world's largest in terms of span length and number of lanes.

Background

Naruto Uzumaki's childhood friend and fellow genin, Shikamaru Nara, is one of the most well-known members of Konoha's ANBU.[1] In the anime, it is shown that Shikamaru has a crush on Naruto, but is unable to reciprocate due to his chakra being tied in a seal that prevents him from doing so. However, he does show interest in Naruto's team, Team 7, and the idea of working with them to achieve their goals and become Hokage.

Personality

Shikamaru is a kind-hearted individual who cares for those in need of help and will go to any lengths to help them. He is shown to be loyal to his friends and family, as shown when he sacrificed himself to save Naruto from Gaara's Lightning Release: Rasenshuriken, and was willing to risk his life to protect Naruto's friends and family from Orochimaru's reincarnated Susanoo. Despite this, he is not above betraying his friends if it comes to the best interest of the group. The Civil War [ edit ]

[3] On the eve of the war, Confederate forces were in control of the city, but a Union victory would be a blow to the Confederacy and its ability to wage war. In an effort to gain support for the war, Lincoln issued Proclamation Number 8, which called for the city to be turned into a military base and declared martial law, banning slaves from leaving the city and forbidding them to travel without a pass. This was followed by the Emancipation Proclamation of January 1, 1863, which freed all slaves in the state of Mississippi, except as provided by the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850. The city's population swelled to a peak of 2,000,000 in 1864, before falling to 600,000 by the end of the war.

prefix_text: Meridian was a small village at the start of the American Civil War in 1861. Its strategic position at the railroad junction led to the Confederate construction of several military
reference_text: installations to support the war. During the Battle of Meridian in 1864, General William Tecumseh Sherman led troops into the city, destroying the railroads in every direction, as well as an arsenal and immense storehouses ; his forces burned much of the buildings to the ground. Sherman is reported to have said afterwards, " Meridian, with its depots, store @-@ houses, arsenal, hospitals, offices, hotels, and cantonments no longer exists. " Despite the destruction, the railroad lines in the city were rapidly repaired, back in operation 26 working days after the battle. Race relations remained tense during the Reconstruction era, with the riot of 1871 following a fire that damaged many businesses.

History and expansion in the 20th century Edit

In 1861, the town was home to a Confederate fort and its garrison of over 1,000 soldiers. The fort was destroyed by Union forces in the Battle of Gettysburg on July 1, 1863, and the Confederates retreated to the town, taking with them their artillery and other war materiel to be used in the war to come.[1]

After the war, the Union government attempted to reincorporate the town into the United States of America by annexing it, but this was opposed by the townspeople, who felt that it was too small to be of any use to the Union and were willing to fight to the death rather than give up their land and homes for the benefit of a foreign nation.[1] As a result, the town was left to its own devices for the next three decades, until the Great Depression of the 1930s brought an end to the economic boom that had taken place in the early 20th century. prefix_text: During the American Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s, Meridian was home to a Council of Federated Organizations ( COFO ) office and several other activist organizations
reference_text: . James Chaney and other local residents, along with Michael Schwerner, his wife Rita, and Andrew Goodman, volunteers from the North, worked to create a community center, holding classes to help prepare African Americans in the area to regain the power to vote. Whites in the area resented the activism, and racial tension often resulted in violence. In June 1964, Chaney, Schwerner, and Goodman went to Neshoba County, Mississippi, to meet with members of a black church that had been bombed and burned. The three disappeared that night on their way back to Meridian. Following a massive FBI investigation, their murdered bodies were found two months later, buried in an earthen dam.

prefix_text: Meridian is rightly considered an architectural treasure trove being one the nations most intact cities from the turn of the last century. Architecture students from around the nation and Canada
reference_text: are known to visit Meridian in groups as part of their coursework due to numerous structures in the city having been designed by noted architects. The only home in the US south designed by noted Canadian born Architect Louis S. Curtiss, famous for inventing the glass curtain wall skyscraper, is extant on Highland Park. The Frank Fort designed Threefoot Building is generally considered one of the best Art Deco skyscrapers in the US and is often compared to Detroit's famed Fisher Building. Noted California Architect Wallace Neff designed a number of homes in Meridian as well as in the Alabama Black Belt which adjoins the city across the nearby Alabama State line. He had relatives in Meridian and Selma who were executives in the then thriving railroad industry and would take commissions in the area when commissions in California were lean. His work is mostly concentrated in the lower numbered blocks of Poplar Springs Drive where his 2516 Poplar Springs Drive is often compared to the similarly designed Falcon Lair, the Beverly Hills home in Benedict Canyon of Rudolph Valentino. One Neff work was lost to an expansion of Anderson Hospital in 1990 and another in Marion Park burned in the 1950s. The Meridian Post Office with its interior done entirely of bronze and Verde marble is also noteworthy as a very fine example of the type of Post Office structures built in thriving and well to do cities in the 1920s and originally had Lalique lighting which was removed sadly during a 1960s remodeling and which are now in private residences on Poplar Springs Drive and in North Hills.

prefix_text: Early public education in Meridian was based on the 1870 Mississippi Constitution. From 1870 to 1885, trustees appointed by the City Council served on the Board of School
reference_text: Directors, which had authority to operate the schools. Although there were several schools in the city before 1884, they were privately owned and only enrolled about 400 students. The city did not build its first publicly owned school until September 1884. The first public school for blacks in the city was held in facilities rented from St. Paul Methodist Church. The Mississippi Legislature amended the city charter in January 1888 to allow the city to maintain its own municipal school district, and in March of the same year $ 30 @,@ 000 in bonds was approved for the city to build new public schools. From this bond, the Wechsler School was built in 1894, becoming the first brick public school building in the state built for blacks.

In the early 1900s, Meridian became a center of African-American education in the state, especially after the Civil War. During this time, the school system expanded to include a high school, junior high, and elementary schools as well as a community college. By the early 1920s, there were over 2,000 students in Meridian's public schools, most of whom were black.

In the 1920s and 1930s, a number of changes took place in Meridian's public schools. For example, the Meridian High School was closed in 1930 and replaced by the Meridian Junior High School. This change was in response to the city's need for more space for the growth of the city and the surrounding area. Also, the city began to implement a "separate but equal" policy for black students, which resulted in the closing of the Meridian High School, which remained open until it was torn down in the 1960s.

prefix_text: Meridian is served by the Meridian @-@ Lauderdale County Public Library, located at the corner of 7th Street and 26th Avenue. The city originally ha
reference_text: two Carnegie libraries, both built in 1913 – one for blacks and one for whites. A group of women had formed the Fortnightly Book and Magazine Club in the 1880s and began raising money to build a library for the city. The books they collected and shared within the club were later the basis of the library collection for Meridian. With wide support for the library, the club enlisted Israel Marks, a city leader, to approach the national philanthropist Andrew Carnegie for funding assistance. The library for blacks was built at 13th Street and 28th Avenue on land donated by St. Paul Methodist Church, and the library for whites was established in a building originally owned by members of the First Presbyterian Church of Meridian, who sold it to the city on September 25, 1911. The African American library was the only library for blacks in the state until after World War I and is the only Carnegie library ever built for African Americans in the country. The two libraries served the city until 1967, when the institutions became integrated because of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, combined their collections, and moved all materials to their current location. The former white library was renovated and converted into the Meridian Museum of Art in 1970, and the former African @-@ American library was demolished on May 28, 2008.

Aerial view of Maidenhair Stairs (photograph by Chris O'Brien)

There are two staircases that lead up to the top of Maiden Stack, one of which is known as the 'Stairs of Mourning' due to the number of gravestones that line the path. These stairs are the only means of access to the top of the tower and the most difficult to climb for non-elite climbers. It is said that one in ten people who attempt the climb die before reaching the top. This is not to be trifled with, as the tower is one of the most dangerous places in the world to be on a night of bad weather.

The staircase at night (photograph by Chris O'Brien)

In 1884 an expedition of French and British naval and military personnel landed on the island of Papa Stour to establish a base for the Royal Navy and the British Expeditionary Force (BEF). This was the first time in the history of the French colonial empire that a foreign power had set up a military base on French soil. It was a time of great excitement for the French, who were keen to prove their mettle in the Far East and had no qualms about spending millions of francs on the construction of the base. However, the British did not take kindly to this intrusion into their territorial waters and in the summer of 1884 a battle broke out between the two navies in the Gulf of Suez. The British won the battle and on the following day took control of the island, which they renamed Port au Prince.

After World War II the French began to look for a way to get their hands on the island and by the 1960s they had managed to secure a lease from

prefix_text: The island is composed of a variety of volcanic and sedimentary rock formations from the Devonian period. At that time the Scottish landmass formed part of th
reference_text: Old Red Sandstone Continent and lay some 10 @-@ 25 degrees south of the equator. The accumulations of Old Red Sandstone, laid down from 408 to 370 million years ago, were created as earlier Silurian rocks, uplifted by the formation of Pangaea, eroded and then were deposited into river deltas. The freshwater Lake Orcadie existed on the edges of the eroding mountains, stretching from Shetland to the southern Moray Firth. The structure of Papa Stour is largely made up of ashes and lavas from volcanic activity associated with this period, including bands of solidified volcanic ash and lava ( rhyolite ), but there is also a Devonian fish bed at Lamba Banks. There are numerous large boulders deposited by Pleistocene glaciation.

prefix_text: Papa Stour is the subject of a 1299 manuscript written in Old Norse, which is the oldest surviving document from Shetland. It deals with a
reference_text: dramatic incident in the house of Duke Hakon Magnusson, who was later to become King Hakon V of Norway. There is a circle of stones near the beach at Housa Voe, which are the remains of a'ting ', or local assembly. This was the scene of a duel, fought and won by Lord Thorvald Thoresson, who was accused of corruption in the 1299 document and was later called ‘ dominus de Papay ’. ( The story of his unfortunate daughter is referred to above. ) The remains of Duke Hakon's thirteenth @-@ century house are still visible near Housa Voe.

dispute between Stour (or Sýr) and his brother-in-law, Þorsteinn, over who should be the heir to the land of Stour's father and his father's father.

The dispute is resolved by the intervention of the archbishop of Orkney, who appoints a committee of three to arbitrate the dispute. One of the members of the committee is a man known as the Red-Haired Man, who wears a red cloak and is said to have the head of a hare. This is an allusion to the legend of the Hairy-nosed Man, who, according to the legend, lived in the forest and killed hares for their pelts.

The Red-Haired Man's name is a play on the word red, which means "blood" in Old Norse. This may have been a pun on the name of the committee, or it may be that the red cloak symbolises blood, as in the case of the Hairy-nosed Man.

In the 1299 manuscript, there is a passage in which the Red-Haired Man says: "You are the son of my brother in law, and he is the son of my father.

It is called the'ald kirk'by locals and referred to by the Ordnance Survey as " the site of a Romish chapel belonging to about the twelfth century ". There is a tradition that the work there was interfered with by supernatural powers and that each day's work on the building was destroyed during the night. Eventually the cornerstones were moved overnight by these unearthly agencies to the present site of the church and work was re @-@ commenced there successfully. Excavations in 2004 found little besides large blocks of rhyolite and a piece of whalebone rib, suggesting that the oral tradition may have some truth to it.

This was a tradition which, however, was confirmed by the Rev. W. R. Macpherson, who visited the island in 1891-1902 to investigate the history of the church and its relation to the island of Orkney. The following is a translation of his report : — " I was able to make a tour of the island, and found no trace of any church, nor was there any trace of any Christian burial-mound on the island. There were, however, a number of tombs, which had been made by the natives of the island to serve as places of sepulture for their dead. These tombs were in a state of disrepair, and the soil was covered with a layer of peat, which had been laid there as a kind of covering for the graves. prefix_text: In common with many small Scottish islands, Papa Stour's population peaked in the 19th century and has experienced a significant decline since then ( s
reference_text: e.g. Mingulay ). By 1970 the island school had closed and the population had declined to sixteen'fairly elderly'residents, but an advertisement in Exchange and Mart reversed the decline. A croft and five sheep were offered free of charge to incomers which brought a flood of applicants. By 1981 the census recorded a population of 33. However, by 2005 the population had fallen to 20 after serious discord between islanders led to several court cases. A number of people left the island and the school closed. By early 2008 the population had dropped to just nine after a family of seven left. The 2011 census recorded a usually resident population of 15 - during the decade 2011 @-@ 11 Scottish island populations as a whole grew by 4 % to 103 @,@ 702.

Papa Stour is a relatively unspoilt part of Fife with a population of 1,890 (2011 census), making it the most densely populated island in Scotland. It lies at the mouth of the Tay River, which empties into the Firth of Forth ( firth.scot/en/visit/papa-stour ) and is bordered on the north by Loch Lomond and on the south by Argyll and Bute. The island is about 20 miles (32 km) long and has a land area of 4 sq mi (9 sq km; see map).

History [ edit ]

Early records of the island date back to the 12th century, when King Malcolm of Scotland (d. 1294) was said to have landed on the island in a ship with his wife and a group of Scottish nobles. The first settlement was established in the mid-13th century by a group of Scots who came to the island seeking a place to settle after the death of their king and his succession to the throne of England. This group was led by John Macleod, an Englishman who had been granted a charter of the island by King Malcolm, and his descendants

prefix_text: The Aberdeen trawler Ben Doran A178, foundered on the Ve Skerries 3 miles northwest of Papa Stour, on the evening
reference_text: of 28 March 1930 while on her way to the village of Scalloway to land her catch. When she grounded weather conditions were fairly good but it was not until the following day that a passing trawler saw, and reported the wreck. By the time that various rescue attempts were launched by the coastguard and local volunteers ( there being no lifeboat in Shetland at that time ), weather conditions had deteriorated to the point where it was impossible to approach the skerries. A request had been made for the Stromness lifeboat from Orkney, only 120 miles away, to launch, but the request was made too late to be of help. All 9 crew perished in the wreck. Only 3 bodies were recovered, that of James Mitchell, which was returned to Aberdeen, and the bodies of J. Cormack and J.R. Insh, which were buried in Scalloway.

of the 24th.

The crew were rescued by the Coastguard and taken to Aberdeen for treatment. All were uninjured except for one who suffered a broken leg in the fall.

A search was launched for the missing trawler but no trace of it was found. It is believed to have capsized in rough seas and was adrift for a few hours before it ran aground.

Inspector John Macleod, of the West Highland Rescue Co-ordination Centre, said: "We are working to establish the circumstances of the accident and will be liaising with the Maritime and Coastguard Agency to try our best to find out what happened."

He appealed for anyone who may have seen the vessel to contact the police.

prefix_text: Papa Stour's most recent shipwreck occurred on 9 December 1977 when the Aberdeen trawler Elinor Viking A278, skipper Alec Fl
reference_text: tt, foundered on the Ve Skerries. The Aith Lifeboat came to the scene but was unable to get near enough to rescue the crew because of the sea conditions. At the request of Alec Webster, Coastguard Station Officer, Lerwick, a volunteer crew in a British Airways Sikorsky S61N helicopter from Sumburgh Airport was scrambled. They managed to winch all the boat's crew to safety within hours of the grounding, despite the storm force winds. The helicopter crew later received a number of awards for bravery. There was no loss of life, but this incident prompted the building of a lighthouse on the skerries in 1979, and may also have been the example required for the formation of the present Search and Rescue helicopter unit, based at Sumburgh Airport.

A total of 12 lives were lost in the wreck, including that of Captain Flindell's wife who was on board as a stewardess.

In a bid to raise awareness of the dangers of shipwrecks, the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) is holding a two-day symposium on the safety of fishing vessels in the South West Pacific.

The symposium will be held at HMAS Albatross (Drambuie) in Fremantle from Thursday (December 9) to Saturday (December 11) and will focus on the maritime environment and how it is affected by climate change.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (ATSIS) representatives will be among the speakers at the symposium as well as representatives from Australia's Department of Defence, Maritime Safety and Emergency Management (MSEM) and the Federal Government's Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO).

MSEM chief executive Dr Michael O'Halloran said there was a lot of interest in the subject, which was good news for ATSIS.

prefix_text: Crofting is the mainstay of island life. Sheep form the backbone of the agricultural economy but a diversity livestock are kept, including cattle, pigs,
reference_text: goats, chickens, ducks and geese. Vegetable are grown too, often in the shelter of circular walls, such plots being known as'plantie scrubs '. Fishing is still conducted but on a relatively small scale. There is a post office at the pier, but no shop. Mains electricity only came to the island at the close of the twentieth century. The Papa Stour Project is a Christian supported housing service offering accommodation to men with drug and alcohol issues. Ferries now sail across the Sound of Papa to West Burrafirth on the Shetland Mainland. The crossing takes 45 minutes, and although the Snolda carries cars, there is only one short road on the island.For visiting yachts the four main voes provide good shelter, but the strong tides in both the Sound of Papa and to the north west require considerable care.

There are two ways to get around the island: by car or by boat. Both are excellent ways to see the island and get a feel for the people and their way of life. You can rent a car for a few days or take a day trip from Christchurch to the south-eastern tip of Tongariro, where you can walk along the coast and see the islands in all their splendor. Alternatively, you can fly to Dunedin and catch a ferry to Tauranga or Queenstown. The cost of airfares is around $100 one way, which is less than the cost of a car rental.

prefix_text: Hurricane Beatriz was a Category 1 hurricane that killed four people after brushing the western coast of Mexico in June 2011. Originating from an area of disturbed weather
reference_text: on June 19, several hundred miles south of Mexico, Beatriz gradually intensified. Gaining latitude, the system became increasingly organized and reached hurricane status on the evening of June 20. The following morning, Beatriz attained winds of 90 mph ( 150 km / h ) as it passed roughly 15 mi ( 20 km ) of Mexico. Due to its interaction with land, the hurricane abruptly weakened hours later. Early on June 22, Beatriz dissipated over open waters. Prior to Beatriz's arrival in Mexico, hurricane watches and warnings were issued for coastal areas. Hundreds of shelters opened across the states of Colima and Guerrero. Heavy rains from the storm triggered significant flooding along the Sabana River in Acapulco, killing four people. However, the overall effects of Beatriz were limited and the rains were largely beneficial in mitigating a severe drought.

Track and intensity [ edit ]

Hurricane Beatriz had a track that was similar to that of Hurricane Irene in 2011, but with a more northerly direction and slightly stronger winds (see image to the right). Its intensity was estimated to be a Category 1 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, which is based on wind speed and sustained wind, and has a rating of 1-5 (strong, moderate, moderate-strong, and weak) according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).[2]

In the United States, hurricane season runs from June 1 to November 30 each year, with the peak season occurring from late June to mid-July. During this time, there are about 1,000 hurricanes that form in the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico, of which about 200 are major hurricanes and the rest are tropical cyclones. In addition, there are a few major hurricanes that form in the eastern Pacific Ocean and are not included in the Atlantic-Gulf-Mexican hurricane season because of their short lifespans

prefix_text: On June 16, 2011, a trough situated off the southern coast of Guatemala showed signs of possible tropical cyclogenesis. Though located within an area favoring development,
reference_text: the system remained broad and disorganized as it moved slowly west @-@ northwestward. Gradually, convection consolidated around an area of low pressure. On June 18, a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert was issued for the system as it was expected to develop into a tropical depression within 24 hours. On the following day, the low further developed and was declared Tropical Depression Two @-@ E by the National Hurricane Center at 1500 UTC. Upon being declared, the depression was located about 335 mi ( 540 km ) south @-@ southeast of Lázaro Cárdenas, Mexico. However, after post @-@ analysis, the depression had actually developed nine hours earlier. Maintaining a west @-@ northwesterly track in response to a subtropical ridge to the north, the depression was forecast to move into a favorable environment, characterized by low wind shear and sea surface temperatures up to 86 ° F ( 30 ° C ). Three hours after classification, the depression strengthened Tropical Storm Beatriz, the second named storm of the season.

In this case, it's the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)'s Coral Reef Watch (CWR), which monitors the health of coral reefs around the world.

The CWR website provides a lot of information about the work NOAA does to keep reefs healthy, such as this map that shows the locations of more than 1,000 coral reefs, as well as their health status (green, good; red, poor). You can click on any coral reef to see how it's doing in relation to the rest of the world and what's going on at the time. NOAA also has a coral reef monitoring program in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, and they've been using satellite imagery to help monitor the health of corals there for a couple of years now.

prefix_text: Most music historians date the writing of " The Bourgeois Blues " to Lead Belly's June 1937 trip to Washington, DC, when he was invi
reference_text: the folklorist Alan Lomax to record for the Library of Congress's folk music collection. On the first night Lead Belly and his wife Martha spent in the city, they encountered racially discriminatory Jim Crow laws similar to those found in their native Louisiana : most hotels refused to rent rooms to African Americans and the few that would were either full or refused to serve him because he was with a white man ( Lomax ). Lomax, in some versions of the story described as an unnamed " white friend ", offered to let the couple stay for the night in his apartment near the Supreme Court Building. The next morning, Lead Belly awoke to Lomax arguing with his landlord about the presence of a black man, with the landlord threatening to call the police.

In the years that followed, Lead Belly continued to write about the blues, but his writing was less lyrical and more of a social commentary than it was in the 1930s. The song "I'm Gonna Make It" was written in 1940, and it's one of the few songs that has a title and a chorus in the same song.

This is an excerpt from the book The Bourgeois Blues: Blues for the Upper and Middle Classes (public library) by Robert Cogswell, a professor of music at Boston University and author of the forthcoming blues-obsessed memoir A Life in Black and White.

I'm Gonna Make It

It's hard to believe that a song so simple could have taken so long to write. The title is a play on the word "go," as in "I'm going to the ball game." And the chorus: "I'm gonna make it, I'm gonna make it, I'm gonna make it!" — that's what you hear over and over in the recording, as if someone is trying to sing it to you in a language you don't understand. prefix_text: " The Bourgeois Blues " is one of Lead Belly's most famous songs and is remembered as his most " heartfelt protest song ". There is
reference_text: disagreement among music scholars as to its importance. Robert Springer claims that the song is " peripheral " to the wider study of the blues, while Lawson points to it as a watershed in the way African Americans see themselves in the fabric of the United States. There is debate over the relationship between the song and radical politics. After its release, it became popular with left @-@ wing political groups. Lead Belly was invited to perform at Camp Unity, the Communist Party USA's summer retreat, and the FBI subsequently opened a file on him in the 1940s. This led to the accusations that the Communists were taking advantage of him and using him as a platform. The party claims, to the contrary, that they were some of the few people who respected him and gave him a chance to perform.

a lot of controversy surrounding the song, as it has been accused of glorifying drug use and the Black Panther Party (BPP), a group that was at the heart of the civil rights movement in the United States.

In an interview with Rolling Stone, lead singer Ronnie Van Zant stated that he was inspired to write the song after seeing a picture of Malcolm X in the New York Times, which was captioned "The Man Who Saved Rock and Roll". Van Zant felt that the caption was a misrepresentation of the man and his work, and decided to take a stand against this type of stereotyping by writing a song that spoke to the issues that Malcolm was trying to bring to the public's attention.

The song was released on October 1, 1965, the same day that Martin Luther King, Jr. was assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee. The song became a number one hit in the United States and the UK, selling over 2 million copies in the first week of its release. It went on to win the Grammy for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal, and was nominated for a Grammy for Best R&B Song as well.

prefix_text: Zachry Construction Corporation submitted the lowest bid and was awarded the $ 261 million contract by TxDOT, the largest ever by that agency. The constructi
reference_text: for the High Five Interchange was unique in that it contained elements not found in other construction project contracts. For example, it specified the concrete maturity method to be used to ensure the concrete's strength ( the first time TxDOT had ever done so ), and contained an early completion bonus, a sliding scale of up to $ 11 million if the company completed the contract within four years. Also built into the construction contract was a provision that Zachry was charged for " lane rentals " by TxDOT for time they closed down traffic lanes — fees based on hourly assessments and the time of day the lane was closed. The fees ranged from $ 50 to a high of $ 110 @,@ 000 for rush hours. In order not to interfere with traffic flow during construction, the new interchange was designed largely as elevated flyover ramps and viaducts so they could be built high over the existing junction lanes ; once traffic was transferred to the new structures the old lanes could simply be closed off and removed. Little of the original interchange remained when the project was finished.

prefix_text: The terrain in the Trout Creek Mountains varies from broad, flat basins and rolling ridges to high rock escarpments cut by deep canyons.
reference_text: The canyons have steep walls with loose talus slopes at the bottoms. There are meadows around springs in the mountains, although most streams in the range do not flow year @-@ round. Major streams that flow off the north slopes of the mountains include ( from west to east ) Cottonwood Creek, Trout Creek, Willow Creek, and Whitehorse Creek. These streams all flow into endorheic basins in Harney County, Oregon. Trout Creek and Whitehorse Creek are the largest of the four. The Kings River and McDermitt Creek each drain an area on the south slopes of the Trout Creek Mountains. The Kings River begins in The Granites and flows south into Nevada, where it meets the Quinn River, which evaporates in the Black Rock Desert. McDermitt Creek begins in Oregon a few miles north of The Granites and flows generally east, crossing the Oregon – Nevada border five times before disappearing into the floor of the Quinn River Valley south of McDermitt.

prefix_text: The Trout Creek Mountains are composed mostly of basalt from a shield volcano that once stood where Steens Mountain is today. Crustal thinning and th
reference_text: Yellowstone hotspot, which was then beneath southeastern Oregon, induced eruptions from Steens and nearby vents about 17 million years ago, in the Miocene. The vents produced a series of lava flows that spread across the land now known as the Trout Creek Mountains. Eruptions from the Steens volcano lasted for about one million years, and at least 70 separate lava flows occurred. Under the resulting basalt rock lie much older metamorphic rocks that may be related to some of the Triassic age formations of the Blue Mountains in northeastern Oregon. Within these metamorphic rocks are diorite and granodiorite intrusive bodies which were presumably intruded during the Cretaceous Period.

prefix_text: The broad McDermitt Caldera is a prominent geologic feature in the Trout Creek Mountains. The oval @-@ shaped caldera is a collaps
reference_text: lava dome that straddles the Oregon – Nevada border on the eastern side of the range and south of the Oregon Canyon Mountains. It is about 28 miles ( 45 km ) long and 22 miles ( 35 km ) wide. The lava dome was created by volcanic eruptions in the early Miocene. A total of five large ash flows were produced along with a large rhyolite dome structure. The caldera formed when the dome collapsed about 16 million years ago. The caldera contains significant ore deposits, and mercury and uranium have been mined at eight or more sites in and around the caldera. Other areas in the caldera were mined for ores of antimony, cesium, and lithium.

reference_text: Pacific Ocean moves eastward over the Oregon and California coastal ranges and the Cascade Range, most precipitation falls in those mountains before reaching the Trout Creek Mountains. Narrow riparian greenways follow the year @-@ round streams. Many greenway areas have quaking aspen and willow groves. Years of heavy livestock grazing in parts of the range resulted in the loss of some grass species, riparian vegetation, and young aspen and willow trees. Habitat and Range

The trout creek range is bounded by San Bernardino National Forest on the north, Los Padres National Forest on the east, Santa Catalina Island National Seashore on the south, and the Angeles National Forest (Beverly Hills National Recreation Area) on the west. In addition, there are a number of privately owned properties that border the range, as well as portions of the National Forests of California, Nevada, and Utah.

The Trout Creek Mountains have an average elevation of 2,500 feet above sea level and a dry season that lasts from May through October. This means that water is available year-round, except during the winter months when snowmelt can be a limiting factor. prefix_text: Several streams in the Trout Creek Mountains are home to trout, including the rare Lahontan cutthroat trout subspecies. These include Willow Creek, Whi
reference_text: Creek, Little Whitehorse Creek, Doolittle Creek, Fifteen Mile Creek, Indian Creek, Sage Canyon Creek, Line Canyon Creek, and some tributaries of McDermitt Creek. Lahontan cutthroat trout live in small, isolated populations that are often confined to individual streams, many of them in the Trout Creek Mountains. These populations have significant genetic differences due to their history of isolation. For most of the 20th century, the trout's numbers declined considerably. It was listed under federal law as an endangered species in 1970 and was reclassified as threatened in 1975. Reasons for the fish's decline included habitat degradation from cattle grazing, drought, overfishing, competition with other fish, and hybridization with introduced rainbow trout, which decreased the number of genetically pure Lahontan cutthroat trout. However, reductions in cattle grazing in riparian zones since the 1980s allowed fish habitat and populations to start to recover.

In a report to the Sierra Club, a group of scientists wrote that the trout population has declined by 90 percent over the past 20 years due to overharvesting by ranchers who want to increase their profit margins. They noted that there are no regulations in place to protect the fish, and that "it is difficult to determine the extent to which this decline is the result of habitat loss and other factors that have little to do with ranching and more to do with human management of the land."

According to the National Park Service, Lahontan cutthroat trout are listed as "threatened" under the Endangered Species Act, which is one of the reasons the Fish and Wildlife Service is working with the Bureau of Land Management to develop a management plan for the stream. If implemented, the plan would require landowners to limit grazing to no more than one cow per 100 acres, as well as provide habitat for other wildlife and plant species.

prefix_text: The Bureau of Land Management ( BLM ) administers most land in the Trout Creek Mountains, but there are also some private lands and some roads in the area
reference_text: . The private lands are mainly used for ranching along mountain streams, while the BLM lands include large grazing allotments for local ranchers'cattle. At least 100 mining claims in the mountains have been recorded since 1892, some of which were staked for gold exploration. Commercial mining has occurred in some areas, mostly near the McDermitt Caldera, where uranium and large amounts of mercury have been extracted. Mines in what was called the Opalite Mining District produced 270 @,@ 000 flasks of mercury — " the richest supply of mercury in the western hemisphere " — from cinnabar extracted from the caldera in the 20th century. The two leading mercury @-@ producing mines in North America were the Cordero and McDermitt mines on the edge of the caldera in Nevada. Together, they operated from 1933 to 1989. The McDermitt Mine, the last mercury mine in the United States, closed three years later, in 1992. However, mineral exploration has continued at the Cordero Mine in the 21st century, and waste containing mercury and arsenic was returned there from the community of McDermitt as part of a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency cleanup project.

Trailheads [ edit ]

For those who wish to hike to the top, a trailhead is located at the end of the parking lot. This is the most direct route, but it is not the easiest. You have to climb a steep incline to get to the trailhead. The elevation gain is 1,000 feet (305 m).[1]

Hiking in the summer can be hot and the sun can be hot as well. Bring plenty of water and sun protection (sunglasses are a good idea for this trail). If you have trouble keeping hydrated, try drinking a cup of ice-cold water every few minutes to avoid hypothermia.

This trail is well marked with white blazes, which are easy to follow. However, the trail has been known to be blocked by boulders and other obstructions on a regular basis. Be sure to check the weather before setting out, as it can change quickly. In the winter, snow can be a problem, especially in the early morning and late afternoons.

In the past, I've written about the need to be careful about what we put in the water, and how that impacts wildlife. But it's worth pointing out that this is a case in which conservationists are working in the opposite direction: trying to make it easier for cattle to graze on land that is, at best, ecologically unviable. That's bad for wildlife, and it's bad for the economy.

The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA), for its part, issued a statement last week in which it called the lawsuit "baseless and without merit." The NCABA's press release went on to say that "the lawsuit has nothing to do with conservation and everything to do with an overzealous government bureaucrat who wants to impose his will on a privately owned ranch in the middle of nowhere."

That may be true, but it's not the whole story. As it turns out, the ranch has been in the news for a long time, and not for the reasons one might expect. For one thing, it's the site of a long-running dispute between the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and its owner, Texas rancher Cliven Bundy.

Agaricomycetes include the most well known mushrooms in the world such as Amanita muscaria, Penis Envy, Stropharia cubensis, Panaeolus cinctulus, Agaricus bisporus, and many more.

B. bisporus is an excellent example of a spore forming mushroom. It grows on wood and can be found in a variety of habitats, but is most commonly found on dead or decayed wood. The cap is white to light brown in color and has a rough texture. There is no discernible gills, which is a characteristic of the genus Agaricus.

There is a blocked window in the south wall of the south chapel. The vault, which is about 27 square feet ( 2 @.@ 5 m2 ), is reached by stone steps from inside the south chapel. Limestone slabs form the roof of the vault and the floor of the chapel above. prefix_text: Route 29 is a state highway in the U.S. state of New Jersey. It runs 34 @.@ 76 mi ( 55 @.@ 94
reference_text: km ) from an interchange with Interstate 295 ( I @-@ 295 ) in Hamilton Township in Mercer County, where it continues as I @-@ 195, to Route 12 ( Bridge Street / Race Street ) in Frenchtown, Hunterdon County. Between the southern terminus and I @-@ 95, the route is a mix of freeway and four @-@ lane divided highway that runs along the Delaware River through Trenton. This section includes a truck @-@ restricted tunnel that was built along the river near historic houses and Riverview Cemetery. North of I @-@ 95, Route 29 turns into a scenic and mostly two @-@ lane highway. North of the South Trenton Tunnel, it is designated the Delaware River Scenic Byway, a New Jersey Scenic Byway and National Scenic Byway, that follows the Delaware River in mostly rural sections of Mercer County and Hunterdon County. The obsolete Delaware & Raritan Canal usually stands between the river and the highway. Most sections of this portion of Route 29 are completely shaded due to the tree canopy. Route 29 also has a spur, Route 129, which connects Route 29 to U.S. Route 1 ( US 1 ) in Trenton.

History [ edit ]

[1] In 1883, construction began on the first segment of the road, which was known as the Atlantic City Expressway. The road opened to vehicular traffic on April 1, 1884, and by the mid-1930s, traffic had increased to the point that it was congested and in need of improvement. A plan to widen the road was put into motion in the early 1930s, but funding was short-lived due to the Great Depression, which hit the United States in the 1930s and was the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression of the 1930s. As a result, the state of New Jersey did not have the funds to continue the project, and it was shut down in 1937.

After the road was closed, several attempts were made to re-open it

reference_text: Somerville and US 22 between Somerville and Newark. The route between Lambertville and Frenchtown was originally Route 29A. In 1953, Route 29 was shifted to follow the alignment of Route 29A to avoid the concurrencies with the U.S. Routes. Route 29 between South Warren Street in Trenton and I @-@ 95 in Ewing Township was upgraded to a four @-@ lane highway, with a portion of freeway, in the 1950s and 1960s. In 1995, the southern freeway part of Route 29 between I @-@ 195 / I @-@ 295 and Route 129 in Hamilton Township was completed. This freeway section was linked to the rest of Route 29 by a tunnel completed in 2002. A realignment of Route 29 in Lambertville by the 2000s made the route concurrent with the entire length of 0 @.@ 26 @-@ mile @-@ long ( 0 @.@ 42 km ) Route 165.

Introduction [ edit ]

The New Jersey Turnpike was built to facilitate the movement of freight from Philadelphia to Trenton, New Jersey. In addition to its role as a transshipment route, the Turnpike served as an important link in the nation's rail network, connecting the East Coast of the United States with the West Coast of the United States.[1] As early as the 1830s, the state of New Jersey began to plan a road that would connect Trenton to Atlantic City, and to New York City. This plan was known as the "Trenton-Jersey Railroad" (later shortened to the "NJ Turnpike"), and its construction began in 1833 with the construction of what is now the turnpike's eastern terminus at Newark, New Jersey.[2] It

The route bends to the north and continues along the Delaware River for several miles, crossing into Frenchtown, where the route becomes Trenton Road. Upon entering Frenchtown, an end shield for northbound Route 29 is posted to mark the end of state maintenance, which officially ends at the Washington Street intersection, where maintenance is transferred to the county. Despite this, Route 29 officially continues farther north along Trenton Road to its northern terminus at Route 12 ( Bridge Street / Race Street ), a short distance east of Route 12 ’ s western terminus at the Uhlerstown @-@ Frenchtown Bridge. The southern terminus of County Route 513 is located a block north of the northern terminus of Route 29 along Route 12.

Kingwood Township is home to several businesses, including a gas station, convenience store, bank, post office, school bus service and an auto repair shop. There are also several homes for sale in the area that range in price from $200,000 to $1 million, according to real estate listings.

A Google search for "Riverside Road" brings up more than 4,000 results, including news stories from The Detroit News, USA Today's Detroit Free Press and the Associated Press.

The Riverside Road sign was put up on the side of the road last week, but it's unclear when it was installed.

This project was funded by bonds issued by the City and Boston Water and Light Company (B&L), a privately owned utility that was granted a monopoly on the sale of water in Boston. The Central Artery was completed in 1901-1902, at a cost of $1.5 million (roughly $6 million in today's dollars).

The invasions toppled the 250 @-@ year @-@ old Pagan Empire, and the Mongol army seized Pagan territories in present @-@ day Dehong, Yunnan and northern Burma to Tagaung. The invasions ushered in 250 years of political fragmentation in Burma and the rise of Tai @-@ Shan states throughout mainland Southeast Asia.

prefix_text: The Mongols first demanded tribute from Pagan in 1271 – 72, as part of their drive to encircle the Song dynasty of China. When King
reference_text: Narathihapate refused, Emperor Kublai Khan himself sent another mission in 1273, again demanding tribute. It too was rejected. In 1275, the emperor ordered the Yunnan government to secure the borderlands in order to block an escape path for the Song, and permitted a limited border war if Pagan contested. Pagan did contest but its army was driven back at the frontier by the Mongol Army in 1277 – 78. After a brief lull, Kublai Khan in 1281 turned his attention to Southeast Asia, demanding tribute from Pagan, the Khmer Empire, Đại Việt and Champa. When the Burmese king again refused, the emperor ordered an invasion of northern Burma. Two dry season campaigns ( 1283 – 85 ) later, the Mongols had occupied down to Tagaung and Hanlin, forcing the Burmese king to flee to Lower Burma. The Mongols organized northern Burma as the province of Zhengmian.

Pagan was the first ruler of the Mongol Khans, a nomadic confederation of warlike horse archers, who ruled much of what is now Mongolia, China, Central Asia as well as parts of Russia, Ukraine and the Middle East.

After his death, his son Kublai Khan took the throne, and in 1279 he began an expansionist campaign against the Yuan dynasty in China. Kublai's campaigns were successful, and by the mid-13th century China was in the throes of a civil war known as the Taiping Rebellion. This resulted in the deaths of more than 20 million people, most of them Chinese, and led to the establishment of the Manchu dynasty in 1644.

Kublai died in 1294, and his son Tamerlane (r. 1326-1368) became the most powerful man in the world. Tamerlane had no qualms about using torture and other barbarous methods to achieve his goals, and the legacy of his reign is one of the bloodiest in history.

But the treaty never really took effect as Narathihapate was assassinated in July 1287, and no authority who could honor the treaty emerged. The Mongol command at Yunnan now deemed the imperial order to withdraw void, and ordered an invasion of central Burma. After the fall of the Yuan dynasty, the Mongols established a new capital at Samarkand, which became the center of the Khwarezmian Empire (Khorasan in Mongolian, meaning "land of the horse" or "mountain people"). What's the deal with the name "Pagan" anyway?

The word "pan" is a root meaning "all," and in this case it refers to all things that existed before the creation of the universe. This is in contrast to the word "primal," which means "first" or "originate from the primordial waters." So when we say "pagan," we're talking about a belief system that predates the world we live in by a long, long time.

So why do we call ourselves Pagan at all?

[ citation needed ] On the night of 12 August 1282, a Mongol army of more than 100,000 marched into Champa and laid siege to the city. In the early morning of 13 August, the Mongols broke through the city walls and began their siege, using fire and battering rams to batter down the walls and walls of the citadel. By the end of the siege, all that remained of the city was a walled-in area of the citadel, surrounded by mud huts and bamboo palisades. After several days of fighting, the siege was broken and the city fell into Mongol hands.

The fall of Champa was a major blow to the Khwarezmian Empire, which at the time was the largest empire in the world. It was the first time that a Muslim power had been defeated by a non-Muslim power since the fall of Byzantium in 1453. This marked the beginning of the end of the Golden Horde and the rise of the Turkic-Turkic state known as the Uighur Empire

The Burmese chronicles report an overwhelming number of Mongol forces laying siege to the fort although their numbers are greatly exaggerated. prefix_text: The immediate result of the war was the collapse of the Pagan Empire. However, the war merely accelerated the collapse but did not cause it. Pagan's
reference_text: disintegration was " in fact more prolonged and agonized. " The kingdom had been in long gradual decline since the early 13th century. Had Pagan possessed a stronger central government, the collapse could have been temporary, and the country “ could have risen again ”. But the dynasty could not recover, and because the Mongols refused to fill the power vacuum, no viable center emerged in the immediate aftermath. Paganism in the Middle Ages

After the collapse of the Pagan Empire, a new religion began to take root in Europe. This new religion was known as Christianity. The Christian Church had its origins in the Church of Mithras, a religion that had been worshiped in Mesopotamia for thousands of years. Mithras was one of the most important gods in the ancient world and his cult spread all over the world. In many parts of the world, he was the equivalent of the Buddha of the Buddhists, or the God of the Druids and Celts.

Mithradates, the first Christian Emperor of Pontus, established the first Christian Church in the 4th century and by the time of Constantine (A.D. 313-337), there were over 1,000 churches in the Roman Empire. Constantine's son Theodosius (A.D. 395-407) was the first to convert to Christianity and in 449, he became the first Pope. The Roman Empire was divided into Eastern and Western Empires, each ruled by a Pope. The Western Empire became the Holy Roman Empire and the Eastern Empire became the Byzantine Empire

Their rise was encouraged by the Mongols, who viewed the states as a useful buffer between Yunnan and the rest of Southeast Asia. The Mongols, who were still trying to incorporate Yunnan into the central administration, were unwilling or unable to make necessary sustained investments to bring the vast regions south of Yunnan into the fold. ( The integration of Yunnan itself into “ China Proper ” was to take several more centuries, and continues to today. ) As such, from the newly formed Tai @-@ Shan states in western and central Southeast Asia to Dai Viet and Champa in eastern Southeast Asia, the Mongols elected to receive nominal tribute. A few years after the fall of Tien Shan, the Mongol leader Genghis Khan began to move south to take control of the area that would become modern-day Xinjiang, the home of the Uyghur people. Genghis Khan's goal was to establish a "Greater China" that would extend from the Yellow River to the Himalayas. The Silk Road was the lifeblood of the Mongol Empire, and without it, it is hard to imagine the empire surviving as it did.

A total of 1,500 Japanese were killed, according to U.S. estimates based on aerial photographs of the battle. Of those, more than 1,000 were American soldiers and civilians.

In his memoirs, Watanabe recalled the battle as a "bloody massacre," in which he was the only survivor of his company.

Watanabe's story was told in a movie, "Ikiru," which won an Academy Award in 1997 for best foreign-language film. The Japanese government did not allow Watanabe to attend the ceremony, but he was given a posthumous award for valor by President Bill Clinton in 1998.

The Battle of Okinawa was one of the fiercest battles of World War II, and it remains a sore point in Japan-U.S. relations. Japan's pacifist constitution forbids the country from fighting overseas unless it is under attack.

The United States is Japan's most important ally in the Asia-Pacific region, with a military presence in more than 70 countries and territories. About half of the country's defense budget is spent on the military, which accounts for one-third of the country's gross domestic product (GDP).

This attack was successful, and the Marines took control of the ridge and a large area in the center of the island.

Kawaguchi's troops began the march on the morning of 16 September. Almost every soldier able to walk had to help carry the wounded. As the march progressed, the exhausted and hungry soldiers, who had eaten their last rations on the morning before their withdrawal, began to discard their heavy equipment and then their rifles. By the time most of them reached Oka's positions at Kokumbona five days later, only half still carried their weapons. The Kuma battalion's survivors, attempting to follow Kawaguchi's Center Body forces, became lost, wandered for three weeks in the jungle, and almost starved to death before finally reaching Kawaguchi's camp.

As the battle raged, British officers and NCOs were killed and mutilated by machine gun fire, and many of the wounded were left to die in the jungle for days at a time. One soldier, Corporal George Brown, described the scene to his commanding officer: "There was nothing to eat, no water, the jungle was full of lice and mosquitoes, and I was in no condition to fight. It was a hell of a lot worse than the front line."

By mid-1942, Japanese resistance had become a stalemate, with no sign of a breakthrough. In the early morning of April 1, a group of Japanese soldiers attempted to break through the Lunga defenses, but were repelled by an American counterattack. The Japanese had lost the will to fight and were forced to withdraw to the island of Iwo Jima.

Aftermath [ edit ]

[ citation needed ] The battle was one of the bloodiest in the Pacific War, and resulted in the deaths of more than 2,000 Japanese soldiers and an unknown number of American servicemen. It is estimated that as many as 100,000 Okinawans were killed in the battle, as well as the civilian population of Naha, the capital of Okinawa Prefecture. In addition, a number of Japanese aircraft were shot down and many of their pilots lost their lives.The battle was one of the bloodiest in the Pacific War, and resulted in the deaths of more than 2,000 Japanese soldiers and an unknown number of American servicemen.

prefix_text: On 15 September, General Hyakutake at Rabaul learned of Kawaguchi's defeat, the Imperial Japanese Army's first defeat involving a
reference_text: unit of this size in the war. The general forwarded the news to the Imperial General Headquarters in Japan. In an emergency session, the top Japanese army and navy command staffs concluded that, " Guadalcanal might develop into the decisive battle of the war. " The results of the battle began to have a telling strategic impact on Japanese operations in other areas of the Pacific. Hyakutake realized that, in order to send sufficient troops and materiel to defeat the Allied forces on Guadalcanal, he could no longer support the major Japanese offensive on the Kokoda Track in New Guinea. Hyakutake — with the concurrence of the General Headquarters — ordered his troops on New Guinea, who were within 30 mi ( 48 km ) of their objective of Port Moresby — to withdraw until the Guadalcanal matter was resolved. The Japanese were never able to restart their drive towards Port Moresby ; the defeat at Edson's Ridge contributed not only to Japan's defeat in the Guadalcanal campaign, but also to Japan's ultimate defeat throughout the South Pacific.

In addition to his command of the Kwantung Army, Kawaguchi was commander of the 1st Marine Division, which fought at Iwo Jima in World War II.

On the morning of 15 September, Kawaguchi's forces began an amphibious assault on Rabaul, a Japanese-administered island in the Solomons that was home to the U.S. Seventh Fleet. The assault was intended to break the siege of New Britain, an airfield and naval base on the island, and allow the Japanese to move troops and materiel to other islands in the South Pacific.

As the Japanese launched their assault, American planes dropped napalm and white phosphorous on the beach, causing a fire that burned for days. By the time the fire was extinguished, more than 2,000 Americans were dead—the largest number of American casualties in a single day since the Battle of Midway in 1942.

In this post, I want to focus on the battle for the diamond fields of Southern Rhodesia, and what that battle tells us about the future of the world's largest exporter of rough diamonds.

Rhodesia's diamonds are the world's largest, and they have a lot to do with the country's wealth. According to World Diamond Council data, the country is the world's top importer of rough diamonds, accounting for more than 40% of the world's rough diamonds (see Figure 1). This is in stark contrast to South Africa, which has the second largest diamond production in the world, and the United States, which ranks third. In fact, the two countries are so close in production that it is hard to tell them apart from a distance of several thousand miles in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.

reference_text: in a rainforest in Guatemala. Ambrosio Tut, a gum @-@ sapper, reported the ruins to La Gaceta, a Guatemalan newspaper, which named the site Tikal. After the Berlin Academy of Sciences'magazine republished the report in 1853, archeologists and treasure hunters began visiting the forest. Today tourism to the site may help protect the rainforest. It is one of the largest archaeological sites and urban centers of the pre @-@ Columbian Maya civilization. History Edit

Pre-Columbian Era Edit

Tikal was the capital of the city-state of Tikal, located in the Yucatan Peninsula, and a major trading center for the Maya, Olmecs, Aztecs, Incahuasi, Toltecs, Zapotecs, Huastecs, Mixtecs, and other Mesoamerican peoples. The city had a population of more than one million at its peak.[1]

During the Classic period, Tikal was one of the most important cities in the Maya Lowlands, and its importance was such that it was known as the "City of Kings" by the Maya, who referred to it as "El Castillo de San Cristóbal" (the Castillo of the Kings). It was ruled by a king named Tezcatlipoca, who reigned from A.D. 250 to 1021.[2]

prefix_text: Tikal was the capital of a conquest state that became one of the most powerful kingdoms of the ancient Maya. Though monumental architecture at the site dates back as
reference_text: far as the 4th century BC, Tikal reached its apogee during the Classic Period, c. 200 to 900 AD. During this time, the city dominated much of the Maya region politically, economically, and militarily, while interacting with areas throughout Mesoamerica such as the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the distant Valley of Mexico. There is evidence that Tikal was conquered by Teotihuacan in the 4th century AD. Following the end of the Late Classic Period, no new major monuments were built at Tikal and there is evidence that elite palaces were burned. These events were coupled with a gradual population decline, culminating with the site ’ s abandonment by the end of the 10th century.

The city was founded by the Olmecs, a pre-Aztec civilization that ruled the region from the 15th to the 16th centuries, and it was ruled by Maya dynasties for the next 300 years. In the mid-13th century, the Spanish conquistadors began to expand their empire, and by the time Cortéz arrived in Tenochtitlán in 1519, the city had been reduced to little more than a garrison town.

Coe's team has been excavating at Tikal since the 1990s, and they are continuing to find evidence of the city's grandeur. prefix_text: The name Tikal may be derived from ti ak 'al in the Yucatec Maya language ; it is said to be a relatively modern name meaning
reference_text: " at the waterhole ". The name was apparently applied to one of the site's ancient reservoirs by hunters and travelers in the region. It has alternatively been interpreted as meaning " the place of the voices " in the Itza Maya language. Tikal, however, is not the ancient name for the site but rather the name adopted shortly after its discovery in the 1840s. Hieroglyphic inscriptions at the ruins refer to the ancient city as Yax Mutal or Yax Mutul, meaning " First Mutal ". Tikal may have come to have been called this because Dos Pilas also came to use the same emblem glyph ; the rulers of the city presumably wanted to distinguish themselves as the first city to bear the name. The kingdom as a whole was simply called Mutul, which is the reading of the " hair bundle " emblem glyph seen in the accompanying photo. Its precise meaning remains obscure.

Tikal has been the capital of the Toltec Empire since at least the 15th century, but its history is shrouded in mystery. It was conquered by Corte-Real in 1521, who renamed it Tenochtitlan, the City of the Sun. The Aztecs took over after Corte-Real's death in 1521, renaming it Teotihuacan. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the name was used as a city name in the pre-Columbian period.

A statue of the sun god Quetzalcoatl (right) is one of the most recognisable symbols of Mesoamerica. Credit: Alamy Stock Photo/Shutterstock

The Maya, on the other hand, were well known for their use of astronomical symbols, such as the Mayan zodiac, which was based on constellations. These symbols became associated with the city-state of Tikal, and are still used to this day by the Maya in their writing system.

In addition to the Maya, other cultures have claimed to have built the pyramids of El Castillo, including the Olmecs, the Incas and the Zapotecs.

The first evidence of human habitation in the region was found by archaeologist John McPhee in 1891 and described as "an old village of a few huts" on the slopes of Mount Arapeshu, which he believed was inhabited by the "solitary and nomadic people of the Malagarazi" (McPhee, 1891). This was based on the fact that there were no signs of settlement in the surrounding area, and it was thought that the Malagarazi were a pastoral people living in the highlands of the Central Plateau. However, archaeological excavations carried out over the next two decades revealed a much more complex settlement, with houses, pottery sherds, animal bones and stone artefacts, which led McPhee to revise his opinion, and in the 1920s he published a book on the site, The Ruins of Tikal (McPhee, 1925).

On the same day, Siyah K ’ ak ’ ( Fire Is Born ) arrived from the west, having passed through El Peru, a site to the west of Tikal, on 8 January. On Stela 31 he is named as " Lord of the West ". Siyah K ’ ak ’ was probably a foreign general serving a figure represented by a non @-@ Maya hieroglyph of a spearthrower combined with an owl, a glyph that is well known from the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the distant Valley of Mexico. Spearthrower Owl may even have been the ruler of Teotihuacan. These recorded events strongly suggest that Siyah K ’ ak ’ led a Teotihuacan invasion that defeated the native Tikal king, who was captured and immediately executed. Siyah K 'ak'appears to have been aided by a powerful political faction at Tikal itself ; roughly at the time of the conquest, a group of Teotihuacan natives were apparently residing near the Lost World complex. He also exerted control over other cities in the area, including Uaxactun, where he became king, but did not take the throne of Tikal for himself. Within a year, the son of Spearthrower Owl by the name of Yax Nuun Ayiin I ( First Crocodile ) had been installed as the tenth king of Tikal while he was still a boy, being enthroned on 13 September 379. He reigned for 47 years as king of Tikal, and remained a vassal of Siyah K 'ak'for as long as the latter lived. It seems likely that Yax Nuun Ayiin I took a wife from the preexisting, defeated, Tikal dynasty and thus legitimized the right to rule of his son, Siyaj Chan K 'awiil II.

Tikal had two capitals, one in the north and one in the south. The city of Tikal was located in the northern part of the city, and the capital was in the south. prefix_text: In the mid 6th century, Caracol seems to have allied with Calakmul and defeated Tikal, closing the Early Classic. The "
reference_text: Tikal hiatus " refers to a period between the late 6th to late 7th century where there was a lapse in the writing of inscriptions and large @-@ scale construction at Tikal. In the latter half of the 6th century AD, a serious crisis befell the city, with no new stelae being erected and with widespread deliberate mutilation of public sculpture. This hiatus in activity at Tikal was long unexplained until later epigraphic decipherments identified that the period was prompted by Tikal's comprehensive defeat at the hands of Calakmul and the Caracol polity in AD 562, a defeat that seems to have resulted in the capture and sacrifice of the king of Tikal. The badly eroded Altar 21 at Caracol described how Tikal suffered this disastrous defeat in a major war in April 562. It seems that Caracol was an ally of Calakmul in the wider conflict between that city and Tikal, with the defeat of Tikal having a lasting impact upon the city. Tikal was not sacked but its power and influence were broken. After its great victory, Caracol grew rapidly and some of Tikal's population may have been forcibly relocated there. During the hiatus period, at least one ruler of Tikal took refuge with Janaab'Pakal of Palenque, another of Calakmul's victims. Calakmul itself thrived during Tikal's long hiatus period.

During the Middle Ages, the cathedral was converted into a prison for prisoners of the crusader king Charles Martel (1189-1204), who was trying to recapture the Holy Land from the Seljuk Turks. In 1204, the cathedral was burned to the ground by the Muslims, who took the treasures as spoils of war.

After the fall of Granada in 1492, the cathedral was used as a military base by the Spanish and Portuguese in the New World. In the early 20th century, it was the site of the American Museum of Natural History in New York and the Museo Nacional de Antropología in Buenos Aires.

Tikal was conquered by the Mongols in 1260 and became part of the Khwarezmian Empire (Mongol Empire, 1260-1368). After the fall of the Khwarezmian Empire, the capital moved to Bukhara, then known as Samarkand. It was here that the Mongol Empire began its expansion into Central Asia, which would culminate in the conquest of the Middle East and North Africa in the 13th century.

Under the Yuan Dynasty (1368-1644), Tikal fell into disrepute and was abandoned, but its ruins were rediscovered in the 18th century by French archaeologist Jean-Baptiste Mouginot. He excavated the city and wrote a book about his findings, La ville d'Oc toc (The City of Oc toc) in 1810. The book was translated into English and published in 1811 under the title Travels in the East and South-East Asia, Volume 1 and Volume 2.

reference_text: Increasingly endemic warfare in the Maya region caused Tikal's supporting population to heavily concentrate close to the city itself, accelerating the use of intensive agriculture and corresponding environmental decline. Construction continued at the beginning of the century, with the erection of Temple 3, the last of the city's major pyramids and the erection of monuments to mark the 19th K 'atun in 810. The beginning of the 10th Bak 'tun in 830 passed uncelebrated, and marks the beginning of a 60 @-@ year hiatus, probably resulting from the collapse of central control in the city. During this hiatus, satellite sites traditionally under Tikal's control began to erect their own monuments featuring local rulers and using the Mutal emblem glyph, with Tikal apparently lacking the authority or the power to crush these bids for independence. In 849, Jewel K 'awiil is mentioned on a stela at Seibal as visiting that city as the Divine Lord of Tikal but he is not recorded elsewhere and Tikal's once great power was little more than a memory. The sites of Ixlu and Jimbal had by now inherited the once exclusive Mutal emblem glyph.

In the years that followed, scholars theorized that climate change played a role in the collapse, but no one knew for sure. Now, new research suggests that a combination of drought and the rise of the Mayan pyramids may have been the final straw.

The researchers, led by archaeologist Michael Coe of the University of California, Santa Cruz, looked at data from tree rings to see how rainfall changed over the past 10,000 years. By comparing the growth rings of trees that grew in the same area, they were able to reconstruct climate conditions at the time of the collapse. The former satellites of Tikal, such as Jimbal and Uaxactun, did not last much longer, erecting their final monuments in 889. By the end of the 9th century the vast majority of Tikal's population had deserted the city, its royal palaces were occupied by squatters and simple thatched dwellings were being erected in the city's ceremonial plazas. The squatters blocked some doorways in the rooms they reoccupied in the monumental structures of the site and left rubbish that included a mixture of domestic refuse and non @-@ utilitarian items such as musical instruments. These inhabitants reused the earlier monuments for their own ritual activities far removed from those of the royal dynasty that had erected them. Some monuments were vandalized and some were moved to new locations. Before its final abandonment all respect for the old rulers had disappeared, with the tombs of the North Acropolis being explored for jade and the easier to find tombs being looted. After 950, Tikal was all but deserted, although a remnant population may have survived in perishable huts interspersed among the ruins. Even these final inhabitants abandoned the city in the 10th or 11th centuries and the rainforest claimed the ruins for the next thousand years. Some of Tikal's population may have migrated to the Peten Lakes region, which remained heavily populated in spite of a plunge in population levels in the first half of the 9th century.

The archaeological site is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the most important archeological sites in the world.

Tikal, located in the north-eastern part of Guatemala, dates back to the Pre-Columbian period (A.D. 500-1450) and was the capital of the Olmec civilization.

In 2010, archaeologists discovered the remains of a pyramid at Tikal, which they believe was built by the Mayan civilization.

The discovery was made during a project to build a highway that would connect Guatemala City to the city of Antigua.

Archaeologists are hoping to use the site as a test case for the construction of a high-speed rail line, which is set to begin construction in the next few years. (Reporting by Alexandra Ulmer; Editing by Ros Russell)

prefix_text: The North Acropolis, together with the Great Plaza immediately to the south, is one of the most studied architectural groups in the Maya area ; the Tikal
reference_text: Project excavated a massive trench across the complex, thoroughly investigating its construction history. It is a complex group with construction beginning in the Preclassic Period, around 350 BC. It developed into a funerary complex for the ruling dynasty of the Classic Period, with each additional royal burial adding new temples on top of the older structures. After AD 400 a row of tall pyramids was added to the earlier Northern Platform, which measured 100 by 80 metres ( 330 by 260 ft ), gradually hiding it from view. Eight temple pyramids were built in the 6th century AD, each of them had an elaborate roofcomb and a stairway flanked by masks of the gods. By the 9th century AD, 43 stelae and 30 altars had been erected in the North Acropolis ; 18 of these monuments were carved with hieroglyphic texts and royal portraits. The North Acropolis continued to receive burials into the Postclassic Period.

Tetuacatl (left) and his wife Tiwanaku (right) were the rulers of the Toltec Empire, which stretched from the Gulf of Mexico to present-day Veracruz, Mexico. Their capital was Tenochtitlan, located on the site of what is now the National Palace of Mexico City.

A group of Maya artisans working on pottery, ceramics, and textiles, circa 600-500 B.C. This image is one of the earliest depictions of the Maya calendar, known as the Long Count calendar. The Maya believed that the world was divided into 12,000 years, which they referred to as yanabá, or "twelve days." Each day was named for a god or goddess, and the number of days in a year was based on the number of days in the year. For example, the year would run from January 1 to December 31, with a leap year every 4 years. In order to keep track of time, the Maya used a system of counting that is still used today. prefix_text: The Mundo Perdido is to the west of the Plaza of the Seven Temples. It is the largest ceremonial complex dating from the Preclassic peri
reference_text: Tikal. The complex was organized as a large E @-@ Group consisting of a pyramid aligned with a platform to the east that supported three temples. The Mundo Perdido complex was rebuilt many times over the course of its history. By AD 250 – 300 its architectural style was influenced by the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the Valley of Mexico, including the use of the talud @-@ tablero form. During the Early Classic period ( c. 250 – 600 ) the Mundo Perdido became one of the twin foci of the city, the other being the North Acropolis. From AD 250 to 378 it may have served as the royal necropolis. The Mundo Perdido complex was given its name by the archaeologists of the University of Pennsylvania ; it is centered upon the Lost World Pyramid and a small platform to the west of it.

reference_text: vary in size but consist of two pyramids facing each other on an east – west axis. These pyramids are flat @-@ topped and have stairways on all four sides. A row of plain stelae is placed immediately to the west of the eastern pyramid and to the north of the pyramids, and lying roughly equidistant from them, there is usually a sculpted stela and altar pair. On the south side of these complexes there is a long vaulted building containing a single room with nine doorways. The entire complex was built at once and these complexes were built at 20 @-@ year ( or k 'atun ) intervals during the Late Classic. The first twin pyramid complex was built in the early 6th century in the East Plaza. It was once thought that these complexes were unique to Tikal but rare examples have now been found at other sites, such as Yaxha and Ixlu, and they may reflect the extent of Tikal's political dominance in the Late Classic.

Pylons and Tunnels

Tikal has at least nine pylons and one or more tunnels leading to the pyramid complexes. The largest and most well-known of these is the Pyramid of the Sun, a pyramid of the highest degree of complexity and one of the largest pyramids in the world. It is the only pyramid of its kind to have been excavated by modern archaeology, and its discovery was a major turning point in the history of Mesoamerica.

The Pyramid of the Sun was built by the Olmecs, who ruled the Valley of Mexico from A.D. 300 to 900. In the pyramid's center is a stone sarcophagus with the head of a human, which is believed to be that of the pharaoh Teotihuacan, who died in 1021 A.D. The sarcophagus was found in 1885 by a team led by Charles Hapgood, who called it the "Ceramic Tomb of the Sphinx." H

reference_text: 'awil, who was entombed in the structure in AD 734, the pyramid was completed around 740 – 750. The temple rises 47 metres ( 154 ft ) high. The massive roofcomb that topped the temple was originally decorated with a giant sculpture of the enthroned king, although little of this decoration survives. The tomb of the king was discovered by Aubrey Trik of the University of Pennsylvania in 1962. Among items recovered from the Late Classic tomb were a large collection of inscribed human and animal bone tubes and strips with sophisticated scenes depicting deities and people, finely carved and rubbed with vermilion, as well as jade and shell ornaments and ceramic vessels filled with offerings of food and drink. The shrine at the summit of the pyramid has three chambers, each behind the next, with the doorways spanned by wooden lintels fashioned from multiple beams. The outermost lintel is plain but the two inner lintels were carved, some of the beams were removed in the 19th century and their location is unknown, while others were taken to museums in Europe.
