Archaeologists have found evidence that the temple was used as a place of worship from the third century BC, but it is unclear when it was built. The most likely date is between 100 BC and 200 AD, when the Chinese began to develop a cult of the sun god and worshiped him in temples and shrines all over the country. This may have been the origin of the name "Temple of the Great Jaguar" which was given to the temple by the Chinese during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644).

reference_text: Acropolis. It started life in the Early Classic as a wide basal platform decorated with large stucco masks that flanked the stairway. Later in the Early Classic a new superstructure was added, with its own masks and decorated panels. During the Hiatus a third stage was built over the earlier constructions, the stairway was demolished and another royal burial, of an unidentified ruler, was set into the structure ( Burial 23 ). While the new pyramid was being built another high ranking tomb ( Burial 24 ) was inserted into the rubble core of the building. The pyramid was then completed, standing 33 metres ( 108 ft ) tall. The final version of Temple 33 was completely dismantled by archaeologists in 1965 in order to arrive at the earlier stages of construction.

It was the largest and most important of the funerary pyramids in the Saqqara necropolis, and its construction is thought to have been a result of the need to provide a burial place for the pharaoh's wife Nefertiti, who was entombed in the pyramid.

A total of eight mummies were found in the pyramid, including one woman and four men. All of the mummies were in good condition, with no signs of trauma to their bodies. However, there were a number of problems with the construction of the pyramid, including the fact that the roof was made of mud, which made it difficult to build and maintain. This led to the pyramid being abandoned for several years, and it was not re-erected until the 19th century.

The Temple 33 pyramid has been excavated by Egypt's Antiquities Ministry, and is one of the best-preserved examples of the pyramid-temple complex that was built during the New Kingdom (1550-1069 BC). reference_text: built into the end of the East Plaza Ballcourt and possessed four entry doorways and three stairways, the fourth ( south ) side was too close to the Central Acropolis for a stairway on that side. The building has a talud @-@ tablero platform profile, modified from the original style found at Teotihuacan. In fact, it has been suggested that the style of the building has closer affinities with El Tajin and Xochicalco than with Teotihuacan itself. The vertical tablero panels are set between sloping talud panels and are decorated with paired disc symbols. Large flower symbols are set into the sloping talud panels, related to the Venus and star symbols used at Teotihuacan. The roof of the structure was decorated with friezes although only fragments now remain, showing a monstrous face, perhaps that of a jaguar, with another head emerging from the mouth. The second head possesses a bifurcated tongue but is probably not that of a snake. The temple, and its associated ballcourt, probably date to the reign of Nuun Ujol Chaak or that of his son Jasaw Chan K 'awiil I, in the later part of the 7th century.

Most of the figurines are stylized, and some have been interpreted as representations of the sun god Quetzalcoatl, a Mesoamerican deity who was worshiped by the Aztecs and Mayas. Osorio-Arellano is a well-known archaeologist in Guatemala, and his team has made a name for itself as one of the most thorough and well-researched teams of its kind in the world.

In addition to the skiing, hiking, backpacking, horseback riding, cross country skijoring, rockclimbing, snowshoeing, mountain berry picking, and other outdoor activities, you can take a tour of the area by horseback or on foot. The area is rich in geologic history, with fossils dating back millions of years. The mountains were formed by glacial meltwater flowing into the North Fork of the Black River, which is the source of the Silverton Reservoir. This water was channeled to the mountain ranges and then deposited as sandstone and quartzite boulders. These rocks are known as rhyolite, a type of igneous rock that has been altered by heat and pressure over geologic time. The rock forms the base of the mountains, and as you hike, you

For example, the base of Elbert on the eastern side exhibits large igneous and metamorphic rocks deposited when the glaciers receded, which lie on a lateral moraine. Further up the eastern side there is a large cirque with a small tarn. There are also lakes to both the north and south, Turquoise and Twin Lakes respectively ; the Twin Lakes are a result of the natural dam of end moraines, and Turquoise Lake was created by the manmade Sugar Loaf Dam.

Hiking [ edit ]

The park is open year-round to hikers, snowshoers, cross-country skiers, and equestrians. A permit is required to hike in the park, and fees are $5 per car (cash only) or $10 per group of 10 or more. Permits are available at the Visitor Center, or by calling 909-865-7000 and asking for the park office. The office is open 8:00 am to 4:00 pm, Monday through Friday.

Camping [ edit ]

There are no campsites in the park, but you can pitch a tent in the parking lot or along the trail. The area is a popular spot for rock climbers during the summer and early fall, and it is possible to get a permit for this use. Camping is prohibited in the backcountry

It is also the most popular route, with people camping in the backcountry for the night before the summit. This will take you about a mile and a half, and is the most direct route to the summit. If you have time, you can take a side trip to Mount Shasta, which is the highest peak in the Sierras at 2,095 feet above sea level.

The trail begins to climb in earnest at mile 4.5, and by mile 6 the views are spectacular. The first half of the climb is on well-traveled trail, but as you get closer to the summit, the trail narrows and descends steeply. It's best to carry a headlamp and be prepared for wet and windy conditions.

After the Black Cloud Trail, the trail becomes more difficult to follow due to rock fall, which is caused by avalanches that have broken off the cliff face, creating a "valley of death" in the middle of the trail. This can be a dangerous place to be, so make sure you know what you're doing

She was launched on 13 March 1899 and completed on 31 July 1900. Kanji [ edit ]

普通 ( かんじょう ), Kanji (Kanji) [1] (pronunciation: [2]) is a syllabary consisting of twenty-four strokes. It is used to write Japanese, and the most commonly used kanji is hiragana (音読, lit. "reading" or "vocabulary") and katakana (品字, lit. "writing"). There are two types of kanji, ideograms and hiragana, and they are written in a way that makes it easy to recognize them by looking at the stroke order. In this article, we will focus on the ideograms and hiragana, but you can read more about them in the article on Kanji.

Japanese ideograms are made up of a set of characters that look like this:

A 会 B 取 C 日 D 集 E 見 F 今 G 千 H 下 I 明 J 方 K 久 L �

prefix_text: At the start of the Russo @-@ Japanese War, Asahi, commanded by Captain Hikohachi Yamada, was assigned to the 1st Divisi
reference_text: the 1st Fleet. She participated in the Battle of Port Arthur on 9 February 1904, when Vice Admiral Tōgō Heihachirō led the 1st Fleet in an attack on the Russian ships of the Pacific Squadron anchored just outside Port Arthur. Tōgō had expected the surprise night attack by his destroyers to be much more successful than it was, anticipating that the Russians would be badly disorganized and weakened, but they had recovered from their surprise and were ready for his attack. The Japanese ships were spotted by the protected cruiser Boyarin, which was patrolling offshore and alerted the Russian defences. Tōgō chose to attack the Russian coastal defences with his main armament and engage the ships with his secondary guns. Splitting his fire proved to be a poor decision as the Japanese eight @-@ inch ( 203 mm ) and six @-@ inch guns inflicted little damage on the Russian ships, which concentrated all their fire on the Japanese ships with some effect. Although many ships on both sides were hit, Russian casualties numbered only 17, while the Japanese suffered 60 killed and wounded before Tōgō disengaged. Asahi was not hit during the engagement.

After the battle was over, Yamada returned to his unit to receive a commendation for valor, and was promoted to Captain on the strength of his performance.

The following year, Yamada was given command of the 2nd Division, which was stationed in the south of Kyushu. On May 1, 1945, Yamada led his division in a successful amphibious landing on Saipan, the largest island in the Marianas archipelago. The landing was a success, and by the end of the month all of the troops had landed on Saipan. However, a typhoon swept through the island, destroying much of the landing force and severely hampering the progress of the invasion. As a result, it was decided to continue the invasion in the next few days, rather than wait for the weather to clear. reference_text: column of Japanese battleships, behind Mikasa, and was one of the primary targets of the Russian ships. She was only hit by a single 12 @-@ inch shell that wounded two crewmen. Both guns in her aft 12 @-@ inch gun turret, however, were disabled by shells that detonated prematurely in their barrels. In turn she concentrated most of her fire upon the battleships Poltava and Tsesarevich although both ships were only lightly damaged by the Japanese shells, which generally failed to penetrate any armour and detonated on impact. The ship made the critical hits of the battle, however, when two of her 12 @-@ inch shells struck the bridge of Tsesarevich, killing the Russian squadron commander, Vice Admiral Wilgelm Vitgeft, two of his staff officers and the ship's quartermaster. The ship's wheel was jammed to port by wreckage and then slowed to a halt which threw the rest of the Russian ships into total confusion. The second @-@ in @-@ command, Rear Admiral Prince Pavel Ukhtomsky, eventually gained control of the remainder of the squadron and headed back to Port Arthur. Slightly more than two months later, on 26 October, Asahi struck a mine off Port Arthur while on blockade duty. Severely damaged, she was under repair at Sasebo Naval Arsenal from November 1904 to April 1905. Russian naval forces in the Far East had been destroyed or neutralized by this time and the Russians were forced to transfer ships from the Baltic Fleet that did not arrive until May.

Yamamoto's attack was repulsed by the combined efforts of the Japanese and American navies, and the Japanese fleet was forced to withdraw to Nagasaki, where it remained for the remainder of the war.

After the battle, the United States and Japan signed the Treaty of San Francisco, which provided for the exchange of prisoners of war (POWs) and indemnities for damage done to each other's ships and aircraft. This resulted in the repatriation of more than 200,000 Japanese POWs to their home country in the years that followed. Asahi was one of the largest recipients of this compensation, receiving a total of $5 million (equivalent to more than $100 million in today's dollars). At the Battle of Iwo Jima on 7 August 1945, Asahi once again took a lead role in the fleet's battle against the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps. Asahi's battleship Nagato was one of the most heavily damaged ships in the battle, losing a third of her superstructure and more than half of her deck. Nagato had to be scuttled in order to prevent damage to the shipyard that was building her and to allow repairs to be made.

In August of that year, the Japanese surrendered unconditionally to the Allied forces at the end of World War II.

In the summer and autumn of 2013, the submarine was refitted to the stage of an active submersible, which is a necessary step in the maintenance of a submarine in service. This was followed by the installation of a diesel-electric propulsion system, which will help Asahi reach her goal of operating for 30 years without maintenance.

According to Japan's Maritime Self-Defense Force (MSDF), as of the end of March 2014, there were three submarines in service with the MSDF, which are the Kure, Shonan Maru-class (SSK) submarines, and the I-400-class (SSK-I-400) submarines. The I-400-class submarines have a displacement of 2,000 tons and are capable of submerging to a depth of more than 300 meters (984 feet). They can carry torpedoes and anti-ship missiles as well as other types of ordnance.

Japan's submarine fleet is the world's largest, with more than 1,000 submarines and support vessels.

Asahi's mission was to provide anti-aircraft protection for U.S. carriers in the Pacific, but she was unable to do so due to poor weather conditions. On the night of 7-8 August, a typhoon passed over the Ryukyu Islands, bringing heavy rain and flooding that caused the deck plating to cave in several times. This was the first of a series of typhoons that would be known as the Kanto-Kansai (Carpathian) typhoons, after the area in which they struck. In the early morning hours of 8 August, Asahi was hit by a torpedo from a Japanese submarine, and sank in less than 30 minutes. Of the 1,890 survivors, 783 were airlifted to Okinawa, and the rest were taken as prisoners of war (POWs).

prefix_text: The 1888 – 89 New Zealand Native football team was a New Zealand rugby union team that toured Britain, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand in 1888 and 1889.
reference_text: It mostly comprised players of Māori ancestry, and also included some Pākehā ( white New Zealanders ). A wholly private endeavour, the tour was not under the auspices of any official rugby authority ; it was organised by New Zealand international player Joseph Warbrick, promoted by civil servant Thomas Eyton, and managed by James Scott, a publican. The Natives were the first New Zealand team to perform a haka, and also the first to wear all black. They played 107 rugby matches during the tour, as well as a small number of Victorian Rules football and association football matches in Australia. Having made a significant impact on the development of New Zealand rugby, the Natives were inducted into the International Rugby Board Hall of Fame in 2008.

The first game was won by a score of 24-0, with two tries scored by John McAllister and one by George Giddings. In the second game, the All Blacks won by a score of 28-0 to take the series 3-0.

Plymouth had an important role in the development of New South Wales, as it was the first settlement in the south-eastern part of the state. The arrival of the Pilgrims was a turning point in the history of the colony, and marked the beginning of a new era of settlement, culture and commerce.

In 1788, Governor Phillip was forced to resign his governorship and return to England due to ill health. This led to the appointment of Sir George Oxenden as Governor-General in his place. Oxenden's first act was to issue a proclamation declaring Plymouth a colony of Great Britain and the Governor-General a Protector of the Colonies, a position in which he remained until his death in 1801.

A memorial to the settlers is located in the centre of St Kilda Road, which runs parallel to the railway line. The memorial commemorates the Pilgrim Fathers and their descendants, and includes a plaque dedicated to each settler who passed away in the last 100 years or so.

She performed both classical works by Vincenzo Bellini and Henry Purcell, mixing them with modernist and neoclassical works by Arnold Schoenberg, Darius Milhaud, Béla Bartók, and Paul Hindemith. The second half of her performance would upset the musical establishment, however. Gershwin played the piano for these pieces. Important figures in the audience included Ernestine Schumann @-@ Heink, Virgil Thomson, and Paul Whiteman. In her speech to the New York Philharmonic on April 1, 1923, she spoke of her love of music and said, "I am in love with music as a means of expressing the feelings of my soul, which is the same as with any other art. Music is an art in its own right, and its value is inextricably bound up with the value of the soul that sings it."

The following is a transcript of her speech:

And I feel as if I have been invited to a wedding or a christening of some new-born child. The thought of such a great and solemn occasion fills me with a kind of rapture that cannot be described in words. I can only say that this is the happiest day

Washington was hailed as a hero, and his reputation for valor was cemented in the public mind.

A large vessel sailing into Charleston first had to cross Charleston Bar, a series of submerged shoals lying about 8 miles ( 13 km ) southeast of the city, and then pass by the southern end of Sullivan's Island as it entered the channel to the inner harbor. In 1805, a fort was built on the west side of the bay to protect the ships from the sea while they were moored in San Francisco Bay. Fort Point Loma was the name given to the fort and it was a part of the U.S. Army until the Civil War.

During the 1850s and 1860s, the Navy began to build fortifications along the California coast in an effort to protect the Navy Yard at Alameda, which was being used as a base for the construction of steamers. These fortifications were designed to protect the wharves and other naval facilities from attack, and the first of these was Fort Point Lobos (also known as Fort Point Loma) in the Bay of Campeche. This fortification was completed in 1855 and was named after the town of Lobos, Mexico, where the Mexican-American War broke out in 1846.

After the Civil War, the Naval Base was decommissioned and became a naval training center. In the early 20th century, the base was turned into a hospital and later a hospital/relief station for World War II and the Korean War. It was renamed Naval Medical Center San Francisco (NMCSF)

reference_text: for possible landing points on nearby Long Island ( now known as the Isle of Palms ), just a few hundred yards from Sullivan's Island ; troops were consequently sent to occupy the northern end of Sullivan's. By June 8, most of the British fleet had crossed the bar and anchored in Five Fathom Hole, an anchorage between the bar and the harbor entrance. With the fort on Sullivan's Island only half complete, Admiral Parker expressed confidence that his warships would easily breach its walls. Optimistically believing he would not even need Clinton's land forces, he wrote to Clinton that after the fort's guns were knocked out, he would " land seamen and marines ( which I have practiced for the purpose ) under the guns " and that they could " keep possession till you send as many troops as you think proper ".

Hood was in the South Carolina capital of Beaufort, about 100 miles (160 km) south of Charleston, when news of the arrival of the British fleet reached him. On June 1, 1864, Hood sailed from Beaufort to the Chesapeake Bay, where he was joined by Rear Admiral William Farragut, commander of the United States fleet in the Atlantic. Farragut had been given command of the Atlantic fleet in the wake of the Battle of Hampton Roads, which had ended the Civil War a few months earlier.

After a week of sailing, Hood and his fleet arrived off New York City on June 4, just in time to watch the bombardment of Fort Sumter, the first step in the secession of the South from the Union. The Union blockade of the South did not last long, and in mid-June, President Abraham Lincoln issued Proclamation No. 1, which called for the restoration of the Union and a national election to be held on November 8, 1864.

On the night of the 18th, a group of about a half-dozen Union soldiers led by a lieutenant named John Buford made their way to the town of New Market, a few miles north of Charles City. Buford's men were on their way to take up positions in an abandoned farmhouse, but the Confederates had other plans.

As night fell, the Union soldiers heard shots coming from the farmhouse and opened fire, killing one of the men and wounding another. The Confederates, however, did not take the opportunity to flee, and continued to fortify their position. At some point during the night, Lee decided to send an advance party to New Market, and ordered Maj. Gen. Benjamin Butler to lead the way.

Butler arrived at the farmhouse just in time to see Lee surrender his command to Butler, who was in charge of the Union forces that had been sent to capture the town. After the surrender, Lee surrendered himself to the Union forces at Appomattox Court House.

prefix_text: On the morning of June 28, Fort Sullivan was defended by Colonel Moultrie, commanding the 2nd South Carolina Regiment and a company of the 4th
reference_text: South Carolina Artillery, numbering 435 men. At around 9 : 00 am that morning, a British ship fired a signal gun indicating all was ready for the attack. Less than an hour later, nine warships had sailed into positions facing the fort. Thunder and Friendship anchored about 1 @.@ 5 miles ( 2 @.@ 4 km ) from the fort while Parker took Active, Bristol, Experiment and Solebay to a closer position about 400 yards ( 370 m ) from Sullivan's Island, where they anchored facing broadside to the fort. Each of these ships began to fire upon the fort when it reached its position, and the defenders returned the fire. Although many of Thunder's shots landed in or near the fort, they had little effect ; according to Moultrie, " We had a morass in the middle, that swallowed them up instantly, and those that fell in the sand in and about the fort, were immediately buried ". Thunder's role in the action was also relatively short @-@ lived ; she had anchored too far away from the fort, and the overloading of her mortars with extra powder to increase their range eventually led to them breaking out of their mounts. Owing to shortage of gunpowder, Moultrie's men were deliberate in the pace of their gunfire, and only a few officers actually aimed the cannons. They also fired in small volleys, four cannon at a time. One British observer wrote, " Their fire was surprisingly well served " and it was " slow, but decisive indeed ; they were very cool and took care not to fire except their guns were exceedingly well directed. "

By this time it was dark, and the only light came from lanterns carried by the men on horseback or in wagons. As night fell, the Confederates began to move in a northwesterly direction to cut off the retreat of the Union forces.

Colonel Moultrie was ordered to fall back to the south bank of the Roanoke River, which was about one mile to the south of Fort Sullivan. The Confederate advance guard was in position on the north bank, and a number of Confederate sharpshooters were stationed on the opposite bank.

Maintaining contact with the enemy was difficult, however, because of the thick underbrush of the swamps and marshes, which made it difficult to see the enemy and make accurate fire. The men had little food and were suffering from thirst, and their ammunition was low in quantity and low in quality.

Aftermath [ edit ]

[3] On the morning of the 18th, the Royal Navy launched a counterattack that recaptured Portobello and other fortifications in the area. The Battle of Trafalgar was one of the bloodiest naval engagements in history, and resulted in the loss of more than 1,000 British and Commonwealth sailors and seamen. It would be a decade before the British regained the upper hand in the Atlantic and North Sea, and another decade before they were able to recapture Portobello and its environs.

prefix_text: Hu lived in Nanjing during the transition from the Ming dynasty to the Qing dynasty. A Ming loyalist, he was offered a position at the rump
reference_text: court of the Hongguang Emperor, but declined the post, and never held anything more than minor political office. He did, however, design the Hongguang Emperor's personal seal, and his loyalty to the dynasty was such that he largely retired from society after the emperor's capture and death in 1645. He owned and operated an academic publishing house called the Ten Bamboo Studio, in which he practised various multi @-@ colour printing and embossing techniques, and he employed several members of his family in this enterprise. Hu's work at the Ten Bamboo Studio pioneered new techniques in colour printmaking, leading to delicate gradations of colour which were not previously achievable in this art form.

Nanjing had fallen into disarray after the death of the Ming emperors in 1644, and was ruled by a succession of warlords, each of whom claimed to be the successor to the deposed Ming emperors. In 1649, the city was taken over by an alliance of Ming loyalists known as the Jin Dynasty, led by Li Zicheng (黃國良), who established himself as the de facto ruler of the city. Li's reign was short-lived, however, as he was overthrown in 1652 and executed for treason. His son, Li Hongzhi (李林瑜), took over the Jin Dynasty, but was deposed in 1656, only to reemerge two years later with the support of the Manchus and declare himself emperor of China.

After Li's death, the Jin Dynasty crumbled, and the Manchus, who had been allied with the Jin Dynasty for a time, began to move in to take control of the city. The Mancheng (明�

Hu named it the Ten Bamboo Studio ( Shizhuzhai, 十竹齋 ), after the ten bamboo plants that grew in front of the property. It functioned as the headquarters for his printing business, where he employed ten artisans including his two brothers Zhengxin and Zhengxing ( 正行, art name Zizhu, 子著 ) and his sons Qipu ( 其樸 ) and Qiyi ( 其毅, courtesy name 致果 ).

In 1620, Hu died of a broken heart and was buried in his home. The tomb was moved a few years later and Hu's remains were reburied in the tomb of a nobleman who had helped Hu escape the persecution of the Yongle Emperor. This was the first time in more than 500 years that a Confucian scholar had been interred in a tomb, and it marked a turning point in the history of China.

After Hu's death, the family continued to be wealthy and influential, and they built a library and other buildings to house their library and manuscripts. The Hu family was one of the most important families in Ming China for the next two centuries.

During the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644), China was in the midst of a civil war between the Manchus and the Mongols. This period of turmoil was known as the Warring States Period (二月突成, Wǔrìjiǎo), and many scholars, scholars-politicians, and military leaders were killed in the war. Hu Zetian was one of these

prefix_text: During Hu's lifetime, the Ming dynasty, which had ruled China for over 250 years, was overthrown and replaced by China's last imperial dynasty
reference_text: , the Qing. Following the fall of the capital Beijing in 1644, remnants of the imperial family and a few ministers set up a Ming loyalist regime in Nanjing with Zhu Yousong on the throne as the Hongguang Emperor. Hu, who was noted for his seal @-@ carving and facility with seal script, created a seal for the new Emperor. The court offered him the position of Drafter for the Secretariat ( zhongshu sheren, 中書舍人 ) as a reward, but he did not accept the role ( although he did accord himself the title of zhongshu sheren in some of his subsequent personal seals ).

Hu's death in 1644 was mourned by the Chinese, who called him "the father of the nation" and a "martyr for the Chinese nation".

Image copyright Getty Images Image caption Chinese Emperor Taizong (right) gave Hu a tomb in Nanjing, capital of the Ming dynasty, in 1644

But the emperor was a divisive figure, and many historians have argued that he did not live up to his father's legacy.

In recent years, China has embarked on a process of re-evaluating its past, which has led to the publication of a growing number of books and articles that seek to shed light on the country's history.

One of the most controversial books is The Origins of Modern China by Zhang Lifan, which was published in 2013.

Zhang's book is an examination of what he describes as the "myth of Confucianism" - the idea that China was founded by a sage named Confucius who lived in 5th Century BC.

The Chinese, he argues, are the descendants of people who migrated from Central Asia and the Middle East to settle in China, and not the other way around.

prefix_text: Despite his reputation as an artist and seal @-@ carver, Hu was primarily a publisher. His publishing house, the Ten Bamboo Studio, produc
reference_text: works on calligraphy, poetry and art ; medical textbooks ; books on etymology and phonetics ; and copies of as well as commentaries on the Confucian Classics. Unlike other publishers in the area, the Ten Bamboo Studio did not publish works of narrative fiction such as plays or novels. This bias towards academia was likely a consequence of the studio's location : the mountain on which Hu took up residence was just to the north of the Nanjing Guozijian ( National Academy ), which provided a captive market for academic texts. Between 1627 and 1644, the Ten Bamboo Studio produced over twenty printed books of this kind, aimed at a wealthy, literary audience. The studio's earliest publications were medical textbooks, the first of which, Tested Prescriptions for Myriad Illnesses ( Wanbing Yanfang, 萬病驗方 ) was published in 1631 and proved popular enough to be reissued ten years later. Hu's brother Zhengxin was a medical practitioner and appears to have been the author of these books.

After the fall of the Ming Dynasty, Hu renamed the studio the Hall Rooted in the Past ( Digutang, 迪古堂 ) as a sign of his affiliation with the previous dynasty, although the Ten Bamboo imprint continued to be used. In the mid-1630s the Ten Bamboo Studio became involved in the construction of the Forbidden City, which was completed in 1635-1636. This is the most famous of the Ming palaces, and its design is a tribute to the artist's love of nature and its beauties.

After the death of the Emperor Yongzheng in 1636, the Ten Bamboo Studio continued to produce political works, but they were no longer commissioned by the emperor. Instead, their output fell into disrepute, and many of the masterpieces were sold at public auction. The last work produced by the studio was a portrait of the Empress Dowager Cixi, which was sold for 10,000 taels in 1638.

By the end of the Ming dynasty there were no more Ten Bamboo Studio masters in the country, and it was thought that the studio had been closed for good. However, a group of artists, known as the "Ten Bamboo Men", were able to survive by working in private workshops and selling their work on the black market. prefix_text: The Ming dynasty had seen considerable advancement in the process of colour printing in China. At his studio, Hu Zhengyan experimented with various forms of woodblock printing
reference_text: , creating processes for producing multi @-@ coloured prints and embossed printed designs. As a result, he was able to produce some of China's first printed publications in colour, using a block printing technique known as " assorted block printing " ( douban yinshua, 饾板印刷 ). This system made use of multiple blocks, each carved with a different part of the final image and each bearing a different colour. It was a lengthy, painstaking process, requiring thirty to fifty engraved printing blocks and up to seventy inkings and impressions to create a single image. Hu also employed a related form of multiple @-@ block printing called " set @-@ block printing " ( taoban yinshua, 套板印刷 ), which had existed since the Yuan period some 200 years earlier but had only recently come into fashion again. He refined these block printing techniques by developing a process for wiping some of the ink off the blocks before printing ; this enabled him to achieve gradation and modulation of shades which were not previously possible.

One of the most famous examples of Hu's printing is the Ming-era portrait of Empress Dowager Cixi (r. 1640-1696), which has been described as the first'magnificent' portrait of a woman in the Western world. The Empress Dowager Cixi was an accomplished artist, and her portrait shows her to be a master of the brush and ink as well as the brush and paper. She has the look of a woman who has spent her life in the world of painting and calligraphy, rather than that of a courtesan or concubine. In addition to the painting, there are a number of engravings that Hu produced for the Empress, including a series of watercolours of her portrait in the Palace of the Forbidden City in Peking. These are the earliest examples of what would become known as the 'Dowager Series' of Chinese art.

Hu Zhengyan's career was cut short by the death of his patron, the Emperor Yongle of the Ming dynasty. He moved to Hangzhou, where he continued to produce portraits and engravings until his death in 1696.

The Hu family was a well-known family in Guangdong, and Hu Xijin (1840-1908), the son of Hu Shih-k'ai (1838-1910), was an important figure in the development of Huayuan painting.

Huayuan paintings have been found in a number of museums, including the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, where they are on display in the Huayuan exhibition.

In recent years, there has been a resurgence of interest in Huayuan painting, particularly in the United States and Europe. The art world is fascinated by the story of Hu and his family, and has created a large collection of Huayuan paintings, as well as an annual Huayuan festival in Hong Kong to celebrate the art form.

A painting of a man with a bow and arrow, dated c. 1900, was sold at Sotheby's in New York for $1.8 million (HK$8.5 million), making it the most expensive painting ever sold in the United States. It was bought by a Chinese collector who plans to donate it to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

prefix_text: Hu's most notable work is the Ten Bamboo Studio Manual of Painting and Calligraphy ( Shizhuzhai Shuhuapu,
reference_text: 十竹齋書畫譜 ), an anthology of around 320 prints by around thirty different artists ( including Hu himself ), published in 1633. It consists of eight sections, covering calligraphy, bamboo, flowers, rocks, birds and animals, plums, orchids and fruit. Some of these sections had been released previously as single volumes. As well as a collection of artworks, it was also intended as an artistic primer, with instructions on correct brush position and technique and several pictures designed for beginners to copy. Although these instructions only appear in the sections on orchids and bamboo, the book still remains the first example of a categorical and analytical approach to Chinese painting. In this book, Hu used his multiple @-@ block printing methods to obtain gradations of colour in the images, rather than obvious outlines or overlaps. The manual is bound in the " butterfly binding " ( hudie zhuang, 蝴蝶裝 ) style, whereby whole @-@ folio illustrations are folded so that each occupies a double @-@ page spread. This binding style allows the reader to lay the book flat in order to look at a particular image. Cambridge University Library released a complete digital scan of the manual, including all writings and illustrations in August, 2015. Said Charles Aylmer, Head of the Cambridge University Chinese Department, " The binding is so fragile, and the manual so delicate, that until it was digitized, we have never been able to let anyone look through it or study it – despite its undoubted importance to scholars. The Chinese were able to transport goods to and from the Far East by sea for less than $1 per kilogram, compared to the cost of sea freight in Europe, which ranged from $5 to $10 per kilogram. This was a huge advantage for the Chinese, who did not have to pay import duties and were free to trade at low prices.

Trade in the Far East was so important that China became the center of the world's silk trade, which reached its zenith in the 16th century. Silk was made from the cocoons of silkworms, which were harvested in the spring and spun into yarn, which was then woven into cloth by women and sold to merchants in the city of Hangzhou, where the silkworm cocoons were stored for the winter.

As the world's most populous country, China had the resources to build a network of trading posts, called mandarins, along the Silk Road. These posts were staffed by Chinese officials and their retinues, who collected taxes and maintained law and order in the area. This, however, did not last long, for, in less than a quarter of an hour, the British ship returned to the anchorage, and took up her station in the same place she had left it the day before.

However, this did not mean that the Australians were out of the war. In the months that followed, Australian and New Zealand troops continued to gain ground, capturing a number of Japanese outposts and fortifications. By the end of the war, the Australians had won an impressive victory, which was followed by a period of peace and prosperity for the Australian people.

Akihiko Umezawa, a Japanese soldier captured by the Australian Army, was one of the most famous prisoners of war in World War II. He became known as the "Angel of Nanking" for his role in the Battle of Changde, where he fought side-by-side with his compatriots against the Japanese forces. Umezawa died in a POW camp in the South Pacific in 1972 at the age of 82.

prefix_text: Sonic the Hedgehog is a 2D, side @-@ scrolling platformer, whose gameplay centers around Sonic's ability to run at high speed through
reference_text: levels incorporating springs, slopes, high falls, and loop @-@ the @-@ loops. The levels contain hazards in the form of robots ( " badniks " in the Western game manuals ) inside of which Dr. Robotnik has trapped animals. Although destroying a robot frees the animal within, this is not required to complete the game. The player must avoid rows of sharp spikes, falling into bottomless pits, being crushed by moving walls or platforms, and drowning ( which can be avoided by breathing air bubbles periodically released from vents ). Sonic's main attack is his spin, where he curls into a ball and rotates rapidly ( damaging enemies and some obstacles ). This can be performed by jumping in the air or rolling on the ground.

In the game, there are a total of four worlds: Eggman's base, Dr. Robotnik's Robotnikland, Knuckles the Echidna's Jungle Hijinx, and Tails the Tornado who is an airship pilot and has a jetpack. Each world is divided into a number of levels, each of which has a boss at the end of it. The player is given a life bar that depletes over time, and when it runs out, the game is over.

Sonic the Hedgehog has been released on the Sega Mega Drive, Game Gear, Nintendo Entertainment System, PlayStation, and Xbox. It is the first Sonic game to be released on a home console, and the first in the series to use the 16-bit hardware. The game was developed by Yuji Naka, who was the lead programmer for the Sonic the Hedgehog series up until that point. Naka's involvement ended when Sega of America took over development of the series, which resulted in the departure of many staff members, such as composer Masato Nakamura.[1]

The reason I brought this up is because in my last blog I talked about how we have an image problem. It's a problem that affects every part of our lives, not just video games. The more we try to fit in, the more we want to be accepted by the people around us, which in turn makes us less likely to take risks, be open to new ideas, and try new things.

This is why, for example, the majority of games are set in one location and have a limited number of places to go and do things. The only thing that changes is the color of the sky, the background, and the characters that are in the game. This creates a sense of sameness, and it's not good for us as a society.

So what can we do about this? Well, one of the most important things is to stop thinking of games as "art" and start thinking of them as "entertainment." Games are entertainment, after all. And entertainment is about creating a story, not telling a story. If you look at any movie, playstation, etc. you'll see that there is a story, but it's the story that makes the movie or tv show a movie or tv show

prefix_text: With a satisfying protagonist completed, Sega turned to esteemed programmer Yuji Naka, who had impressed them through his work on Phantasy Star and the Genesis por
reference_text: of Ghouls'n Ghosts. The gameplay originated with a tech demo by Naka, who developed an algorithm allowing a sprite to move smoothly on a curve by determining its position with a dot matrix. Naka's prototype was a platform game with a fast @-@ moving character rolling in a ball through a long, winding tube, and this concept was fleshed out with Ohshima's character designs and levels by designer Hirokazu Yasuhara. Yasuhara originally intended to work on the game for three months due to the delay of his planned move to the United States by the outbreak of the Gulf War, but was engrossed in the project for nearly a year. His designs for levels were intended to attract both hardcore and casual gamers by integrating occasional challenging set pieces into the mostly accessible level design. The game's color scheme was influenced by the work of pop artist Eizin Suzuki, and the aesthetics of Green Hill were influenced by the geography of California.

Naka was brought on to work on Sonic the Hedgehog, but the project was put on hold due to his inexperience with 3D graphics at the time. Instead, Sega brought on Shigeru Miyamoto, a master of the genre, to take over the project. Miyamoto's first task was to create a level editor that would allow players to create their own levels, as well as the game's story, characters, and music. This was an important step in the development of the game, as it allowed Sega to focus on the gameplay rather than having to worry about what was going on in the background. In addition to the level editor, Sega also needed an in-game map editor, which was made possible by the use of a computer-aided design (CAD) program called Sculptris. Sculptris, which was released in 1991, had the ability to draw polygons on the screen in real time, and the player could manipulate these polygons by dragging them around the screen. This made it possible not only to create new levels, but also to add new characters to the game, such as Knuckles the Echidna (pictured above) and Tails

prefix_text: In designing the game mechanics, Naka was inspired by Shigeru Miyamoto, whose games he had enjoyed playing years earlier. Admiring the simplicity
reference_text: of Miyamoto's mechanics in complex environments, Naka decided that Sonic would be controlled with only a directional pad for movement and a single button for jumping. He also wanted his creation to be more action @-@ oriented than the Mario series ; while playing Super Mario Bros., he had wondered why the levels could not be cleared more quickly. Due to the need to demonstrate the Genesis'technological prowess, the developing game underwent extensive testing and redesign, a process taking over six months. The developers'efforts were rewarded ; according to Yuji Naka, the game had the fastest @-@ ever character speed in a video game and a rotation effect in the special stages that was considered impossible on the console. The team intended to add a two @-@ player mode displayed via split @-@ screen, but Naka's programming knowledge was insufficient to implement this feature. However, such a mode would later appear in sequel Sonic the Hedgehog 2 ( 1992 ), where the second player would control Sonic's best friend Miles " Tails " Prower. Naka, Oshima, and Yasuhara worked 19 hours a day on the project for several months.

Biography

In the mid-1980s, Nakamura was a high school student in the United States. His interest in music began at a young age, and he began playing the saxophone in his family's living room when he was five years old. At the age of six, the family moved to Los Angeles, California to pursue a career in music. In the summer of 1988, Nakamura enrolled in Berklee College of Music in Boston, Massachusetts, with the intention of becoming a jazz musician like John Coltrane.[1]

Nakamura studied with a wide variety of jazz musicians, including Herbie Hancock, Wayne Shorter, Bill Frisell, Miles Copleston, Kenny Burrell, and many others. During his time at Berklee, Nakamura developed a love for improvisation and the art of songwriting, which would serve him well in his career as a solo artist and in the creation of music for video games, such as Super Smash Bros. Melee's music for Mario Kart: Double Dash!! and the soundtrack for The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time 3D.

Story

Sonic's parents were killed by Dr. Eggman, who stole their research to create Chaos Emeralds. In order to avenge his parents, Sonic sets out to find the Chaos Emeralds and stop Eggman once and for all. Along the way, he meets Knuckles the Echidna, Tails the Tornado, Amy Rose the Robotnik Babysitter-in-Training, Rouge the Bat-Fighter, Silver the Hedgehog, Big the Cat, Chao the Acrobat, and a new friend named Sticks the Badminton-Wielding Fox. The game takes place in a world that looks a lot like the one from Sonic the Hedgehog 2, but with a few differences. For one, there are no Chao to play tennis with, nor are there any enemies that are based on characters from the series. Also, instead of being an arcade game, this game is a side-scrolling platformer with a story that is told in cutscenes rather than text.

Gameplay

The gameplay is similar to that of Super Mario Bros. 3, except that Sonic has four lives instead of three, and his jumps are a little higher than Mario's. In addition,

prefix_text: Sonic the Hedgehog has been available for all three major seventh @-@ generation video game consoles. It was part of the Wii Virtual Console at the servic
reference_text: 's 2006 introduction, and was released for the Xbox Live Arcade and PlayStation Network shortly afterwards. The game was released for the iPod Classic, iPod video, and video @-@ capable iPod Nano models in 2007 and for Apple's iOS service ( compatible iPhone and iPod touch models ) in April 2009. Sonic the Hedgehog became available on GameTap in September 2009. In October 2010, it was released as a Microsoft Windows download which was ported to Steam. The game was ported to two online app services ( Google Play and the Amazon Appstore ) in December 2012. A remastered mobile port, created using Christian Whitehead's Retro Engine previously used in the 2011 rerelease of Sonic CD, was released on iOS, replacing the original port, on May 15, 2013 with an Android version released the following day. The port features widescreen graphics, the optional ability to spin dash, a time attack mode, and the unlockable option to play as Tails or Knuckles the Echidna. The game was also released as part of the Nintendo 3DS 3D Classics line in May 2013 in Japan, and worldwide in December.

Gameplay

Sonic's moves are similar to those of Mario, but he can jump higher and has a spin attack. The game is played on a 2D plane, with Sonic moving left and right, up and down, and diagonally. There are four types of enemies: Knuckles the Echidna, Tails the Chaos Emerald, Amy Rose the Green Egg, and Rouge the Bat. Each of the four have different attack patterns, and they are able to attack in any direction they are

prefix_text: Sonic the Hedgehog has maintained its popularity, appearing on lists of the greatest video games of all time. Frank Provo of GameSpot described the game as
reference_text: " one of the best platformers of all time ", noting that despite technical issues in the Game Boy Advance port " after all these years, the underlying graphics, audio, and gameplay still hold up ". Lucas M. Thomas of IGN agreed that it stood the test of time : " You 'll be impressed by the clarity and color that come through... Few people realize how difficult it was to create Sonic's graphics engine, which allowed for the incredible rate of speed the game's known for. But the technical achievement impressed back in'91, and still does so today. " Mega ranked the game its third @-@ favorite Genesis title, and in 2001 Game Informer called it the 24th @-@ greatest game of all time. Sonic the Hedgehog has been a commercial success ; the original Genesis version sold over 15 million copies by February 2009, and the mobile version had eight million paid downloads by 2008.

Story

Sonic is a hedgehog who lives in a world known as Mobius. His home is the Sky Patrol, a group of space-faring robots that protect the sky from threats such as meteorites and space pirates. One day, an evil force from the Dark Gaia Empire invades Mobius, enslaving the Sky Patrol and taking control of the planet. To fight back, Sonic sets out on a quest to find the Chaos Emeralds, which grant the wielder the power to transform into Super Sonic. Along the way, he runs into Tails, Knuckles, Amy the Echidna, Rouge the Bat, Silver the Hedgehog, Big the Cat, Shadow the Hedgehog, and more. The game is divided into two parts, the first of which takes place on Earth and the second on Mobius. In the Earth portion, players control Sonic and his friends as they travel through the United States, stopping the Empire from taking over the world. After defeating Eggman, the Empire flees, leaving Sonic and his friends to continue

prefix_text: The game's success led Sega to develop an extensive media franchise. A 1992 sequel, Sonic the Hedgehog 2, gave Sonic a best friend ( a
reference_text: sidekick ) named Miles " Tails " Prower and continued the fight against Dr. Robotnik. Sonic has generated dozens of additional games and a large cast of recurring characters ( keeping Sonic and Robotnik as mainstays ), surviving the end of Sega console manufacturing after the Dreamcast. The series has ventured from platformers to fighting, racing, role @-@ playing, and sports games, and has expanded into anime and manga, cartoons and comic books, novels, and toys. Sonic the Hedgehog has become one of the best @-@ selling video game franchises of all time, with over 150 million copies sold by May 2014. The game's first stage, Green Hill Zone, has also been re @-@ purposed for use in several other titles such as Sonic Adventure 2, Sonic Generations and the Super Smash Bros. series.

Plot Synopsis and Epilogue

After being shot in the back by a bounty hunter, Boba Fett (Ben Mendelsohn) awakens in a prison cell. His cellmate is Jango Fett (Donnie Yen), who explains that they are on the run from bounty hunters and have no way to communicate with one another. Jango is a Mandalorian and Boba is a clone of his son, Boba Han Solo (Harrison Ford). The two begin to converse in a language neither has ever heard before, and it becomes clear that their relationship is far from platonic. They are forced to work together to survive the galaxy's most dangerous criminals, the Hutts of Tatooine.[1]

prefix_text: US Highway 2 ( US 2 ) is a component of the United States Numbered Highway System that connects Everett, Washington, to the Upper Peninsula ( UP )
reference_text: of the US state of Michigan, with a separate segment that runs from Rouses Point, New York, to Houlton, Maine. In Michigan, the highway runs through the UP in two segments as a part of the state trunkline highway system, entering the state at Ironwood and ending at St. Ignace ; in between, US 2 briefly traverses the state of Wisconsin. As one of the major transportation arteries in the UP, US 2 is a major conduit for traffic through the state and neighboring northern Midwest states. Two sections of the roadway are included as part of the Great Lakes Circle Tours, and other segments are listed as state @-@ designated Pure Michigan Byways. There are several memorial highway designations and historic bridges along US 2 that date to the 1910s and 1920s. The highway runs through rural sections of the UP, passing through two national and two state forests in the process.

prefix_text: The route of what became US 2 was used as part of two Indian trails before European settlers came to the UP, and as part of the Michigan segments
reference_text: of the Theodore Roosevelt International Highway and the King's International Highway auto trails in the early 20th century. The state later included these trails as part of M ‑ 12 when the first state highway trunklines were designated in 1919. Most of M ‑ 12 was redesignated as part of US 2 when the US Highway System was created on November 11, 1926. Since the 1930s, several changes have reshaped the highway's routing through the UP. One such alteration eventually created a business loop that connected across the state line with Hurley, Wisconsin, and others pushed an originally inland routing of US 2 closer to the Lake Michigan shoreline. With the creation of the Interstate Highway System, part of US 2 was rerouted to coincide with the new Interstate 75 ( I ‑ 75 ), though in the 1980s, the U.S. Highway was truncated and removed from the I ‑ 75 freeway, resulting in today's basic form.

Originally known as the Bridge of the Damned, it was the first bridge in Grand Rapids to be built with a cantilever truss design, which allowed it to withstand winds of up to 100 mph (160 km/h). The bridge opened in 1885 and served as a connection between the city of Kalamazoo and the town of Saginaw, which was about two miles (3.2 km) to the south. However, by the mid-1930s, traffic had increased to the point that the bridge was no longer safe for traffic, and it was torn down in 1937. Today, the site of the bridge is owned by the Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT), and there is a parking lot for visitors to enjoy the view of the Detroit River from the bridge.

reference_text: Built as a part of a raceway flume on the river, the water level is actually higher than the road surface. This produces a siphon effect, giving the bridge its nickname. The Manistique Pulp and Paper Company was organized in 1916 and needed a dam on the Manistique River to supply their mill. This dam would require a large section of the city to be flooded, and shallow river banks meant difficulties in any bridge construction. Instead of expensive dikes, a concrete tank was built lengthwise in the river bed ; the sides of this tank provided man @-@ made banks higher than the natural banks. The Michigan Works Progress Administration described the bridge as having " concrete bulkheads, formed by the side spans of the bridge, [ that ] allow the mill to maintain the water level several feet above the roadbed. " The Manistique Tourism Council stated : " At one time, the bridge itself was partially supported by the water that was atmospherically forced under it, " and that the bridge has been featured in Ripley's Believe It or Not!. This mill was in use for a number of years and is said to have done a good deal of work for the shipbuilding yard at Plymouth.

A large number of millwork of this type was carried out on the ships which were built in the Royal Navy Yard at Woolwich, which had been converted into a shipbuilding yard by the Admiralty in 1834. These ships were of all sizes and in all respects were similar to the work which had been done before the conversion, except that the machinery was of iron rather than wrought iron. In some of the ships it was found that the working of the machinery was too great for the strength of the ship, and this necessitated the fitting of a counterbalancing system to counteract the centrifugal force which would result from the work being done at a speed of twenty-five or thirty miles an hour. This system consisted of a pair of cranks on each side of the mill, which were connected by a pulley and chain to a wheel of the same size as the crank. Early history [ edit ]

In prehistorical times, there were no humans in New Zealand, except for a few species of marsupials such as kangaroos (Macropus giganteus and G. rufogriseus, the latter of which lived in South Island and Tasmanian regions). The landmass was covered by a sea, which covered most of the island until the Pleistocene Epoch (5.6 million years ago to 11,700 years ago), when sea levels rose due to glacial meltwater and ice sheets in the Northern Hemisphere. At that time, the landmass was separated from the sea by a land bridge called Rapa Nui (Rapa meaning "Land of the Natives" in Maori, and Niu-Moutain meaning "Mountains of the Natives"). This land bridge remained in place until the end of the last ice age around 12,000 years ago.

reference_text: while the Colonial Office in London retained control of some affairs, the Governor of the each colony was required to raise their own colonial militia. To do this, they were granted the authority from the British crown to raise military and naval forces. Initially these were militias in support of British regulars, but when military support for the colonies ended in 1870, the colonies assumed their own defence responsibilities. The colonial military forces included unpaid volunteer militia, paid citizen soldiers, and a small permanent component. They were mainly infantry, cavalry and mounted infantry, and were neither housed in barracks nor subject to full military discipline. Even after significant reforms in the 1870s — including the expansion of the permanent forces to include engineer and artillery units — they remained too small and unbalanced to be considered armies in the modern sense. By 1885, the forces numbered 21 @,@ 000 men. Although they could not be compelled to serve overseas many volunteers subsequently did see action in a number conflicts of the British Empire during the 19th century, with the colonies raising contingents to serve in Sudan, South Africa and China.

This act provided for the establishment of a navy and established the Department of Naval Affairs and Marine, which was responsible for the training and equipping of seamen, as well as maintaining and repairing naval vessels.

A total of 2,814 Australians and New Zealanders lost their lives in the First World War, of whom more than a third were killed by landmines. The war was a turning point in Australia's history, leading to the creation of the Commonwealth of Australia in 1901 and the end of British rule in Australia in 1901. In addition, it is estimated that up to 100,000 Australian and New Zealand servicemen were wounded or maimed during the war.

Australia's contribution to the Great War was to play a major role in the Gallipoli campaign of 1915-1917, and was one of the most significant contributions of the Australian Expeditionary Force (AEF) to the war effort. The AEF fought with distinction in the Dardanelles and Gallipoli theatres, as well as in the Middle East, Africa and South-East Asia. It was the first time that Australia had participated in a major war since the Boer War in 1899-1901.

I Anzac Corps then took part in the Third Battle of Ypres in Belgium as part of the campaign to capture the Gheluvelt Plateau, between September and November 1917. The operation was a success, but not without a price. On the night of 7-8 June, more than 1,000 Australians were killed and another 1,000 wounded in a German counterattacking that lasted until dawn the next morning.

In his memoirs, Field Marshal Sir Douglas Haig wrote that he was "deeply moved to the memory of the gallant Australians who gave their lives in this battle, and I feel that it is my duty to pay their last respects to their comrades and those who lost their lives in the defence of our motherland".

A memorial was erected in the village of Beaumont-Hamel, just north of Ypres, to honour the fallen. It is the only place in the world where this battle is commemorated in this way.

By the end of the day, France was in shambles, its capital of Paris reduced to rubble and thousands of its citizens massacred in cold blood.

It was the bloodiest day in French history since the Battle of Verdun in 1916. In the days that followed, the French people rose up in a wave of resistance to the German occupiers, leading to the creation of the Vichy government under Marshal Petain in collaboration with the British and American occupation forces.

After three years of war, the war was at an end. But not for the French, who were forced to live under the yoke of the Germans for another ten years.

In the years that followed, Australia's military remained a low priority for the Labor government of Gough Whitlam, who sought to avoid a repeat of the Vietnam War by withdrawing from Southeast Asia in 1975.

Labor was re-elected in 1977 and, after an acrimonious split in the party, Whitlam's successor Paul Keatley took the party to the centre ground in the 1980s with a policy of "no first use" of nuclear weapons.

That policy was adopted by the Coalition government of John Howard in 1996, but its effects were marginal at best.

The Howard government had no qualms about bombing Serbia in 1999, killing tens of thousands of Serbs and Bosnians, and in the same year launched air strikes against Iraq for the first time in the Middle East.

In 2003, Tony Abbot, Australia's ambassador to the United Nations, told the Security Council that "there is no doubt in my mind that Saddam Hussein is a threat to his neighbours and to the international community" and called for a pre-emptive strike against Iraq.

The air raids were designed to frighten the Germans into surrendering and, if necessary, to inflict casualties on German troops in the field.

By the end of May, the Germans had agreed to a ceasefire and were in the process of evacuating their troops from the Western Front. reference_text: Australian airmen served in dozens of British and five Australian squadrons in RAF Bomber Command between 1940 and the end of the war. Australians took part in all of Bomber Command's major offensives and suffered heavy losses during raids on German cities and targets in France. Australian aircrew in Bomber Command had one of the highest casualty rates of any part of the Australian military during the Second World War and sustained almost 20 percent of all Australian deaths in combat ; 3 @,@ 486 were killed and hundreds more were taken prisoner. Australian airmen in light bomber and fighter squadrons also participated in the liberation of Western Europe during 1944 and 1945 and two RAAF maritime patrol squadrons served in the Battle of the Atlantic.

prefix_text: From the 1920s Australia's defence thinking was dominated by British Imperial defence policy, which was embodied by the " Singapore strategy ". This strategy involved th
reference_text: construction and defence of a major naval base at Singapore from which a large British fleet would respond to Japanese aggression in the region. To this end, a high proportion of Australian forces in Asia were concentrated in Malaya during 1940 and 1941 as the threat from Japan increased. However, as a result of the emphasis on co @-@ operation with Britain, relatively few Australian military units had been retained in Australia and the Asia @-@ Pacific region. Measures were taken to improve Australia's defences as war with Japan loomed in 1941, but these proved inadequate. In December 1941, the Australian Army in the Pacific comprised the 8th Division, most of which was stationed in Malaya, and eight partially trained and equipped divisions in Australia. The RAAF was equipped with 373 aircraft, most of which were obsolete trainers, and the RAN had three cruisers and two destroyers in Australian waters.

In the first half of the 20th century there was a steady increase in Australia's defence spending from $1 billion in 1900 to a peak of $5 billion in the mid-1950s. This was due to the need to maintain a strong navy and air force, but also to counter the threat of Soviet expansion in the Pacific and East Asia. The Australian government had no qualms about spending money on defence, as long as it was spent in a fiscally responsible manner. This led to an increasingly militaristic attitude in the public and political discourse, which became more pronounced during the Cold War and its aftermath.

Australia's strategic position in the Pacific was based on the fact that it was the only country on the island of New Hebrides with access to the South Pacific, and the only country to have a land border with the Soviet Union. This gave Australia a privileged position in the region, and the perception that Australia was in a position of power and influence was fostered by the military-industrial complex (MIC). The MIC was a combination of government-industry-academia, whose members worked in defence and other industries, and the academic and thinktanks that produced research for the government and industry. prefix_text: The Australian military suffered a series of defeats during the early months of the Pacific War. The 8th Division and RAAF squadrons in Malaya formed a
reference_text: part of the British Commonwealth forces which were unable to stop a smaller Japanese invasion force which landed on 7 December. The British Commonwealth force withdrew to Singapore at the end of January, but was forced to surrender on 15 February after the Japanese captured much of the island. Smaller Australian forces were also overwhelmed and defeated during early 1942 at Rabaul, and in Ambon, Timor, and Java. The Australian town of Darwin was heavily bombed by the Japanese on 19 February, to prevent it from being used as an Allied base. Over 22 @,@ 000 Australians were taken prisoner in early 1942 and endured harsh conditions in Japanese captivity. The prisoners were subjected to malnutrition, denied medical treatment and frequently beaten and killed by their guards. As a result, 8 @,@ 296 Australian prisoners died in captivity.

By the end of the war, there were fewer than 1,000 Australian troops in the Pacific, down from a peak of more than 10,000 at the start of the war. Australia's participation in the Second World War was the largest in its history, accounting for more than one-third of the nation's defence budget in the 1940s and 50s.

prefix_text: Australians played a central role in the New Guinea campaign during 1942 and 1943. After an attempt to land troops at Port Moresby was defeated in the Battl
reference_text: the Coral Sea, the Japanese attempted to capture the strategically important town by advancing overland across the Owen Stanley Ranges and Milne Bay. Australian Army units defeated these offensives in the Kokoda Track campaign and Battle of Milne Bay with the support of the RAAF and USAAF. Australian and US Army units subsequently assaulted and captured the Japanese bases on the north coast of Papua in the hard @-@ fought Battle of Buna @-@ Gona. The Australian Army also defeated a Japanese attempt to capture the town of Wau in January 1943 and went onto the offensive in the Salamaua @-@ Lae campaign in April. In late 1943, the 7th and 9th Divisions played an important role in Operation Cartwheel, when they landed to the east and west of Lae and secured the Huon Peninsula during the Huon Peninsula campaign and Finisterre Range campaign.

However, the Japanese continued to build up their forces in the South Pacific, and on Christmas Day 1943 a Japanese submarine, the I-16, sank the SS Ville de Bois-Jouet, which was carrying supplies to the Australian garrison at Rabaul. This was the first of a series of attacks on Australian convoys that would continue until the end of the war.

In early 1944, the Japanese launched Operation Tomahawk, the invasion of New Guinea. The operation was a disaster, resulting in the deaths of more than 2,000 Australian servicemen and a large number of civilian New Guineans. It is estimated that at least one-third of the Australian casualties were due to inadequate food rations, and many Australians lost their lives as a result of the disease scurvy brought on by the poor sanitary conditions on the island.

The war ended in May 1945, with the Allies winning the Battle of the Coral Sea and the Pacific theatre of World War II.

prefix_text: Australia's role in the Pacific War declined from 1944. The increasing size of the US forces in the Pacific rendered the Australian military superfluous and labour shortages

In late 1944, Australian troops and RAAF squadrons replaced US garrisons in eastern New Guinea, New Britain, and Bougainville, and launched offensives aimed at destroying or containing the remaining Japanese forces there. In May 1945, I Corps, the Australian First Tactical Air Force and USAAF and USN units began the Borneo Campaign, which continued until the end of the war. These campaigns contributed little to Japan's defeat and remain controversial.

After the war [ edit ]

In the 1950s and 1960s there was a resurgence of interest in the war, particularly in Australia. This was due to the publication of a number of books and articles by Australian and New Zealand soldiers and the Australian War Memorial in Canberra was renamed the Australian War Memorial to commemorate the sacrifice of Australian servicemen and women who fought in the Pacific and the Middle East, as well as those who died in the Second World War. The war also became a subject of political debate in Australia and the United Sates as politicians sought to make amends for the nation's role in the war and in some cases sought reparations from the Japanese government.

AUSTRALIA'S DIFFERENT ROLE IN WORLD WAR II

During the Second World War Australia played a significant role in the Allied war effort, providing air and naval support to the Allies in North Africa, the Middle East and the Pacific.

In the Mediterranean, Australian aircraft flew more sorties than any other nation, and the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) became the most heavily involved air force in the war.

The RAAF's contribution was made possible by the arrival of the USAAF P-38 Lightning, which began to be used in the Mediterranean in December

prefix_text: During the early years of the Cold War, Australian defence planning assumed that in the event of the outbreak of a global war between the Western world and Eastern bloc
reference_text: countries it would need to contribute forces under collective security arrangements as part of the United Nations, or a coalition led by either the United States or Britain. The Middle East was considered the most likely area of operations for Australian forces, where they would most likely operate with British forces. Early commitments included the involvement of RAAF aircrew during the Berlin Airlift in 1948 – 49 and the deployment of No. 78 Wing RAAF to Malta in the Mediterranean from 1952 to 1954. Meanwhile, defence preparedness initiatives included the introduction of a National Service Scheme in 1951 to provide manpower for the citizen forces of the Army, RAAF and RAN.

This was based on the assumption that the Soviet Union, China and North Korea had nuclear weapons and were determined to use them against the United States and its allies.

It was a reasonable assumption at the time, but not one that has held up to the test of time.

Today, there is no reason to believe that any of the countries that were in the running for war in the 1950s and 1960s are any longer interested in doing so.

In recent years, China has moved to modernise its military and, with the help of Russia, has begun to project power in the Asia-Pacific region.

The same is true of Russia, which has become a major power in its own right, as well as the former Soviet republics of Central Asia.

Australia's military capabilities are no longer the best in the world and the threat of war with China and Russia is no longer a credible threat to Australia's security.

The war was a turning point in the history of trench warfare, which had been in the ascendancy since the Napoleonic Wars of the 18th and 19th centuries. In the first half of the 19th century, trenches were the domain of infantry, but by the end of the century, artillery was used to devastating effect in the Great War (1914–18), and the use of mechanized warfare began to take hold. As a result, infantry became a secondary force in the trenches, and it was not until the late 1930s that a large-scale offensive was launched against the enemy's trenches. This was the Battle of the Somme, which began on July 1, 1916, and lasted until November 11, 1916. By that time, more than one million soldiers had lost their lives in the battle, and it is estimated that as many as 100,000 were wounded.

Synopsis for "Exit Through the Kwik" Edit

A group of aliens from another planet arrive on Earth in search of a planet that they call home. The aliens are led by Dr. Zoidberg, who claims to be the "king of the aliens" and has created a society where everyone is equal, no matter how many arms they have, what color their skin is, or their gender. However, his rule is not without its flaws, as some of the aliens are greedy, and some want to rule by force. One alien, Mart, is an outcast, a man who does not have a penis, and is treated like a second class citizen. When he tries to escape his life of servitude, he ends up in the sewers of New New York, where he meets his best friend Leela (Amy Poehler), the only person who understands him. Together, they work as janitors to make ends meet, and Leela becomes romantically involved with him. The next day, Zoidberg is found dead in his office, and it is revealed that he was murdered by Mart. The Battle of Fort Sumter was a turning point in the American Revolution, and it has been the subject of a number of books, including John Garth's A Short History of the American Revolution (1958), which was based on an oral history conducted by Garth's great-grandfather, William C. Joe was the last to qualify by pinning Roode after slamming him back and neck @-@ first into the mat with his signature Muscle Buster maneuver. Joe then hung the title belt at 19 minutes and 49 seconds to win the competition.

In the mid-1990s, Savage began a feud with Hulk Hogan, which would culminate in a WrestleMania match at Madison Square Garden in New York City on April 2, 1994. The two had been feuding for several years, and Hogan's wife Trish Stratus was one of the most vocal opponents of Savage's on-screen alter ego Savage Steve Austin. Produced by Bob Ezrin, this album was the first of a series of Lenny & The Mindbenders albums that would continue for the next three and a half years. The lineup of the band changed over the course of the recording sessions, but was kept together for the album and its follow-up, A Tribute to Leonard Cohen (released in 1987). In addition to Bob Ezrin, other members of the band included bassist/vocalist Steve Albini, who was replaced by John Scofield on the album and on the tour that followed.

A Tribute to Leonard Cohen, the band's second album, was recorded in New York City, with a number of sessions taking place at Studio B, the home of Columbia Records' in-house session group, the "Blue Note Boys" (led by George Wein, Jr.). The sessions were overseen by the label's head of A&R, Alan Moulder, and his team of executive vice presidents/associates, who had worked with the band in the past. Plot

After the death of his father, Jack Torrance moves to Los Angeles to take over the family business. However, his plans are thwarted by a group of bullies known as the Bully Pulpit, who try to get him fired by any means necessary. The bully pulpit consists of Torrance's best friend Stanley Rizzo, the school janitor Bill Denbrough, and Jack's father Henry Bumstead (whom Jack is in love with). Henry has an ulterior motive for tormenting Jack, and it is revealed that he is the son of the serial killer Norman Bates from Psycho. After being tormented by Norman's mother Norma Bates, Jack begins to develop homicidal tendencies as a result of his father's murder.

Plot [ edit ]

A letter written by John Wilkes Booth in the summer of 1887 was found in the pocket of a man who claimed to be Booth's bodyguard and identified him as "Buckley" to the FBI. The letter contained details of the plot, as well as a list of people who would be in attendance at the assassination. Booth wrote that he had been "given to understand" that the plan was to kill President Grover Cleveland by firing a shot from the White House, but did not specify which shot was to be fired. In an attempt to avoid being caught, Booth planned to hire a hit man to carry out the assassination and then escape to Mexico with the money he had stolen from the bank robbery and other crimes. The plot was foiled when one of Booth's accomplices turned him in to the police for the murder of William McKinley on June 6, 1887 (McKinley was assassinated the next day by Leon Czolgosz, an Austrian-born immigrant to the United States who had worked as a stagecoach driver before moving to New York and becoming a gangster in the 1880s and 1890s). Zaitz was a graduate of Stanford University and the University of California at Berkeley, where he studied political science with a focus on Soviet and Eastern European affairs. After graduating in 1968, he went to New York to work for the Associated Press, and in 1971 was hired by the San Francisco Examiner. His work on the Watergate break-in was the basis for his Pulitzer Prize-winning book The Burglary: The FBI's Secret War Against the Press (1972), which won the National Book Award for nonfiction that year.

In the 1970s and 1980s, Zaitz was one of the most prolific and well-regarded investigative journalists in the country, with a reputation for digging into the inner workings of government and the business world. Her trial was the first time anyone had been tried for Meredith's murder in the United States. Stork claimed self-defense, and the jury found her guilty by a 9-1 vote. In the years that followed, a number of witnesses came forward to corroborate her story, including a police officer who was on the scene that night, as well as an ex-boyfriend of Stork's who testified that he had sex with her the night of the murder.

After her conviction, Stork appealed her conviction to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which upheld her conviction on the grounds that there was insufficient evidence to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that she was the person who committed the crime. The appeals court noted that "it is difficult to imagine a more flagrant miscarriage of justice than the prosecution's failure to present any evidence at all that the murder was committed by a person other than Ms. Stork."

Both women were sentenced to five years in prison. Croft and Hagan did not testify during their trial. " We hashed over everything – evidence, notes, evidence, notes. I think we did an absolutely fabulous job, " said one of the jurors. At the sentencing for Croft and Hagan, the federal Judge Malcolm Marsh described them as " people of obvious goodwill who had committed an extremely serious offense against the criminal justice system. " Prosecutor Tim Reardon called the conspiracy to commit assassination " a deadly serious crime aimed at the heart of the criminal justice system. " Croft and Hagan were released from imprisonment at FCI Dublin, California in April 1998, and returned to Britain.
