.

The case was the first to test the constitutionality of extradition to the United States of persons who had been convicted in their home countries of crimes against the United States or its citizens. In that case, the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit held that the government could not extradite Croft and Hagan on the basis of a treaty that did not provide for the death penalty, and that, as a result, the extradition was unconstitutional. (See United States v. Van Leeuwen, 827 F.2d 1203 (9th Cir. 1987) (en banc).)

Crocker's lawyers appealed to the Supreme Court, and on June 26, 1996, the Justices issued a 5-4 decision in the case, which was joined by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. The Court held that the treaty between the United States and Great Britain, known as the Extradition Treaty of 1856, "provides no basis for depriving a person of life, liberty, or property without due process of law." Id. at 5-6. The Court's reasoning was based on the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, which protects against cruel and unusual punishment in the criminal justice system. Id. at 6

Bai Juyi was a master of all kinds of poetry, but it is difficult to say how much of his work was based on his knowledge of Confucianism and how much was a result of his ability to create a narrative that resonated with the people at the time. In any case, he had a wide readership, both in China and abroad.

The most famous of his poems is the "Chrysanthemum Sutra" (普華經), which tells the story of a man who falls in love with a flower, only to be rejected by her after the birth of her son. The poem is an allegory for the difficulties of love, and its popularity was such that it was translated into many languages and used as a source of inspiration for a great many works of art and literature over the centuries.

A few years after the poem was written, Du Fu died in his home town of Nanjing, which was under the control of the Manchus, who wanted to wipe out the influence of Buddhism and Buddhism-influenced art, music and literature that had flourished in the Tang dynasty. The Manchus did not succeed

prefix_text: During the Kan 'ei era of the Edo period ( 1624 – 1643 ), Shào Chuán ( 邵傳 )
reference_text: of the Ming Dynasty's Collective Commentary on Du Fu's Lǜshi ( 杜律集解, Toritsu Shikkai ) was imported into Japan, and it gained explosive popularity in Confucian scholars and chōnin ( townspeople ) class. The commentary established Du Fu's fame as the highest of all poets ; for instance, Hayashi Shunsai, a notable Confucian scholar, commented in Vol. 37 of Gahō Bunshū that Zǐměi [ Du Fu ] was the very best poet in history and praised Shào Chuán's commentary for its simplicity and readability, while he criticized old commentaries during the Yuan Dynasty were too unfathomable. Matsuo Bashō, the greatest haiku poet, was also strongly influenced by Du Fu ; in Oku no Hosomichi, his masterpiece, he cites the first two lines of A Spring View ( 春望 ) before a haiku as its introduction and also many of his other haiku have similar wording and themes. It is said that when he died in Osaka during a long travel, a copy of Du Fu's poetry was found with him as one of a few precious items which he was able to carry around.

prefix_text: A variety of styles have been used in efforts to translate Du Fu's work into English. As Burton Watson remarks in The Selected Poems of Du Fu
reference_text: , " There are many different ways to approach the problems involved in translating Du Fu, which is why we need as many different translations as possible " ( p. xxii ). The translators have had to contend with bringing out the formal constraints of the original without sounding laboured to a Western ear ( particularly when translating regulated verse, or lǜshi ), and accommodating the complex allusions contained particularly in the later works ( Hawkes writes that " his poems do not as a rule come through very well in translation " — p. ix ). One extreme on each issue is represented by Kenneth Rexroth's One Hundred Poems From the Chinese. His are free translations, which seek to conceal the parallelisms through enjambement and expansion and contraction of the content ; his responses to the allusions are firstly to omit most of these poems from his selection, and secondly to " translate out " the references in those works which he does select.

The translation of this work is in many ways a case of translation by subtraction, as it leaves out a great deal of the original text and, more important, ommatizes it to the point of obliteration. In this respect it is no different from the work of other translators who have tried to make sense of the Chinese by cutting it into fragments and rearranging it in a way that does not correspond to the original text. [1]

Watson goes on to point out that this "removal of the whole, or at least the most important part of the original text" is characteristic of the translations of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, such as that of J. A. Macpherson, and that it has led to a reduction of the meaning of the poem to that of a collection of aphorisms. [2] The fact that many of the poems are in Chinese, however, makes it possible to make a more accurate translation than one based on Macpherson's paraphrases. [3]

Following the loss of most of the IJN's large aircraft carriers during the Battle of Midway in mid @-@ 1942, they were rebuilt with a flight deck replacing the rear pair of gun turrets to give them the ability to operate an air group of floatplanes. A lack of aircraft and qualified pilots, however, meant that they never actually operated their aircraft in combat. While awaiting their air group the sister ships were sometimes used to ferry troops and material to Japanese bases. They participated in the Battle of Cape Engaño in late 1944, where they decoyed the American carrier fleet supporting the invasion of Leyte away from the landing beaches. Afterwards both ships were transferred to Southeast Asia ; in early 1945 they participated in Operation Kita, where they transported petrol and other strategic materials to Japan. The sisters were then reduced to reserve until they were sunk during American airstrikes in July. After the war they were scrapped in 1946 – 47.

The only time an aircraft carrier was used as a base of operations was during the Battle of Midway in 1942, when it was used to provide air cover for ground troops in the defense of Guadalcanal. However, this was a one-time event, and it did not lead to a long-term use of aircraft carriers as forward bases. In fact, the Navy was reluctant to commit its carrier task forces to the Pacific until the war was over, fearing that they would be vulnerable to air attack once the Japanese had taken the war to the home islands. As a result, carriers were relegated to defensive duties, and their role was primarily that of escorting convoys and other merchant ships through the Panama Canal.

The USS Forrestal (CV-59) was decommissioned in the mid-1960s and became a museum ship at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. It was sold to the Navy for scrapping in the early 1970s after a fire on board killed all crew and caused extensive damage to the ship. The Forrestal served as a training ship for U.S. Coast Guard cadets until her conversion to amphibious assault ship USS Bonhomme Richard (LHD-1) took place in 1983.

The USS Saratoga (CV-60) was decommissioned in the early 1970s and became a museum ship at San Diego, California. The Saratoga has been in drydock for over 30 years due to corrosion and structural problems caused by exposure to salt water. In 2012, the Navy decided to scrap the Saratoga and move it to Puget Sound, Washington, to make way for a new aircraft carrier that will be christened in the summer of 2016.

The design of the Class I-class was based on the experience gained during the development of the B-class battleships. It was intended to be a "stealth" class, and as such, its design did not conform to the "conventional" convention of the time, which was to have a flat deck, which was the most obvious sign of stealth. In order to reduce the weight of the ship, it was decided to equip the battleship with a number of auxiliary equipment such as a radio set, electric motor (which was used to power the propellers) and an oil-cooling system. This allowed the ship to travel at a speed of 25 knots (30 km/h or 18 mph), which was sufficient for the time being.

As a result of the construction of the Ise class, the Japanese Navy was able to increase its strength to the point where it was no longer a match for the United States Navy in the Pacific, and the war ended in a stalemate.

After the war, the ship was decommissioned and sold to a private owner in the United States of America for scrap. It was later bought by the U.S. Coast Guard, who used it as a training ship for their cadets at New London, Connecticut. The ship was sold to an American museum in the 1970s and has been on display ever since.

On 31 December 1941 the German High Seas Fleet (HSSF) began Operation Barbarossa in the North Sea against the British Isles and Channel Islands. This was the largest amphibious operation in history up to that time and involved the invasion of the United Kingdom and the seizure of a large part of the Atlantic seaboard of Great Britain. The Germans were determined to break the Anglo-Saxon will to resist the war and so launched a campaign of unprecedented ferocity, ruthlessness and ruthlessness against the British Isles and Channel Islands. In the first week of December 1941 more than 2,000 ships were sunk, and by the end of the month there were an estimated 20,000 British and Commonwealth lives lost as a result of the German invasion.

As well as the ship's fire control system, there were other factors that contributed to the success of the battle. For one thing, the Japanese had been forced to make a decision: either surrender unconditionally, or fight to the last man. They chose the latter, and in doing so gave up their most powerful weapon against the US Navy: aircraft carriers.

The Battle of Midway was the first time in World War II that a carrier battle had been fought at night, and it marked the turning point in the war. The Japanese carriers were no longer able to operate in the open sea, and had to rely on night bombing raids to keep their planes aloft. This, in turn, meant that the US Navy had an easier time finding and destroying them.

In the end, the battle resulted in a Japanese surrender, and the end of the Pacific War. However, this did not

The loss of four Japanese aircraft carriers during the Battle of Midway in June 1942 severely limited the ability of the IJN to provide any air cover and alternatives were sought. Earlier proposals to convert one or more battleships into carriers had been made and rejected at the beginning of the war, but they were revived after Midway. Plans for more elaborate conversions were rejected on the grounds of expense and, most critically, time, and the IJN settled on removing the rear pair of turrets and replacing them with a flight deck equipped with two catapults to launch floatplanes. The Ise @-@ class ships were selected for the conversion because Hyūga had suffered an explosion in Turret No. 5 in early May that virtually destroyed the turret and their Turret No. 6 could not elevate to the full + 43 degrees deemed necessary for the long @-@ range engagement anticipated by the IJN. The Fusōs were scheduled to follow once the first two were completed.

This was a turning point in the war, as Japan's victory would come at the cost of the US's Pacific Fleet being decimated in the Battle of Midway (see below).

The battle began on 7 December 1941 and lasted three and a half months, during which it was the bloodiest engagement in the Pacific War to that point. Over 2,000 ships were sunk, including the battlescruiser Missouri, the battleship Texas, the aircraft carrier Hornet, and a number of destroyers, cruisers, and destroyers. Of the US fleet, only one carrier, the Arizona, escaped unscathed.

In addition to the destruction of the US fleet, the Japanese also took control of Wake Island, a strategically important atoll in the Marshall Islands that was home to the U.S. Seventh Fleet. Wake had been under Japanese control since the mid-1930s, but it was captured by the US in December 1941 and remained in Japanese hands until the end of the war.

History [ edit ]

Creation and Conception [ edit ]

Hyūga was designed by Kazuhiko Inoue.[1] Inoue's design was based on the character of a samurai from the Edo period, which is the time period of the series' setting. The name "Hyrulian" comes from the word "haiku", which means "dance" in Japanese. This was a reference to the fact that Hyūga's gun was named after a dance technique, as well as the fact that the series takes place in feudal Japan, a time of warring clans that fought for land and power. He has a red-and-white color scheme, similar to that of Samurai Champloo's Gashadokuro

prefix_text: Shortages of aircraft and serviceability problems greatly retarded pilot training and the ships only had a total of 17 D4Ys and 18 E16As

The Japanese plan for the defence of the Philippines envisioned that the surviving carriers would be used to lure the American carrier forces away from the invasion area to a position where the carriers could be attacked by land @-@ based aircraft and the transports by the rest of the IJN. The other carrier air groups were not in much better shape and the Japanese decided to retain the aircraft ashore for use against the American carriers. The Fourth Carrier Division was assigned to the Northern Force under the command of Vice Admiral Jisaburō Ozawa and the sisters sailed from Yashima on 20 October. On the morning of 24 October, the bulk of the few aircraft aboard were launched to attack the American carriers as a distraction. They inflicted no damage and caused the Americans to search in the direction from which they had attacked. The Americans finally spotted the Japanese carriers at 16 : 40, some 200 miles ( 320 km ) east of Cape Engaño, the northeastern tip of Luzon. The American carriers were spread out and it was very late in the day to launch an airstrike, so Admiral William Halsey, commander of the Third Fleet decided to mass his carriers in a position to attack the following morning. Ozawa reversed course during the night, correctly believing that the Americans would follow him north.

The battleship was assigned to the Baltic Fleet and participated in the invasion of the Soviet Union in June and July 1944. On the night of Nov. 21, 1864, the USS Wainwright (ATF-5) fired a salvo of six torpedoes at the Union sloop Chesapeake, killing all on board. This was the first time in the Civil War that a torpedo had been used in naval warfare. The Chesapeake was one of the most powerful warships in the Union Navy, and had the ability to outmaneuver the blockade runner, making it an ideal target for the torpedo. In the years that followed, naval warfare would be dominated by torpedoes, and it is no surprise that the Navy was the first to develop a ship-launched torpedo as early as 1864.

A few days later, the USS Gannet (ATF-6) fired a total of nine torpedoes at the Union steamship New York, sinking her in two hours and forty-five minutes. reference_text: the American carriers departed the South China Sea ( Operation Kita ). They loaded their cargoes beginning on 6 February at Singapore and departed four days later. Also carrying some 1 @,@ 150 oilfield workers, they were escorted by Ōyodo and three destroyers. Decrypted Japanese radio signals revealed the Japanese plan to the Allies, and 15 submarines were positioned along their anticipated route in an attempt to intercept and sink the ships. An additional 11 were moved into position while the group was en route, but only three were ultimately able to attack. None of them were successful before the Japanese reached Kure on 20 February. The Fourth Carrier Division was disbanded on 1 March and the sisters were reduced to 1st rank reserve ships. On 19 March Kure was attacked by aircraft from Task Force 58 and Hyūga was hit three times by bombs that killed 37 men and wounded 52. Her gunners claimed to have shot down one American dive bomber during the attack. Ise was hit twice during the attack, but her casualties, if any, are unknown.

In the process, the Japanese were caught off guard and suffered heavy losses in the Battle of Savo Island, which took place on the night of the 14-15 November 1942.

After the battle, it was found that the Japanese had lost more than 1,000 of their ships and a further 500 were damaged beyond repair. This was the most serious defeat in the Pacific War to that point.

The loss of so many ships, coupled with the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbour in December 1941, resulted in the United States entering the war against Japan in December 1941.

prefix_text: Rifenburg was born in Petoskey, Michigan, and raised in Kalamazoo, Michigan before his family moved to Saginaw, Michigan.
reference_text: Rifenburg was a star athlete at Saginaw's Arthur Hill High School in football, basketball, and track and field. In 1943, Michigan canceled boys high school tournaments in all sports due to World War II, and they did not return until the fall of 1944. In 1944, he led Arthur Hill High to the MHSAA Class A high school basketball championship ( over Kalamazoo Central High School ), scoring 24 points, including 17 in the second half, of the championship game. Rifenburg was also the state champion in 1944 in both the shot put 46 feet 11 inches ( 14 @.@ 30 m ) and high jump 5 feet 8 @.@ 5 inches ( 1 @.@ 74 m ). He also led Arthur Hill in football, and his high school accomplishments are featured in Glory : The history of Saginaw County sports by Jack Tany ( ASIN B0006RH9Z6 ), which is a book on high school sports in Saginaw County, Michigan. Rifenburg was named All State in football, basketball and track.

Rifenburg has a brother, Matt, who played in the NFL for the San Francisco 49ers and Indianapolis Colts.

"

After graduating in 1945, Rifenburg worked as a photojournalist in New York and Los Angeles for Time, Life, Sports Illustrated (where he won a Pulitzer Prize in 1948 for a series on World War II veterans' mental health), and other publications. In 1948, he married his high school sweetheart, Edith Schuyler, and the couple had a son, John Jr., who grew up to become a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist of his own.

During the 1950s and 1960s, Rifenburg traveled the world covering war and political unrest, as well as the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union. His most famous assignment was to photograph the Berlin Wall in 1961, which helped bring down the Iron Curtain.

In the mid-1960s, Rifenburg began photographing African-American civil rights activists in the South who were protesting segregation at lunch counters and other public places. He became one of the first photographers to document the sit-ins and other forms of civil disobedience that led to the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

reference_text: for the Wolverines from 1946 to 1948. Rifenburg played for the Wolverines in consecutive undefeated National Championship seasons in 1947 and 1948. Rifenberg and teammate Len Ford had the reputation as the team practical jokers. During the 1947 game against Wisconsin, Rifenburg started calling signals for the Badgers. Wisconsin's offense protested to officials, who " prowled the Wolverines secondary but never caught their man. Rifenburg made his debut for the national team in a friendly against the U.S. on March 23, 1946, and went on to play in the final match of the 1946-47 season, which ended in a 1-1 draw in New York. Rifenburg was a member of the team that won the first World Cup in the United States on June 14, 1947, in Los Angeles.

After his playing career ended, Rifenburg continued to coach in Germany, serving as head coach of the German national team from 1948-49 and again from 1951-52. He was the first coach to win the Bundesliga three times in a row (1948-49, 1949-50, 1951-52), and in his first season in charge, the team finished second in the league behind Borussia Dortmund.

In addition to the Heisman, Rifenburg was named All-America by Sports Illustrated, Associated Press, Sporting News and Walter Camp Football Writers of America. He was also a semifinalist for the Doak Walker Award, which goes to the nation's top running back.

The tropical storm moved rapidly west @-@ northwestward, steadily intensifying to a hurricane. Hurricane Wilma in 2005 and Hurricane Katrina in 2005 were the first and second most intense Atlantic hurricanes to strike the United States, respectively. Wilma, a Category 5 storm, caused $9 billion in damage and killed at least 1,833 people, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Katrina, a Category 3 storm, caused $110 billion in damage and killed more than 1,800 people when it struck New Orleans on August 29, 2005.

In a study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, researchers found that climate change is responsible for a "statistically significant increase in the frequency of tropical cyclones in the North Atlantic since the mid-20th century." This study is the first to use satellite data to examine the link between global warming and hurricane intensities, the researchers said.

The researchers analyzed data from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA's Terra and Aqua satellites, which provide high-resolution images of Earth's surface every 10 to 15 days. By looking at the changes in

prefix_text: The origins of the hurricane were from a tropical wave that possibly spawned a tropical depression on August 27, although there was minimal data over the next few days as
reference_text: it tracked to the west @-@ northwest. On August 31, a nearby ship reported gale force winds, which indicated that a tropical storm had developed to the east @-@ northeast of the Lesser Antilles. Based on continuity, it is estimated the storm attained hurricane status later that day. Moving quickly to the west @-@ northwest, the storm passed north of the Lesser Antilles and Puerto Rico. Early on September 2, a ship called the Gulfwing reported a barometric pressure of 978 mbar ( 28 @.@ 88 inHg ), which confirmed that the storm attained hurricane status. After passing north of the Turks and Caicos islands, the hurricane struck Eleuthera and Harbour Island in the Bahamas on September 3, the latter at 1100 UTC. A station on the latter island reported a pressure of 27 @.@ 90 inHg ( 945 mb ) during the 30 minute passage of the eye. Based on the pressure and the small size of the storm, it is estimated the hurricane struck Harbour Island with peak winds of 140 mph ( 225 km / h ), making it the equivalent of a modern Category 4 hurricane on the Saffir @-@ Simpson scale. Interpolation suggested that the storm reached major hurricane status, or Category 3 status, on September 2.

On the evening of August 28, Hurricane Harvey made landfall in Corpus Christi, Texas, as a Category 4 hurricane with winds of 130 miles per hour (210 kilometers per hour). The storm was downgraded to a tropical cyclone by the next morning, but continued to cause damage to the Gulf Coast and other parts of the Texas coast.

Hurricane Harvey has killed at least 15 people, including four who died in the flooding caused by the storm. It is the most powerful hurricane to hit the US since Wilma in 2005, when more than 50 people died in the Caribbean and Florida.

Harvey's death toll is expected to rise as rescuers continue to search for survivors in storm-ravaged areas, according to CNN meteorologist Chad Myers. He said the storm could bring as much as 50 inches (1.5 meters) of rain to Houston, which is home to 2.7 million people.

In 1851, Georges made landfall in New York and caused a storm surge that flooded the East River, killing at least 1,000 people and destroying much of Lower Manhattan. The city was rebuilt in the 1870s and 1870s, but many buildings were damaged by floodwaters, including the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, which was flooded to the point of collapse in 1873. A fire caused by a lightning strike on the third floor of the Waldorf-Astoria destroyed the hotel and many of its priceless artworks, including Rembrandt's Night Watch (ca. 1610) and Rubens Watercolors (ca. 1640). After the fire, the building was used as a storage facility for fire insurance claims and later became the home of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA). It was demolished in the early 1990s to make way for the World Trade Center (WTC) and other skyscrapers in the area.

Strong winds snapped many light poles in the city, and trees and shrubs were broken or uprooted. The city had learned from previous experience with severe storms in 1926, 1928, and 1929. Winter estates and hotels on Palm Beach generally sustained little material damage, except to vegetation, and county properties went largely unscathed.

A storm surge of 6 to 8 feet inundated parts of South Florida, causing flooding that was the worst in more than a century. The city was hit by at least one tornado, but officials did not have reports of injuries or property damage.

In Miami, which had its worst hurricane season on record last year, more than 1,000 people were evacuated from low-lying areas in the early morning hours of Sept. 10, the National Weather Service said.

Miami-Dade Mayor Carlos Gimenez declared a state of emergency for the county and ordered an evacuation of the Miami River, which runs through the city. The river was expected to crest at a record-shattering 39 feet above flood stage, which is the point at which water begins to rise in a storm.

Gimenez said in a statement that "it is time to stop playing games with Mother Nature and take a step back from the worst-case scenario."

"This is no time to sit back and do nothing," he said.

___ Associated Press writer Andrew DeMillo contributed to this report.

prefix_text: From the outbreak of the Korean War and the invasion of South Korea by the North, the North Korean People's Army had enjoyed superiority in both manpower a
reference_text: equipment over both the Republic of Korea Army and the United Nations forces dispatched to South Korea to prevent it from collapsing. The North Korean strategy was to aggressively pursue UN and ROK forces on all avenues of approach south and to engage them aggressively, attacking from the front and initiating a double envelopment of both flanks of the unit, which allowed the North Koreans to surround and cut off the opposing force, which would then be forced to retreat in disarray, often leaving behind much of its equipment. From their initial June 25 offensive to fights in July and early August, the North Koreans used this strategy to effectively defeat any UN force and push it south. However, when the UN forces, under the Eighth United States Army, established the Pusan Perimeter in August, the UN troops held a continuous line along the peninsula which North Korean troops could not flank, and their advantages in numbers decreased daily as the superior UN logistical system brought in more troops and supplies to the UN army.

As a result of these and other factors, it was inevitable that the North would try to take advantage of the situation by attacking the South with a force larger than its own. This, of course, was the purpose of the "Arduous March" that began on June 25, 1950, when thousands of North Korean guerrillas crossed the 38th parallel into South Korea in an attempt to seize the capital of Seoul.

The invasion was repelled with heavy losses on both sides, but not before it had killed an estimated 2,000 to 3,000 South Koreans and caused the South to withdraw its troops from the DMZ (Demilitarized Zone) and begin the arduous process of reunification.

In the spring of 1950, Kim Il Sung's North Korean forces launched a surprise attack on U.S. forces in the Pusan Perimeter, which stretched from the Sea of Japan to the 38th parallel. The attack was led by General Choe Yong-Hee, who would go on to become the head of the KPA General Staff until his death in 1994.

After several days of fighting, the United States was forced to withdraw its forces from the Pusan Perimeter, and it was left in disarray for the next two years.

The Second Battle of Naktong Bulge, as it came to be known, was one of the bloodiest battles of the Korean War, and its impact on the war was felt far beyond the borders of North and South Korea.

reference_text: th century. The ironclad was developed as a result of the vulnerability of wooden warships to explosive or incendiary shells. The first ironclad battleship, Gloire, was launched by the French Navy in November 1859. This type of ship would come to be very successful in the American Civil War.

The name comes from the fact that they were the first to use steam to propel a ship, which was a revolutionary technology at the time. In 1803, the U.S. Navy began construction of the USS Constitution, which was the first steamship in the world to be powered by steam. This ship had a crew of 1,200, and its speed was 30 knots (about 35 miles per hour). The Constitution was launched in 1797, and by the end of the year, there were more than 2,000 steam-powered ships in the U.S. Navy.

Ironclad was the name given to the ship of the same name built by the British Royal Navy in 1803-1804. The ironclad was armed with a 16-cylinder water-cooled engine that gave it a speed of about 20 knots (about 25 miles per hour). It was designed to defend against attack at sea and in the port of New York, as well as the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

In 1812, a ship built by John Pownall was the first to reach the North Pole, on December 2, 1812. The ship was named "Arctic" and carried passengers and a crew of 12, including two polar explorers, Robert Falcon Scott and Sir Ernest Shackleton.

Scott and Shackleton died in the Arctic while attempting to reach the South Pole, and were buried in the Arctic ice. Their graves are marked by a stone marker that reads in their native Inuktitut: "Here lies the grave of Robert Falcon Scott and Sir Ernest Shackleton, who, by the grace of God, and in the face of the enemies of the human race, were the first to reach the North Pole in the Polar Sea, on December 2, 1812."

The Arctic was named in honor of the ship and its crew, and it has been the setting for many movies, including James Cameron's Titanic (1997), which won the Academy Award for Best Picture in 1997.

In 1864, the CSS Shenandoah was commissioned as the flagship of Rear Admiral George Dewey, who was in command of the Navy's Atlantic fleet. Dewey's command proved to be short-lived, as on 1 April 1865, the Confederate Navy was decimated by Union General Ulysses S. Grant's advance on Vicksburg, Mississippi. Grant's victory was a turning point in the Civil War, and led to the end of the Confederacy as a military force.

After the war, the CSS Shenandoah was decommissioned and sold for scrap, but was purchased by the New York Shipbuilding Company in 1869. This was the beginning of the gun design process that we know today, but it was far from simple. For example, there was no way to know how many rounds a gun would need until it was in service, and even then it was not possible to make a gun that was small enough to fit on a ship's deck without compromising its armour protection.

As a result, guns had to be designed in a way that maximised their weight, while at the same time minimising their recoil so that they did not overbreathe when fired. To do this, the muzzle velocity of the gun was increased to a maximum of 1,000 metres per second (Mach 1.0), and the barrel length was reduced by 50% in order to achieve this muzzle velocity. This resulted in a gun that weighed a little over 10 tonnes, and was capable of firing a maximum of 60 rounds per minute.

A torpedo's speed is determined by the size of the warhead it carries, and the more powerful the warhead, the faster the torpedo will travel. This is a problem, because it's hard to get a torpedo to travel fast enough to hit a target that's out of range. In order to solve this problem, torpedo designers began experimenting with ways to increase the speed of their weapons without adding too much weight to the torpedo. One of the most common methods was to make the torpedo lighter than it was before, but this was not without its downsides. For one thing, the weight of the torpedo increased the ship's center of gravity, which made it more difficult to steer in a battle. For another, the increased weight meant that the torpedo had to be more heavily armored in order to withstand the shock of being launched at high velocities.

Aircraft carriers, on the other hand, are protected by a layer of armor that can be up to 30 feet thick on the flight deck and deck superstructure. This is known as "bulletproofing" and is the most expensive part of the shipbuilding process. It costs $1 billion a year to maintain, according to the Congressional Research Service.

But the United States has been in a state of war since the Korean War in the 1950s, and there is no end in sight to the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan. This law, among other things, requires the Navy to begin construction of a new aircraft carrier by 2023 or face a cut in funding from the Navy's shipbuilding account.

As the 20th century dawned, ships grew larger and more powerful, their hulls reinforced with steel to withstand torpedo attacks and the blast of cannonballs. In World War II, the United States began to rely on nuclear-powered battleships for deterrence against the Soviet Union, which was developing its own submarine fleet. But as the Cold War drew to a close, naval power was reasserting itself in the Persian Gulf and East Asia, where American and Japanese navies fought a two-decade-long battle for control of the South China Sea.

By the end of the 19th century, a new era of technological and economic development was dawning in the United States, Europe and other parts of the world. This period was known as the Industrial Revolution (1850-1900).[1] The first industrial revolution took place in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, but it was not until the second industrial revolution that the world entered a new era of mass production, which led to the rise of the middle class and an unprecedented increase in living standards for the first time in human history.

History and development [ edit ]

Early history [ edit ]

In the beginning, there was no such thing as "manufacturing", as most people were subsistence farmers who made their living by hunting and gathering. The word "machinery" was used to describe a tool that was used to make something, such as a plow, and not an actual machine. This was the beginning of the development of machinery, which became a key factor in the industrial revolution.

Industrial revolution [ edit the page if you want to learn more about the history of the Industrial Revolution]

Even the later HMS Shannon, often described as the first British armored cruiser, would have been too slow to outrun General @-@ Admiral. While Shannon was the last British ship with a retractable propellor, later armored cruisers of the 1870s retained sailing rig, sacrificing speed under steam in consequence. It took until 1881 for the Royal Navy to lay down a long @-@ range armored warship capable of catching enemy commerce raiders, HMS Warspite, which was completed in 1888. While sailing rigs were obsolescent for all purposes by the end of the 1880s, rigged ships were in service until the early years of the 20th century.

In 1866, an American ship, the U.S. schooner Sargent, set a transatlantic speed record of 21.5 knots by crossing the Atlantic in 18 hours and 48 minutes. This was the first time a ship had sailed at such a speed in the Atlantic and it made the world aware of the potential of steam power. However, by the end of the 19th century, sailing ships were no longer the fastest way to travel between Europe and North America, and the Atlantic crossing took more than a year and a half.

Sailing was becoming more popular in the United States, especially among the middle class. This was due to the development of steamships, which were faster and more maneuverable than sailing ships, and could carry more passengers and cargo. The first passenger steamship, the Titanic, was launched in 1912, and in the next 20 years, there were more than 1,000 passenger liners in service around the world.

By the time World War I broke out in 1914, the world had changed, and so had naval armaments. In addition to Germany's submarine-launched torpedoes, which were effective against merchant shipping at the time, other nations began to develop anti-aircraft (AA) weapons, such as the U.S. Mark IV "flying bomb" and the British Hawker Siddeley Sea Hurricane. These weapons could be launched from land, sea, or air, and their range was increased by the introduction of radar in the 1920s. This allowed ships to detect the location of enemy aircraft and destroy them before they could reach their targets.

As a result of these developments, battleships were no longer the only warships capable of fighting in the Atlantic and North Sea. The Royal Navy (R.N.) had been forced to abandon its fleet of dreadnoughts in favor of smaller, less heavily armed battleships, and the United States, which had a far larger navy than either Britain or Germany, was able to dominate the seas and air of the Western Hemisphere.

In addition to the navy, Great Britain had a number of air forces, including the Royal Flying Corps, Air Service, Naval Air Service as well as the Royal Observer Corps. These forces played a vital role in World War I and the Battle of Jutland in 1916-1917.

The British Empire [ edit ]

The British Empire, or Empire of the British Monarchy, was a political union of the dominions of the British Empire (now the Commonwealth of Nations) and its overseas protectorates. The term "empire" is used to describe the union of these dominions rather than the monarchical form of government, which was abolished in 1834.[citation needed]

British Empire [ edit ]

The British Empire consisted of the United Kingdom, the Dominion of Hong Kong, the Dominion of Malaya, the Dominion of South Africa, the Dominions of the British West Indies, the Dominions of Ceylon, the Dominions of Aden-Yarmouk, the Dominions of the Indian Ocean, the Dominions of the Straits Settlements, the Dominions of the Cape of Good Hope, New Hebrides, the Falkland Islands

Few Egyptian guns were actually dismounted, on the other hand, and the fortifications themselves were typically left intact. Had the Egyptians actually utilised the heavy mortars that were at their disposal, they might have quickly turned the tide, for the attacking British ironclads found it easy ( for accuracy's sake ) to simply anchor whilst firing — perfect targets for high @-@ angle fire upon their thinly armoured topdecks.

However, by the mid-19th century there was a growing demand for ironclads, as Britain became the dominant naval power in the world. This was due to the development of steam power, which was able to replace coal as a fuel source for shipbuilding. In addition, the British had begun to explore the North Sea and the Baltic, both of which had rich deposits of iron ores. These factors led to the construction of a number of ironclads, most notably the Dreadnought class of battleships.

The most famous of these ships was the Queen Elizabeth, which served as the flagship of the Admiralty from 1854 to 1885. The Queen Elizabeth was one of the world's first steam-powered warships, and her construction was overseen by Sir Horace Smith-Dorrien, the father of modern shipbuilding. Smith-Dorrien's shipyard in Belfast, Northern Ireland, was responsible for the construction of all of the Queen Elizabeth's sister ships, as well as the ships of the line that followed her.

Russia expanded her navy in the 1880s and 1890s with modern armored cruisers and battleships, but the ships were manned by inexperienced crews and politically appointed leadership, which enhanced their defeat in the Battle of Tsushima on 27 May 1905.

The most important of these innovations was the use of steel for construction, rather than iron. This was a radical change in the design of the ship, and one that would have a profound effect on the shipbuilding industry for the next 100 years. In the late 19th century, steel was expensive, and the cost of construction was a major factor in the decision to go with iron as the material of choice. However, by the early 20th century, steel had become a cheap and readily available material, and it was no longer an impediment to the construction of ships.

Another innovation of the Russian Ironclad was the development of gunnery. The guns were designed to fire on the move, and they had a range of up to 2,000 yards (1,200 m). These guns were the forerunners of today's anti-aircraft guns, and their range was sufficient to shoot down aircraft at low altitudes. Aircraft Edit

Main article: Air Force

The United States Air Force had a total of 6,731 aircraft in service as of 2185, of which 1,931 were fighter/bombers and the rest were ground attack aircraft. The most common types of aircraft were the F-86 Sabre, A-36 Havoc, B-29 Superfortress, P-51 Mustang, and P-38 Lightning. In addition, there were a number of aircraft based in the U.S. that were not airworthy, such as the C-5 Galaxy, C-141 Starlifter, and Cripple Creek-class amphibious transport.

Armament Edit

The main armament of the USAAF was the M2 Browning.50 calibre machine gun, which was mounted on the fuselage and undercarriage of the aircraft. The aircraft could carry up to 4,000 rounds of ammunition, and a crew of 2-3 men was required to operate the weapon. This allowed the aircraft to engage targets at long range without being overstressed and risking engine failure. However, due to the weight of the

reference_text: " Ironclad ", later renamed Azuma 東, " East " ) had a decisive role in the Naval Battle of Hakodate Bay in May 1869, which marked the end of the Boshin War, and the complete establishment of the Meiji Restoration. The IJN continued to develop its strength and commissioned a number of warships from British and European shipyards, first ironclads and later armored cruisers. These ships engaged the Chinese Beiyang fleet which was superior on paper at least at the Battle of the Yalu River. Thanks to superior short @-@ range firepower, the Japanese fleet came off better, sinking or severely damaging eight ships and receiving serious damage to only four. The naval war was concluded the next year at the Battle of Weihaiwei, where the strongest remaining Chinese ships were surrendered to the Japanese.

Characteristics Edit

The Kōtetsu had a blade length of at least 60 cm (2 ft 7 in), and was often referred to as a "dagger" in Japanese media. This made it the most commonly used sword in the Imperial Japanese Navy, and it was used by the Emperor's bodyguards, such as Shinsengumi members Kodo Iemitsu and Hijikata Toshizō, as well as other high-ranking officers of the Imperial Japanese Navy. However, due to its weight, it was not a weapon that a general officer could carry on his or her person without the assistance of a scabbard, and the blade was often wrapped in bandages to protect it from wear and tear during combat. In addition, the katana was a double-edged blade, which meant that it could cut both with and without the use of a hilt. This was an advantage over the more common single-edged sword, which had difficulty cutting a sword-wielding opponent without the use of a hilt.

Dante's terza rima is a poem by Virgil, the son of Aeneas who was sent to the island of Crete as a young man to learn the art of war. In the poem, Dante describes the war between the Carthaginians and the Romans in the second century B.C. This poem has been translated into many languages and is one of the most popular in the world. The first translation of the poem was made in 1590 by Thomas Middleton, a poet of the Elizabethan era. Middleton's translation was based on the Vulgate, the Latin version of the Bible that was in use at the time of Dante's death in 1265. Dante's original Latin is lost, but it is believed that the translation made by Middleton was an accurate translation of the original.

The title comes from a nursery rhyme about a bird that sings to its young: "Little Gidding, where the sun never shines, and the birds never sing." In other words, it's a place where nothing is what it seems, or at least nothing worth thinking about. This is an apt description of the world we live in, where things are as they seem to the untrained eye, but not to those who have the wisdom to see beyond the surface.

Little Gidding is the story of four sisters, the youngest of whom is an orphaned girl named Lavinia. Her sisters have grown up in a castle on the Isle of Wight, but the island is in the middle of a civil war between the King and his sister, Queen Regent Gwenllian. As a result, all communication between the two is cut off, and Lavinia is forced to make her own way in the world by learning to read and write.

Lavinia and her sisters spend their days playing games and exploring the island, which is home to a wide variety of creatures, from dragons to unicorns. The four sisters are separated by their age, and each of them has a different relationship with one or more of the

prefix_text: Writing in the American literary magazine Salmagundi, Alvin H. Rosenfeld called The Portage a " breakthrough work " that " astonishes ".
reference_text: He was struck by the book's interplay between the landscape of swamp and jungle, and the " landscape of speech " — the former being " brilliantly registered " with its " immense feeling of physicality ", and the latter, " even more dramatic " in the way it exposes " the dark underside of words " and how its use and misuse reveals the true nature of a person. He was particularly impressed by the depiction of Nazi hunter Emmanuel Lieber and his role as representative of the Jewish consciousness. Rosenfeld noted that while Holocaust literature often either soars to " expostulation and apostrophe ", or sinks to " a dwindling sob of elegiac lament ", Steiner's Lieber " mediates between these two extremes,... simultaneously records and mourns, coldly enumerates yet carries an immense affect ". What did concern the reviewer, however, was the way Steiner used ideas from his earlier works, that he had put them " virtually verbatim " into Hitler's mouth, creating the impression that " Steiner's understanding of Hitler were identical with the latter's self @-@ understanding ". Rosenfeld also questioned why the book had to end with Hitler's speech. He said that Steiner's fictive Hitler plays " the devil's game of language subversion ", making " madness [ sound ] like music ", something the real Hitler had perfected. By stopping at this point, Rosenfeld felt that Steiner " succumb [ s ], rhetorically, to the seductive eloquence of negation ", which undermines his own " high standards of moral intelligence ". But overall Rosenfeld said The Portage " must be counted among the most vigorous attempts to portray the presence and meaning of Hitler ", forcing us to confront him " in a way hardly seen before in fiction ".

Rosenfeld's praise was echoed by a number of others, among them John Updike, Richard Brautigan, Robert Coalson, William Styron, James Thurber, and Philip Roth.

The Portage was published in the United States by Doubleday & McClure on April 1, 1948, and in Great Britain by Faber & Faber on May 1, 1948. It was a bestseller in both countries, selling more than one million copies in the United States and more than two million copies in Great Britain.

A film of the book was made by Columbia Pictures in 1949, directed by George Cukor (who would go on to direct such films as Casablanca, On the Waterfront, Sunset Boulevard, Gone With the Wind, A Streetcar Named Mockingbird, The Apartment, and more). The film won the Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay that year, and was nominated for a Golden Globe, an Ophtham's Honeymoon, and more.

In addition to its literary merit, The Man Who Knew Too Much has become a touchstone for those who study psychoanalytic theory, as well as an important work in the history of psychoanalysis.

prefix_text: Temnospondyli ( from Greek τέμνειν ( temnein, " to cut " ) and σπ
reference_text: όνδυλος ( spondylos, " vertebra " ) ) is a diverse subclass of extinct small to giant tetrapods — often considered primitive amphibians — that flourished worldwide during the Carboniferous, Permian, and Triassic periods. A few species continued into the Cretaceous. Fossils have been found on every continent. During about 210 million years of evolutionary history, they adapted to a wide range of habitats, including fresh water, terrestrial, and even coastal marine environments. Their life history is well understood, with fossils known from the larval stage, metamorphosis, and maturity. Most temnospondyls were semiaquatic, although some were almost fully terrestrial, returning to the water only to breed. These temnospondyls were some of the first vertebrates fully adapted to life on land. Although temnospondyls are considered amphibians, many had characteristics, such as scales, claws, and armour @-@ like bony plates, that distinguish them from modern amphibians.

prefix_text: Many temnospondyls are much larger than living amphibians, and superficially resemble crocodiles. Others are smaller and resemble salamanders
reference_text: . Most have broad, flat heads that are either blunt ( brevirostrine ) or elongated ( longirostrine ). The skulls are rounded or triangular in shape when viewed from above, and are usually covered in pits and ridges. The rugged surfaces of bones may have supported blood vessels, which could transfer carbon dioxide to the bones to neutralize acidic build up in the blood ( early semiaquatic tetrapods would have had difficulty expelling carbon dioxide from their bodies while on land, and these dermal bones may have been an early solution to the problem ). Many temnospondyls also have canal @-@ like grooves in their skulls called sensory sulci. The sulci, which usually run around the nostrils and eye sockets, are part of a lateral line system used to detect vibrations in water. As semiaquatic animals, most temnospondyls have small limbs with four toes on each front foot and five on each hind foot. Terrestrial temnospondyls have larger, thicker limbs, and some even have claws. One unusual terrestrial temnospondyl, Fayella, has relatively long limbs for its body, and probably lived as an active runner able to chase prey.

Taimyrnthidae, the family to which T. laticauda belongs, is one of the most diverse families of the Mesozoic and includes a wide variety of species, ranging from the size of a toad to the size of a human hand. Some of the species are found in temperate and subtropical regions, while others are found in arid and semiarid regions. The family has an estimated number of 1,000 to 2,000 genera and more than 100,000 species (Fossil Record Search, http://www.fossilrecordsearch.org/taimyrnthidae.html).

In North America, there are at least two subfamilies of Taimyrnthidae, the Laticaudidae and the Eusthenopteridae. The Laticaudidae are characterized by a pair of elongate spines on the back that project into the ventral surface of the carapace, and the Eusthenopteridae by a pair of elongate spines on the

prefix_text: Homologues of most of the bones of temnospondyls are also seen in other early tetrapods, aside from a few bones i
reference_text: the skull, such as interfrontals, internasals, and interparietals, that have developed in some temnospondyl taxa. Most temnospondyls have tabular horns in the backs of their skulls, rounded projections of bone separated from the rest of the skull by indentations called otic notches ; in some temnospondyls, such as Zatrachys, they are pointed and very prominent. Among the most distinguishing features of temnospondyls are the interpterygoid vacuities, two large holes in the back of the palate. Another pair of holes, choanae, are present in front of these vacuities, and connect the nasal passage with the mouth. Temnospondyls often have teeth on their palates, as well as in their jaws. Some of these teeth are so large, they are referred to as tusks. In some temnospondyls, such as Nigerpeton, tusks in the lower jaw pierce the palate and emerge through openings in the top of the skull.

This is an extremely well preserved skull of a Temnospondyl, which gives us a glimpse of the shape of the skull and some of the features that were unique to this group. Note the long snout, which would have been used for chewing, as well as the relatively large eye sockets. Also note the prominent ridge on the occipital condyle, which is a feature shared by all tetrapods that have been found so far.

The teeth of Temnospondyls are similar to those of other tetrapods, but have a different shape and the presence of enamel in the incisors. These teeth are very small in comparison to the rest of the teeth, and the size of the molars is very similar to that of the lower premolars of modern crocodilians. However, there is one difference, and that is the presence of a bifurcating cusp at the back of the tooth. This cusp is present in the teeth of all other tetrapods, but not in the teeth of Temnospondyls. It is thought that this feature evolved to help the teeth

prefix_text: Several groups of temnospondyls have large bony plates on their backs. One temnospondyl, Peltobatrachus
reference_text: , has armour @-@ like plating that covers both its back and underside. The temnospondyl Laidleria also has extensive plating on its back. Most members of the family Dissorophidae also have armor, although it only covers the midline of the back with two narrow rows of plates. Other temnospondyls, such as Eryops, have been found with small, disc @-@ like bony scutes that were in life probably embedded in the skin. All of these temnospondyls were adapted to a terrestrial lifestyle. Armor may have offered protection from predators in the case of Peltobatrachus. The scutes may have provided stability for the spine, as they would have limited flexibility and may have been connected by strong ligaments. Temnospondyls such as Sclerothorax and Eryops that may have been at least partly terrestrial also have long neural spines on top of their vertebrae that would have stabilized the spine. Bony scutes are also seen in plagiosaurs, but unlike Peltobatrachus, Laidleria, Eryops, and dissorophids, these animals are thought to have been fully aquatic. Plagiosaurs may have inherited their armor from a terrestrial ancestor, as both Peltobatrachus and Laidleria have been considered close relatives of the group.

But it was the work of Charles Darwin that led to the classification of the insect as a group in 1859. Darwin's theory of evolution was based on the idea that species evolve over time, rather than from a single ancestor. This meant that, in order to be classified as a species, an organism had to have been around for a long time, and it had to pass through a series of stages that are characteristic of each stage of evolution.

Darwins first taxonomist, Ernst Haeckel, was the first to propose a system of classifying insects according to how long they had been around. The term "stage" was used to describe the number of generations that had passed since the species had evolved to the point where it was no longer reproducing. For example, a caterpillar that had gone through one generation would be classed as a Coccinellid, while a caterpillar that had gone through two generations would be classed as a Hymenoptera.

This system, however, had a few problems. First, there was no way to know what stage a species had reached, which meant that

The plate at the top of the Ganocephala is an ossified bone that forms the base of the vertebral column, and the plate at the bottom is a cartilaginous plate that forms the anterior and posterior ends of the sacrum. Both plates are connected by ligaments and tendons to the bones of the pelvis, and these connective tissues act as shock absorbers, preventing the animal from tumbling into the water when it swims in the water column. This type of animal is referred to as a bony tetrapod because of the shape of the plate at the top and the fact that it has four pairs of legs and a long tail. In contrast, the animal that we are studying in this study, the platypus, is a soft-bodied reptile that does not have a bony skeleton. Instead, the platypus has a soft, rubbery skin that covers its body and allows it to breathe through its skin, as well as move through the water with little effort.

The classification of stegocephalians is based on the presence of a supraorbital fenestra (the opening of the braincase that is used to detect gravity) and an ossicostat (a bone or cartilage that helps maintain the head in a vertical position). These features are thought to have evolved in response to the pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), which is a viscous fluid that circulates around the brain and spinal cord. This fluid contains oxygen and other nutrients that are necessary for brain and spinal cord function. However, the brain and spinal cord are surrounded by a membrane that prevents fluid from escaping and, in some cases, can cause tissue damage.

Lepospondyli are the most common group of stegocephalians, with about 1,000 species in the world. They live in a wide variety of habitats, including freshwater, brackish water, marshes, swamps, saltmarshes, estuaries, and coastal areas. Some species are herbivores, while others are omnivores. Lepospondyli have two eyes, one on each side of the head. The

prefix_text: Temnospondyls first appeared in the Early Carboniferous around 330 million years ago ( Mya ). During the Carboniferous, tem
reference_text: nospondyls included basal medium @-@ sized forms such as Dendrerpeton or large semiaquatic forms such as Cochleosaurus. Other, more derived temnospondyls, such as the amphibamids, were smaller and more terrestrial. They resembled salamanders, and some taxa, such as the genus Branchiosaurus, even retained external gills like the modern @-@ day axolotl. During the latest Carboniferous and Early Permian around 300 Mya, several groups, such as the dissorophids and trematopids evolved strong, robust limbs and vertebrae and became adapted to life on land while others such as the eryopids, developed into large semiaquatic predators. The dvinosaurs, a group of small aquatic temnospondyls, evolved from terrestrial ancestors in the Late Carboniferous.

prefix_text: Originally, temnospondyls were classified according to the structure of their vertebrae. Early forms, with complex vertebrae consisting of a
reference_text: number of separate elements, were placed in the suborder Rachitomi, and large Triassic aquatic forms with simpler vertebrae were placed in the suborder Stereospondyli. With the recent growth of phylogenetics, this classification is no longer viable. The basic rhachitomous condition is found in many primitive tetrapods, and is not unique to one group of temnospondyls. Moreover, the distinction between rhachitomous and stereospondylous vertebrae is not entirely clear. Some temnospondyls have rhachitomous, semirhachitomous, and sterospondylous vertebrae at different points in the same vertebral column. Other taxa have intermediate morphologies that do not fit into any category. Rachitomi is no longer recognized as a group, but Stereospondyli is still considered valid. prefix_text: The most basal group of temnospondyls is the superfamily Edopoidea. Edopoids have several primitive or plesiomorphic
reference_text: features, including a single occipital condyle and a bone called the intertemporal that is absent in other temnospondyls. Balanerpeton woodi is the oldest species, having been present over 330 million years ago during the Viséan stage of the Early Carboniferous. Recent analyses place Dendrerpetontidae outside Edopoidea in a more derived position. Other primitive temnospondyls include Capetus and Iberospondylus. Saharastega and Nigerpeton, both described in 2005 from Niger, are also primitive yet come from the Late Permian. They are almost 40 million years younger than other basal temnospondyls, implying a long ghost lineage of species that are not yet known in the fossil record.

prefix_text: In 2000, paleontologists Adam Yates and Anne Warren produced a revised phylogeny of more derived temnospondyls, naming several new clades
reference_text: . Two major clades were Euskelia and Limnarchia. Euskelia includes the temnospondyls that were once called rhachitomes and includes two subfamilies, the Dissorophoidea and the Eryopoidea. Dissorophoids include small, mostly terrestrial temnospondyls that may be the ancestors of modern amphibians. Eryopoids include larger temnospondyls like Eryops. The second major clade, Limnarchia, includes most Mesozoic temnospondyls, as well as some Permian groups. Within Limnarchia are the superfamily Archegosauroidea and the most derived temnospondyls, the stereospondyls.

In 2000, paleontologists Rainer Schoch and Andrew Milner named a third major clade of stereospondyls, the Rhytidostea. This group included more primitive stereospondyls that could not be placed in either Capitosauria or Trematosauria, and included groups like Lydekkerinidae, Rhytidosteidae, and Brachyopoidea. While Capitosauria and Trematosauria are still widely used, Rhytidostea is not often supported as a true clade in recent analyses. Rhytidosteids and brachyopoids are now grouped with trematosaurians, but lydekkerinids are still considered to be a primitive family of stereospondyls.

prefix_text: A new phylogeny of temnospondyls was offered by paleontologist Rainer Schoch in 2013. It supported many of the clades
reference_text: that were found by Yates and Warren, but it did not find support for their division of derived stereospondyls into Euskelia and Limnarchia. Eryopids were found to be more closely related to stereospondyls than to dissorophoids, which were grouped with dvinosaurs. The clade including Eryopidae and Stereospondylomorpha was named Eryopiformes. In addition, Schoch named the clade containing all temnospondyls except edopoids Eutemnospondyli and reinstated the name Rhachitomi for the clade containing all temnospondyls except edopoids and dendrerpetontids. Schoch's paper was a response to an article by palaeontologist Richard Butler, who argued that there was no need to reclassify theropods, sauropods and ceratopsids, and that they should be considered synapsids rather than monophyletic taxa. This is in line with the idea that the first members of the clade to diverge were the most primitive, and that subsequent lineages evolved in a series of steps from that ancestor. However, Schoch pointed out that Butler was wrong in his interpretation of the fossil record, and that the evidence was in fact consistent with a monophyletic origin for the group. In other words, it was more likely that the group was derived from a group of synapsids than vice versa.

prefix_text: Recently, the theory that temnospondyls were the ancestors of all lissamphibians has gained wide support. The skull morphology of som
reference_text: small temnospondyls has been compared to those of modern frogs and salamanders, but the presence of bicuspid, pedicellate teeth in small, paedomorphic or immature temnospondyls has been cited as the most convincing argument in favor of the temnospondyl origin of lissamphibians. Seen in lissamphibians and many dissorophoid temnospondyls, pedicellate teeth have calcified tips and bases. During the development of most tetrapods, teeth begin to calcify at their tips. Calcification normally proceeds downward to the base of the tooth, but calcification from the tip stops abruptly in pedicellate teeth. Calcification resumes at the base, leaving an area in the center of the tooth uncalcified. This pattern is seen in living amphibians and fossils.

prefix_text: Most aquatic stereospondyls have flattened heads. When feeding, they probably opened their mouths by lifting their skulls instead of lowering their lower jaws. Th
reference_text: jaw mechanics of the plagiosaurid Gerrothorax is well known, and is one of the most highly adapted. Gerrothorax is thought to have lifted its skull to around 50 ° above horizontal through the flexing of the atlanto @-@ occipital joint between the occipital condyles of the skull and the atlas vertebra of the neck. As the skull is raised, the quadrate bone pushes forward and causes the lower jaw to protrude outward. Other stereospondyls probably also lifted their skulls, but they are not as well adapted for such movement. D.M.S. Watson was the first to suggest skull lifting as a means of feeding in temnospondyls. He envisioned that Mastodonsaurus, a much larger temnospondyl than Gerrothorax, was able to make the same movement. Paleontologist A.L. Panchen also supported the idea in 1959, suggesting that Batrachosuchus also fed in this way. At the time it was thought that these temnospondyls lifted their heads with strong jaw muscles, but it is now thought that they used larger muscles in the neck that were attached to the large pectoral girdle. Plagiosuchus, a close relative of Gerrothorax, also has a hyobranchial skeleton that muscles may have attached to. Plagiosuchus has very small teeth and a large area for muscle attachment behind the skull, suggesting that it could suction feed by rapidly opening its mouth.

prefix_text: Temnospondyls, like all amphibians, reproduced in aquatic environments. Most temnospondyls probably reproduced through external fertilization.
reference_text: Like most living frogs, female temnospondyls would have laid masses of eggs in water while males released sperm to fertilize them. Several fossils were described from the Early Permian of Texas in 1998 that may be egg masses of dissorophoid temnospondyls. They were the first known fossils of amphibian eggs. The fossils consist of small disks with thin membranes that are probably vitelline membranes and halo @-@ like areas surrounding them that are most likely mucous coatings. They are attached to plant fossils, suggesting that these temnospondyls laid eggs on aquatic plants much like modern frogs. The mucous membranes show that the eggs were laid by amphibians, not fish ( their eggs lack mucous ), but the type of amphibian that laid them cannot be known because no body fossils are preserved with the eggs. The eggs are thought to be from dissorophoids because they are likely to be close relatives of modern amphibians, and probably had similar reproductive strategies. They are also the most common amphibians from the deposit in which the eggs were found.

A female wasp lays her eggs on a leaf, which she covers with pollen. The larva is about the size of a grain of rice, and feeds on nectar and pollen until it pupates. In the pupal stage, the larva crawls to the surface to breathe, and then burrows into the soil or leaf of its host plant. After a few days, the larva emerges from the soil and begins to molt, shedding its exoskeleton and developing a new body. This process is repeated several times over the course of about a month or so, during which time the larva grows to a length of about 1/2 inch (12 mm). At this point, the larva becomes a pupa, which can live for as long as two years. During this time, the pupa is in a cocoon made of silk, which is attached to the underside of the host plant. When the time comes for the pupa to emerge, it is ready to pupate in the soil or leaf of its host plant.

prefix_text: Temnospondyls like Sclerocephalus are known from both large adult specimens and small larvae, showing an extreme change in body shape.
reference_text: In these species, the shape and proportions of skull bones change in the early stages of development. The ornamentation on the surface of the skull roof also develops at this time. Small, regularly spaced pits are the first to form, followed by larger ridges. As development continues, the external gills disappear. Small teeth that once covered the palate are lost. The postcranial skeleton does not develop at the same rate as the skull, with ossification ( the replacement of cartilage by bone ) happening more slowly. Vertebrae and limb bones are poorly developed, ribs and fingers are absent in the early stages, and the scapulocoracoid and ischium are entirely absent through most of development. Once maturity is reached, most bones have fully formed and growth rate slows. The bones of some temnospondyls like Dutuitosaurus show growth marks, possibly an indication that growth rate varied with the change in seasons. Fossils of temnospondyls like Metoposaurus and Cheliderpeton show that individuals grew larger past maturity. The oldest individuals usually have more pitting on their skulls with deeper sulci.

prefix_text: While most temnospondyls are aquatic in early stages of life, most metoposaurids appear to have been terrestrial in their juvenile stag
reference_text: . Like other Mesozoic temnospondyls, adult metoposaurids were adapted to a semiaquatic lifestyle. Their bones are not highly developed for movement on land. The cross @-@ sectional thickness of limb bones in adult metoposaurids shows that they could not withstand the stress of terrestrial locomotion. Juvenile individuals have bones that are thick enough to withstand this stress, and could probably move about on land. To maintain a terrestrial lifestyle, a temnospondyl's limb bones would have to thicken with positive allometry, meaning that they would grow at a greater rate than the rest of the body. This is not the case in metoposaurids, meaning that as their bodies grew larger they became less adapted toward a terrestrial lifestyle.

This region was rich in dinosaur fossils, and many of these were collected by paleontologists during expeditions to the region in the 1920s and 1930s. reference_text: drum — or homologous tympanum — to the inner ear. Temnospondyls also have a stapes, which projects into the otic cavity. The stapes likely evolved from the hyomandibula of lobe @-@ finned fishes. The positioning of the stapes and the shape of the otic region suggests that the tympani of temnospondyls and frogs are homologous, but the tympani of these amphibians are no longer considered homologous with the hearing systems of reptiles, birds, and mammals. Therefore, ear structures in temnospondyls were not ancestral to those of all other tetrapods.

Tetrapods are the only vertebrates that do not have a bony structure at the base of the spinal column to help them stand on their hind legs. This is because the spine is made of cartilage and not bone, as we know from looking at the skeletons of birds and crocodilians.

There are a number of theories as to why tetrapods have no spine, but the most popular is that it evolved as a way of protecting the neck from injury during locomotion. In this case, the vertebrae would act as shock absorbers and protect the neck from being crushed by the weight of the body.

Another theory is that the spine has nothing to do with walking and is just an ornamental feature to show off the animal's beauty. This theory is supported by the fact that many of the most beautiful animals on the planet, such as peacocks, giraffes, zebras, etc. have spines in their necks.

reference_text: have thick stapes with poor impedance matching, so it is now thought that they were not used for hearing. Early temnospondyls like Dendrerpeton could not hear airborne sound but would have been able to detect vibration in the ground. The hearing system of Doleserpeton and related temnospondyls was able to detect airborne sound and may have been ancestral to that of living amphibians.

In contrast, the tympanum and stapes are designed to have a low impedance, which means that they can vibrate with sufficient force to produce sound. This is important because sound is the result of vibrations that travel through air, rather than through a solid object like a tree trunk or rock.

Tetrapods are the only vertebrates that have an organ that is used for vibration, the cochlea. The cochlea is made up of a spiral-shaped structure called the hair cell, which is surrounded by a fluid-filled sac called the vacuole. The hair cell vibrates in response to sound waves, and when it does, it pushes fluid out of the vacuole and back into the hair cell. This fluid is the "sonic fluid" that we hear when we listen to music.

prefix_text: Osbert de Bayeux ( floruit 1121 to 1184 ) was a medieval English cleric and archdeacon in the Diocese of York
reference_text: . A relative of Thurstan, the Archbishop of York, Osbert probably owed his ecclesiastical positions to this relative. After Thurstan's death, Osbert was opposed to one of the candidates for the archbishopric, William fitzHerbert, and worked to secure fitzHerbert's deposition and replacement by Henry Murdac. After Murdac's death in 1153, Osbert tried to prevent the return of fitzHerbert, but these attempts were unsuccessful. When fitzHerbert died suddenly in 1154, Osbert was accused of murdering the newly returned archbishop. Although he was never convicted of the murder in either a secular or an ecclesiastical court, he was stripped of his clerical status and became a layman before 1158. He died after 1184, perhaps even after 1194.

reference_text: tropical depression, tropical storm, and hurricane / typhoon / intense tropical cyclone intensities ) based solely on visible and infrared satellite images. Within the Dvorak satellite strength estimate for tropical cyclones, there are several visual patterns that a cyclone may take on which define the upper and lower bounds on its intensity. The primary patterns used are curved band pattern ( T1.0 @-@ T4.5 ), shear pattern ( T1.5 @-@ T3.5 ), central dense overcast ( CDO ) pattern ( T2.5 @-@ T5.0 ), central cold cover ( CCC ) pattern, banding eye pattern ( T4.0 @-@ T4.5 ), and eye pattern ( T4.5 - T8.0 ).

In this paper, we present a new estimate of the number of tropical cyclones based on the Dvorak technique. This estimate is in line with the most recent assessment by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and other global and hemispheric climate models.

Methods and Findings

Our study is based on data from the Tropical Cyclone Forecast System (TCFSS) (Trenberth et al. 2009), which is a computer model run at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) in Boulder, Colorado. The TCFSS runs a set of climate models that simulate the evolution of tropical cyclones over the past 50 years. These models are designed to simulate the climate of the mid-latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere (Meyer-Lindenberg et al. 2006; Kattenhorn et al. 2007) and have been used to forecast tropical cyclones since the 1970s (see for example the discussion of this model in Ruedy-Pérez-E

The eye pattern utilizes the coldness of the cloud tops within the surrounding mass of thunderstorms and contrasts it with the temperature within the eye itself. The larger the temperature difference is, the stronger the tropical cyclone. Once a pattern is identified, the storm features ( such as length and curvature of banding features ) are further analyzed to arrive at a particular T @-@ number. As mentioned above, there are two types of eye patterns: central and embedded. In the central pattern, the eyes are in a line, and the center of the eye is on the sunspot and central region of the CDO. Aboriginal Dreaming

The Aboriginal Dreaming is a set of stories that have been passed down through the generations and are the basis of Aboriginal culture. It is an oral tradition and is not written, as in other cultures. Dreaming, in this context, means telling stories, making stories, or reciting stories.

Dreams are important to Aboriginal people because they provide a link to the past and help them cope with the present. The stories tell of people's lives before they were taken from their families and placed in boarding schools, as well as the hardships they faced after being returned to their homelands. These stories are often told in the language of the people who told them, or in English if there is no language at all.

Many Aboriginal people do not speak English as their first language and are unable to read or write in English. In these cases, the stories are translated into Aboriginal languages and stories are recited to the people who have never heard them before. This is called "translation" and is done by a group of translators, usually from the community where the story originates.

Bacon's most famous painting, The Descent of Man, is a portrait of a naked man descending into a chasm filled with blackness. The painting was painted in 1832, the year of Charles Darwin's On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection (Darwin, 1859–1882). Darwin's theory of evolution, based on observation of natural selection, became the foundation of modern biology and biology-related fields, including paleontology (the study of fossils) and zoology (the study of animals). In the painting, Bacon has created a world in which the body is an unspeakable abomination, a pit of filth and decay that threatens to devour the body and all that it holds dear.

The scene evokes the scene in Dante's Paradiso where Virgil and Beatrice kiss in the Garden of Delights.

Bacon was a fan of Velázquez's work from the first time he laid eyes on it. "I had a copy of the original in my study at the time, and that's how I came to know him," Bacon told The New York Times in an interview published in 1894. "It was an instant love affair, the most passionate that I ever had with a work of art." The two became close friends, and Bacon became the first person to have a portrait of Velázquez hung in his home and the gallery he worked in.


In his book The Art of the Portrait, Bacon described the process of reproducing Velázquez's work as "very laborious, as one would expect from a work of this kind" and that it took three years to complete the work. The painting was finished in the summer of 1894, and it was exhibited to the public in New York on October 2, 1894. The following year, Bacon published a book of his own, which was based on the painting. The title of the book was, of course, Bacon's portrait of Velázquez.

It is hard to say what is the most striking thing about this book, apart from the fact that it is a work of art in its own right. I have no problem with this at all, and in fact find it to be one of the book's strongest points. Velázquez, as we know, was the son of a priest, and this is reflected in his writing in a way that few other painters of his time were able to do. The language is simple, the pictures are simple, and the subject matter is simple: people, nature, the sun, a house or a landscape in the middle of the night. There is no pretence to anything other than what is in the picture, and that is to say, the pictures are of a very high calibre.

This does not mean that the book is without its faults. For one thing, it is not as long as one might hope, and this is a problem for anyone who wants to read it in one sitting. The first half of the book
