After the meeting of Londonderry Corporation was again disrupted in August, Eamon Melaugh telephoned the Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association ( NICRA ) and invited them to hold a march in Derry. The date chosen was 5 October 1968, an adhoc committee was formed ( although in reality most of the organizing was done by McCann and Melaugh ) and the route was to take the marchers inside the city walls, where nationalists were traditionally not permitted to march. The Minister of Home Affairs, William Craig, made an order on 3 October prohibiting the march on the grounds that the Apprentice Boys of Derry were intending to hold a march on the same day. In the words of Martin Melaugh of CAIN " this particular tactic... provided the excuse needed to ban the march. " When the marchers attempted to defy the ban on 5 October they were stopped by a Royal Ulster Constabulary ( RUC ) cordon. The police drew their batons and struck marchers, including Stormont MP Eddie McAteer and Westminster MP Gerry Fitt. Subsequently the police " broke ranks and used their batons indiscriminately on people in Duke Street ". Marchers trying to escape met another party of police and " these police also used their batons indiscriminately. " Water cannons were also used. The police action caused outrage in the nationalist area of Derry, and at a meeting four days later the Derry Citizens'Action Committee ( DCAC ) was formed, with John Hume as chairman and Ivan Cooper as vice @-@ chairman.

The Irish Republican Army (IRA) [ edit ]

The Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA) was formed in the summer of 1921 by James Connolly, Seán Mac Diarmada O'Mahony, John McGahern (later to change his name to Parnell) and Michael Mallin. The three men were members of the Sinn Féin Party and had worked together for a number of years before the formation of the PIRA. In 1921, McGahern was a student at Trinity College Dublin, while Mac Diarmada was studying for a doctorate in law at University College Galway (UCD). Mallin was an Irish-born barrister and had served as solicitor-general for the Irish Free State during the Civil War and was the brother-in-law of the British Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin.

The barricades were taken down the following morning.

The parade is a great way to spend a Sunday afternoon and it is well worth checking out if you are in the area.

prefix_text: Chad is a landlocked country in Africa whose northern region lies within the eastern reaches of the Sahara Desert and whose southern region lies within the eastern portion of th
reference_text: Sahel. It borders Libya to the south, Niger to the east, Sudan to the west, and the Central African Republic to the north. Chad was originally part of French West Africa until 1960, when it declared independence. Some four years later, the former French colony made its début at the 1964 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan. For the next three decades, Chad became embroiled in civil war and experienced invasions by Libya and upheavals by Sudanese @-@ backed rebels ; the civil war ended in 1990, although rebel threats had persisted between then and 2008. During Chad's greatest era of instability, athletes from the country did not attend the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montréal, Canada or the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow, USSR, although delegations were sent to all other games between 1964 and 2008.

prefix_text: The name of Bintulu was derived from the local native language " Mentu Ulau " ( picking heads ). Bintulu was a small fishing
reference_text: village when Rajah James Brooke acquired it in 1861. Brooke later built a fort there in 1862. In 1867, the first General Council meeting ( now Sarawak State Legislative Assembly ) was convened in Bintulu. It is the earliest state legislature system in Malaysia. The construction of the earliest airstrip in Bintulu began in 1934 but was halted in 1938 due to financial difficulties. During World War II, the airstrip was heavily bombed by Allied forces. The British later rebuilt the airstrip, and it became fully operational in 1955. The old airport was replaced by a new airport in 2002. Bintulu remained a fishing village until 1969 when oil and gas reserves were discovered off the coast. Since then, Bintulu has become the centre of energy intensive industries such as a Malaysia LNG plant, a Shell Middle Distillate Synthesis plant, and a Bintulu combined cycle power plant. The economy has also expanded into oil palm and forest plantations, palm oil processing, wood @-@ waste processing, and cement manufacturing. The port of Bintulu is the busiest in Sarawak. The town is also a gateway to Samalajau Industrial Park.

prefix_text: During the 16th century, Bintulu was named " River de Burulu " by Portuguese cartographers. There are several legends surrounding the name Bi
reference_text: intulu. During the Brooke dynasty, the indigenous Iban people practised headhunting to maintain their social status in the community. They threw the heads into the Kemena River, after which the heads had to be collected from the river. The practice of collecting the heads was known as " Mentu Ulau " ( picking heads ) in the local native language. Another story relates that two Iban warriors named Bernik and Jelab built houses along the river. They and their followers frequently carried out preservation of severed heads near a small river stream branching off from Sebezaw River because the river bank was flat and wide. Therefore, the small river stream was named " Mentu Ulau " river. Outsiders who came to Bintulu subsequently pronounced the name as " Mentulau ", and later the name evolved into " Bentulu " and, finally, " Bintulu ".

According to legend, a man named Nokomot, an African slave, escaped from his captors and made his way to the river. After crossing the river, Nokomot fell into the water and swam for three days and three nights without eating or drinking. On the third day, his hunger overcame him and he swallowed a fish, which turned out to be a kingfisher. The kingfisher's beak was filled with poison, and Nokomot died of suffocation. Legend has it that the river was named after him to pay tribute to his spirit.

The forest has an abundance of flora and fauna, as well as a rich history of human habitation dating back to the Neolithic era (10,000 to 5,000 BC).

Brooke's career as a merchant was short-lived and he returned to Sarawak after a few years, this time with plans to set up a sugar plantation. Brooke died in 1872 and was buried in a cemetery in his native village of Pangkalan Bun, which is now the site of the National Museum of Sarawak. The museum was inaugurated in 1976 and houses a collection of artefacts related to Brooke's life and the history of the island.

reference_text: intulu was still a small fishing village, with a population of 5 @,@ 000. No roads were constructed in Bintulu until 1969 when the first untarred road was built to connect Bintulu to Miri. The first bus that serviced the Miri – Bintulu route was owned by Majlis Amanah Rakyat ( MARA ). The MARA bus line was an initiative by the Malaysian federal government to provide public transportation for the people. The Iban villagers paid the bus driver with " vegetables, chickens, bamboo shoots, and other items ". Before 1960, Bintulu was connected to Kuching by sea through a ship named " Swee Joo ". After 1960, the ship " Chin Chin " was added to the route. It took around 36 to 48 hours to reach Bintulu from Kuching, depending on the sea conditions. Due to lack of food supplies from Kuching, the villagers had to make do with limited food, and several villagers resorted to hunting in the jungles to supplement the food supply.

History [ edit ]

Early history [ edit the table of contents ]

[1] During the 18th and 19th centuries, British and Dutch explorers, traders, and colonizers came to the islands in search of gold, rubber, and other natural resources. The islanders resisted colonization, and in 1816, a war broke out between the Dutch and the British to determine who would control the islands. The British won the war, and by 1820, control of the islands was handed over to the U.S. Navy. After the war, the islands were divided into British and Dutch territories, which remained under British control until independence in 1962.

A few years ago I started my research into the history of Bintulu, which led me to the area known as "the graveyard" where thousands of bodies were exhumed in the 1950s and '60s to test the theory that malaria was the cause of death. This was a time when there was no vaccine for malaria, and the government did not know what to do with the bodies that were left in the open for a few days to decompose. It was an unsanitary and inhumane practice that caused a lot of pain and suffering to the bereaved families, who had to pay for the funerals of their loved ones.

After the death of my mother-in-law, I decided to look into the issue of burial practices in Bintulu and found that many of the people who had died in the early '50s and '60s were buried in a pit that was about 20 metres deep and 10 metres wide. The pit had no water, and people were forced to bathe in the pit every day, even during the rainy season. This practice was carried out by the government and private companies, with the permission of the local chief minister at the time, as well as the police.

The mission was a resounding success, but not without a price. More than 10,000 Serbs were killed, most of them civilians, and hundreds of thousands of homes were razed to the ground.

In the aftermath of the war, Bosnia's political leaders sought to make amends by signing the Dayton Accords, which called for a federal system of self-governing Bosnia and Herzegovina. The new state was to be known as Republika Srpska (RS), and it came into being on April 1, 2006.

prefix_text: On 18 May 1991, the Zrinski Battalion was established as a special forces unit of the ZNG. The core of the unit consisted of 27 volunteers
reference_text: drawn from the Kumrovec Special Police Unit ( SPU ). Initially, it relied on former French Foreign Legion troops. The most senior among the former legionnaires was Ante Roso, previously a Sous @-@ Officier ( non @-@ commissioned officer – NCO ) in the 4th Foreign Regiment. In consequence, Roso was tasked with setting up the unit as its initial commander. Major Miljenko Filipović, likewise a former French Foreign Legion member, was assigned the battalions deputy commander. The unit was based in the village of Kumrovec in the region of Hrvatsko Zagorje, on the grounds of the former " Josip Broz Tito " political school. The site, adjacent to the border of Slovenia, was selected to be inaccessible to Yugoslav Air Force raids without violation of Slovene or possibly Austrian airspace. In June 1991, the Kumrovec SPU was transferred to Sljeme Peak north of Zagreb leaving Kumrovec base to the Zrinski Battalion, as well as the second special forces unit, the Frankopan Battalion.

In the summer of 1991, the Zrinski Battalion began to take part in Operation Barbarossa, the invasion of the Soviet Union by the German Armed Forces. On 1 September, the first of a series of operations to recapture Stalingrad was launched in the area of Vyazma, which was under the control of the Red Army. During the battle, the battalion suffered heavy losses, but managed to repel the assault and hold the city until the end of the war.

After the war, the Zrinski Battalion was reintegrated into the German Armed Forces and remained in service until its disbandment in 1994.

During the Second World War, the Zrinski Battalion was one of the most successful units of the SS-Totenkopfverbände, with a reputation for fighting courageously under difficult conditions. It is estimated that more than 1,000 men from the battalion were killed in action and another 1,000 were wounded.

In September, the battalion was deployed to Gospić, where it took part in battle to control Gospić against the JNA. Troops assigned to the battalion captured Kaniža barracks in Gospić. The ZNG was renamed the Croatian Army ( Hrvatska vojska – HV ) on 3 November 1991. In late 1991, personnel of the Zrinski Battalion set up another special forces unit of the HV — the Matija Vlačić Battalion based in Opatija.

reference_text: it does today, the initial routing of NY 93 deviated from the modern path in the vicinity of the city of Lockport. The first mile of the trail is in a wooded area with lots of brush and downed trees. The forest is thick and very overgrown, making it difficult to see where you are going. At the end of this mile, you come to a fork in the trail. Go left (north) to continue on the Appalachian Trail (AT) for a few more miles. Or, turn right (south) and follow the river downstream to the river crossing. This is a good place to get a feel for the terrain before you head into the woods.

I'm sure there are a lot of people who have no idea what this is, but it's an old-school train, the kind that used to run all the way from New York to Chicago. It's a little different from the Amtrak and Metropolitans of yore, but not much. The carriages are old, the scenery has aged with the passage of time, and the scenery is the best part of the trip. You get to see the city in all its splendor, from the rooftops of Midtown to the back alleys of Little Italy.

The trip starts with a stop at Union Station, where you're greeted by a sign that reads "Welcome to Akron, home of the world's largest rail museum." This is a good time to point out that Akron is the only city in the United States with a museum dedicated to railroading. The museum is housed in the Akron-Canton Railroad Museum, which was founded in 1892 by railroad magnate and philanthropist Henry W. "Hank" Cleveland. Cleveland was one of the most powerful men in the country at the time, and his support helped the railroad get off the ground. The museum houses artifacts from Cleveland's railroad days,

On the morning of September 11, 2001, President George W. Bush declared a state of emergency in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut and activated the National Guard. This was the first time in American history that the military was called into the state of emergency to deal with a terrorist attack. The following day, on September 12, 2001, President Bush signed Executive Order 11905, which provided for the establishment of a Civil Defense Agency (CDAA) within the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). The CDAA was charged with the responsibility of coordinating the Federal, State, and local governments in response to civil emergencies, as well as providing disaster preparedness and response training to the public at large.

prefix_text: On the outbreak of World War I in 1914, Fabian Ware, a director of the Rio Tinto Company, found that at 45 years old he was
reference_text: too old to join the British Army. He used the influence of Rio Tinto chairman, Viscount Milner, to become the commander of a mobile unit of the British Red Cross. He arrived in France in September 1914 and whilst there was struck by the lack of any official mechanism for documenting or marking the location of graves of those who had been killed and felt compelled to create an organisation within the Red Cross for this purpose. In March 1915, with the support of Nevil Macready, Adjutant @-@ General of the British Expeditionary Force, Ware's work was given official recognition and support by the Imperial War Office and the unit was transferred to the British Army as the Graves Registration Commission. The new Graves Registration Commission had over 31 @,@ 000 graves of British and Imperial soldiers registered by October 1915 and 50 @,@ 000 registered by May 1916.

The story of Ware's life is a cautionary tale for anyone who wants to live long and prosper, but it has one particular wrinkle: Ware had no family, and his only connection to the outside world was a letter of recommendation from his brother-in-law, an Army officer in the Pacific. In other words, he was a "stranger in a strange land" to most Americans of his time and place.

But that's not the case for most of the 1.5 billion people who live in the world today. The World Health Organization estimates that there are more than a billion people around the world without access to electricity, running water, a sewage system (which is a big deal in developing countries where waterborne diseases are common), or any of the services that modern life requires. That's one in every seven people on the planet.

And it's not just the lack of access that's a problem. A study in the Journal of the American Medical Association found that, on average, people with no access to health care die five years earlier than those with access to care. In some countries, such as sub-Saharan Africa, the gap is as high as 20 years.

prefix_text: As reports of the grave registration work became public, the Commission began to receive letters of enquiry and requests for photographs of graves from relatives of deceased soldiers.

The Graves Registration Commission became the Directorate of Graves Registration and Enquiries in the spring of 1916 in recognition of the fact that the scope of work began to extend beyond simple grave registration and began to include responding to enquiries from relatives of those killed. The directorate's work was also extended beyond the Western Front and into other theatres of war, with units deployed in Greece, Egypt and Mesopotamia.

prefix_text: The scale, and associated high number of casualties, of the war produced an entirely new attitude towards the commemoration of war dead. Previous to World War I
reference_text: , individual commemoration of war dead was often on an ad hoc basis and was almost exclusively limited to commissioned officers. However, the war required mobilisation of a significant percentage of the population, either as volunteers or through conscription. An expectation had consequently arisen that individual soldiers would expect to be commemorated, even if they were low @-@ ranking members of the military. A committee under Frederic Kenyon, Director of the British Museum, presented a report to the Commission in November 1918 detailing how it envisioned the development of the cemeteries. Two key elements of this report were that bodies should not be repatriated and that uniform memorials should be used to avoid class distinctions. Beyond the logistical nightmare of returning home so many corpses, it was felt that repatriation would conflict with the feeling of brotherhood that had developed between serving ranks.

This marked the beginning of the practice of commemorating the war dead in national ceremonies, as opposed to individual commemorations by local or private individuals. It was not until the end of the war in 1918 that the practice became widespread throughout the British Empire and, to a lesser extent, the United States of America.

It was not until the 1950s that the memorial was moved to its current location, where it remains to this day. In recent years there have been calls for it to be moved again, but so far no decision has been taken.

In 1885 an Act of Parliament provided for the erection of gravestones to be inscribed with epitaphs, which were to be in the form of a stone or stone slab with inscriptions on the front and back. The inscription on the front was the name of the deceased, followed by the date of death, and the inscription on the back was the family name or a descriptive epithets such as "son of" or "husband of". This Act was repealed in 1912 and a new Act was passed in 1927 to replace it with the more modern statute of burial (section 2 of the Coroners and Justice Act 1987).

Grave markers and headstones have become a part of the landscape over the last 100 years or so, and there are a number of reasons for this. First, it is easier to mark a grave than it is to write a name on a headstone. Secondly, the design of the stone is more ornate than that of a headstone, and this adds to the sense of permanence. Thirdly, gravestones are often placed in front of a house or other building that is the focus of the community, and these can be seen as a memorial to the deceased in the same way that a

Sometimes a soldier employed a pseudonym because they were too young to serve or were sought by law enforcement ; in such cases their primary name is shown along with the notation " served as ". Many headstones are for unidentified casualties ; they consequently bear only what could be discovered from the body. The epitaph, developed by Rudyard Kipling, that appears on the graves of unidentified soldiers for which no details are known is " A Soldier of the Great War known unto God ". Some headstones bear the text " believed to be buried in this cemetery " when they are believed to be buried in the cemetery but the exact location of the grave is not known. In some cases soldiers were buried in collective graves and distinguishing one body from another was not possible and thus one headstone covers more than one grave. The headstone does not denote any specific details of the death except for its date, and even then only if it is known, and are deliberately ambiguous about the cause of death.

Combining structural and horticultural elements was not unfamiliar to the Commission's architects. In the 19th century, cemetery designers began to experiment with ways to add interest to the cemetery and increase visitors' interest in visiting the cemetery. One of the most popular methods was to place flowers in the graves of loved ones who had died in the past few years. These flowers were placed on the gravestones to commemorate the passing of the loved one, as well as to remind visitors that the cemetery was a place of rest from the stresses of life. The practice of placing flowers in the graves of loved ones began to become popular in the United States and other countries in the mid-1800s. By the end of the 19th century, floral interments were a common feature of cemeteries, and many people felt that this was a more dignified way of commemorating the dead than the use of headstones.

The Letters of the Magi

One of the best-preserved manuscripts of the Magi is the Codex Regius, which dates from the 11th century. This is a codex made of vellum (a type of papyrus) and contains about 1,000 pages in total. The text on the Codex Regius is written in Latin, the language of the Roman Empire at the time. It is very difficult to read, but it does contain some interesting information about the life of the Magi.

These qualities were displayed in the two surviving manuscripts of his riddles and four of his Ars Tatuini. The Ars is one of only two surviving 8th @-@ century Latin grammars from England, and was based on the works of Priscian and Consentius. The riddles deal with such diverse topics as philosophy and charity, the five senses and the alphabet, and a book and a pen. The riddles are formed in acrostics. The grammar is a reworking of Donatus's Ars Minor with the addition of information drawn from other grammarians. It was not designed for a newcomer to the Latin language, but is designed for more advanced students. It covers the eight parts of speech through illustrations drawn from classical scholars, although not directly but through other grammatical works. There are also some examples drawn from the Psalms. The work was completed before he became archbishop, and was used not only in England but also on the continent. A recent edition of his works is Tatuini Opera omnia, published in 1968 with some translations into English and German from the original Latin.

Gibraltar became a focal point for the British-American Civil War of 1864-1865 and the Anglo-American Naval War of 1864-1865. During the war, the British garrison was forced to evacuate and many of the townspeople were interned in Gibraltar for their loyalty to the United States of America. In 1866, the town was reincorporated as a British Overseas Territory by Queen Victoria in order to avoid the embarrassment of a U.S. invasion of Great Britain by the Confederate States of America (CSA). However, this was short-lived, as the CSA declared war on the United States in 1866 and invaded the British territory, taking Gibraltar by force on April 2, 1866.
